THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Margaret T. Carrigg, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Cusch, Inc. and Moos Brothers of Charleston, Inc., d/b/a T-Bonz Restaurant, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-067
Submitted January, 1 2006 â€“ Filed February 1, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Richard Alexander Murdaugh, of Hampton, for Appellant.
        Derek Farrell Dean, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This is a slip and fall case.Â  Carrigg alleged that while dining at a restaurant owned by Cusch, Inc., d/b/a T-Bonz Restaurant (T-Bonz), she slipped on water on the floor leading to the restroom and fell, injuring herself.Â  The circuit court granted T-Bonzâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
1.Â Â Â Â Â Â  In order to recover for injuries sustained in a fall caused by a foreign substance on the storekeeperâ€™s floor, a customer must prove either that the foreign substance was placed on the floor by the storekeeper or that the storekeeper had actual or constructive notice of the foreign substance on the floor and failed to remove it.Â  Wintersteen v. Food Lion, Inc., 344 S.C. 32, 35, 542 S.E.2d 728, 729 (2001).Â  No evidence in the record indicates that employees of T-Bonz caused the water to be placed on the floor, or that anyone at T-Bonz had actual knowledge of the water.Â  Thus, negligence can be established only by a showing of constructive knowledge.Â  We hold that Carrigg is unable to demonstrate constructive notice pursuant to the following authorities:Â  Gillespie v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., 302 S.C. 90, 91, 394 S.E.2d 24, 25 (Ct. App. 1990) (holding that the mere fact that water was on the floor and within the vision of store employees is not enough to establish constructive knowledge); Young v. Meeting Street Piggly Wiggly, 288 S.C. 508, 510, 343 S.E.2d 636, 637-38 (Ct. App. 1986) (holding that a merchantâ€™s liability may not be based solely on the presence of moisture on the floor); Olson v. Faculty House of Carolina, Inc., 354 S.C. 161, 165-66, 580 S.E.2d 440, 442 (2003) (holding that to impose a duty on merchants to continuously inspect and maintain floors to ensure their freedom from foreign substances would effectively render them insurers of customer safety).Â  
2.Â Â Â Â Â Â  We find that Carriggâ€™s arguments to the effect that T-Bonz either created an unreasonably dangerous condition by failing to cover the entire floor with the mats or was on notice of the dangerous condition as evidenced by its policy of placing the mats on the floor are not properly preserved for appeal.Â  See Elam v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 361 S.C. 9, 23, 602 S.E.2d 772, 779-780 (2004) (holding that issues and arguments are preserved for appellate review only when they are raised to and ruled on by the lower court).Â  In any event, we find the arguments fail on the merits pursuant to the following authorities: Olson, 354 S.C. at 166, 580 S.E.2d at 443 (holding that merchants are not required to make floors more slip-resistant when they are wet); Wintersteen, 344 S.C. at 37, 542 S.E.2d at 731 (holding that in slip-and-fall cases involving foreign substances, courts in this state have rejected a â€œduty to preventâ€ rule, thus requiring a plaintiff to prove actual or constructive notice).Â  
AFFIRMED. 
STILWELL, KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Â Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Toni E. Cooke, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Richard C. Cooke, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Dillon County
Jamie Lee Murdock, Jr., Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-068Â Â Â  
Heard November 16, 2005 â€“ Filed February 1, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Evander G. Jeffords, of Florence; John S. Nichols, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        George M. Hearn, Jr., of Conway, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Toni Cooke (Wife) appeals from the order of the family court identifying, valuing, and apportioning the marital property and awarding Wife $15,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees and $15,000 in expert fees.Â  We affirm. 
FACTS
Richard C. Cooke (Husband) and Wife married in August of 1984.Â  At the time of their marriage Husband was a twenty-four year old farmer and Wife was an eighteen year old high school senior.Â  Husbandâ€™s father was in the nursing home business.Â  Shortly after the couple married, Husband took and passed the test to become a nursing home administrator.Â  Wife graduated from high school and worked part-time at a drug store and went to college, until she gave birth to the coupleâ€™s son, Richard, in 1986.Â  In 1989, the couple entered into an agreement to operate McCoy Memorial Nursing Center (McCoy).Â  Wife returned to college and graduated in 1991.Â  She began taking the test to become a nursing home administrator, which she ultimately passed in 2002.Â  
In 1992, the couple formed Cooke Management Company, which they used to manage McCoy and one of Husbandâ€™s fatherâ€™s facilities.Â  In 1994, the coupleâ€™s daughter, Avonlea, was born.Â  That same year the couple formed A&R Enterprises to manage and lease McCormick Health Care and Fountain Inn Nursing Home.Â  The couple continued to manage those nursing homes in addition to several others until their separation in November of 2000.Â  
In February 2001, Wife commenced an action seeking separate maintenance and support, joint custody, determination of child support, alimony, equitable apportionment of the marital property, and an award of attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  The family court issued a temporary injunction and restraining order prohibiting the parties from disposing of or encumbering marital property.Â  In May 2002, the family court granted the couple a divorce based on one yearâ€™s continuous separation and approved a joint custody agreement awarding custody of their son to Husband and custody of their daughter to Wife.Â  In its order, the family court also retained jurisdiction over all other issues raise by the parties in their pleadings awaiting completion of discovery.Â  
The family court held a hearing on the remaining issues in July of 2003 and issued a final order in September 2003.Â  In its order, the family court: (1) approved a settlement agreement between the parties regarding alimony and division of the business property; (2) identified, valued and apportioned the remaining marital property; (3) determined the child support obligations of both parties; and (4) ordered Husband to pay $15,000 toward Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees and $15,000 toward Wifeâ€™s expert fees.Â  Both parties filed motions pursuant to Rules 59 and 60, SCRCP, requesting the family court alter or amend its order.Â  The family court reduced the value of the â€œbootâ€ Husband received as a result of a bank merger by the amount Husband used to pay taxes, changed an award of the â€œFord Farmâ€ to the Husband with credit to Wife, and ordered Husband pay the mortgages on two tracts of property awarded to the Wife.Â  It denied all of the other requests made by the parties in their motions.Â  Wife appealed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On appeal from an order of the family court, the appellate court has jurisdiction to find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Hopkins v. Hopkins, 343 S.C. 301, 304, 540 S.E.2d 454, 456 (2000).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require us to ignore the findings of the family court.Â  Haselden v. Haselden, 347 S.C. 48, 58, 552 S.E.2d 329, 334 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œNeither are we required to ignore the fact that the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.â€Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Equitable Apportionment
Wife argues the family court erred in apportioning 45% of the marital estate to her and 55% to Husband.Â  We disagree. 
Section 20-7-472 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) requires the family court to consider fifteen factors in apportioning marital property, but allows the court to weigh those factors as it deems appropriate.Â  In reviewing the family courtâ€™s equitable apportionment, an appellate courtâ€™s role is to examine the fairness of the apportionment as a whole.Â  Bragg v. Bragg, 347 S.C. 16, 24, 553 S.E.2d 251, 255 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  The family courtâ€™s apportionment will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Id.Â  at 23, 553 S.E.2d at 255.Â  â€œThis court will affirm the family court judge if it can be determined that the judge addressed the factors under section 20-7-472 sufficiently for us to conclude he was cognizant of the statutory factors.â€Â  Jenkins v. Jenkins, 345 S.C. 88, 100, 545 S.E.2d 531, 537 (Ct. App. 2001). 
The family courtâ€™s order indicates it considered all of the appropriate factors, and we find the family court fairly apportioned the marital property as a whole.Â  At the time of the trial, Husband was 43, while Wife was 37.Â  Their marriage lasted for 17 years.Â  Both Husband and Wife have college degrees and are certified nursing home administrators.Â  Both have experienced health problems in the past, but as the family court found, neither have problems that affect their ability to work.Â  We agree with the family courtâ€™s determination that Husband earns approximately $180,000 per year based on his earnings for 1999, 2000, 2001, and 2002.Â  As part of an agreement between the parties, Wife will discontinue her employment at Bradford Gardens, however she will receive $325,000 in lump sum alimony payable by Husband over a period of five years.Â  Although Husband alleged Wife committed adultery, the family court found that the marriage was broken simply because the parties grew apart.Â  
The parties entered into a custody agreement in which their son would live with Husband and their daughter would live with Wife.Â  In light of this arrangement, the family court ordered Husband to pay Wife $200 per month in child support in addition to paying for 70% of daughterâ€™s private school tuition and maintaining health insurance for both children.Â  
The family court required the parties to be responsible for any debt associated with the property they received, other than two tracts Wife received that Husband is to pay the mortgages.Â  
The family court determined Husbandâ€™s earnings were triple Wifeâ€™s over the course of the marriage.Â  This determination is supported by Husbandâ€™s testimony that he contributed 76% of the income during the marriage, as compared to Wifeâ€™s 24% and a schedule introduced by Husband detailing the partiesâ€™ earnings.Â  Wife does not contest this fact, but simply argues she made more indirect contributions in addition to her direct financial contributions.Â  However, Husband contends he and Wife shared the household duties and his mother cared for their son while Wife worked.Â  
In Pool v. Pool, we addressed a comparable situation in which the family court awarded 60% of the marital property to the husband. 321 S.C. 84, 88, 467 S.E.2d 753, 756 (Ct. App. 1996) affâ€™d as modified by 329 S.C. 324, 494 S.E.2d 820 (1998).Â  Similar to this case, the husband made 71% of the direct financial contributions to the marriage and the parties offered contradictory testimony concerning their indirect contributions.Â  In upholding the family courtâ€™s decision, we found, â€œThe court assessed the credibility of the parties in weighing their testimony concerning their indirect contributions to the marriage and concluded the parties contributed equally in terms of indirect contributions.â€Â  Id. at 87-89, 467 S.E.2d at 755-56.Â  Considering the contributions and the other factors, we concluded the overall apportionment was fair.Â  Id.Â  at 89, 467 S.E.2d at 756.
In the instant case, similar to Pool, we find the family court assessed the credibility of the parties concerning the contributions to the marriage.Â  In addition, the court thoroughly addressed the other applicable factors.Â  Thus, we find the family court did not abuse its discretion in apportioning 55% of the marital property to Husband and 45% to Wife.
II.Â  Life Insurance 
 Wife argues the family court erred in awarding her only $109,080.45 from the proceeds of the life insurance policy on Husbandâ€™s father.Â  We disagree.Â  
During the marriage, Husbandâ€™s father, Carlyle Cook took out several policies on his life.Â  One policy, which had a face value of $450,000, named Husband as the owner of the policy and primary beneficiary.Â  Husband testified at the final hearing that McCoy, which he and his father jointly owned, paid the premiums.Â  In June 2002, just after the coupleâ€™s divorce, but prior to the family courtâ€™s identification of the marital property, Husbandâ€™s father died as a result of an accident.Â  Husband, as primary beneficiary, received $484,802 in proceeds from the policy.Â  In its final order, the family court determined because McCoy paid the premiums on the policy and Husband owned a 50% interest in McCoy, only one-half of the proceeds from the policy were marital property.Â  The Wifeâ€™s 45% share of this amount was $109,080.45.Â  On Wifeâ€™s motion to alter or amend, the family court held that even if the entire death proceeds were included in the marital estate, based on the contributions of the parties in acquiring the funds, the award of $109,080.45 to Wife was appropriate and should not be modified.Â Â  
Section 20-7-472 vests the family court, not this court, with discretion to decide what weight to assign each factor in considering equitable apportionment of the marital estate.Â  When reviewing the family courtâ€™s equitable apportionment, â€œthis Court looks to the fairness of the overall apportionment.Â  If the end result is equitable, it is irrelevant that this Court might have weighed specific factors differently than the trial judge.â€Â  Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 300, 372 S.E.2d 107, 113 (Ct. App. 1988) (citation omitted).
Here, as noted above, the family court considered all of the relevant factors in making its initial apportionment of the marital estate.Â  In its order on the Wifeâ€™s motion to alter or amend, the court focused on the contribution of the parties to the acquisition of the life insurance proceeds in apportioning the proceeds as a marital asset.Â  In her brief, the wife made no argument that such an apportionment was inequitable.[1]Â  An appellant has the burden of convincing this court that the family court committed error in its findings.Â  Widman v. Widman, 348 S.C. 97, 117, 557 S.E.2d 693, 703 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Therefore, we hold that as the family court considered all of the relevant factors, we find no abuse of discretion in its award to Wife of $109,080.45 as her share of the life insurance proceeds. 
III. Valuation of Certificate of Deposit and â€œBootâ€ 
Wife argues the family court erred in valuing a certificate of deposit (CD) at Carolina Community Bank and the cash â€œbootâ€ received by Husband after the merger of Carolina Community Bank and First Bank of North Carolina.Â  Wife asserts the family court erred in finding Husband used funds from these accounts to pay the coupleâ€™s 2000 income tax liabilities.Â  She contends Husband offered no evidence other than his own testimony to support his assertion, and thus, the family court erred in reducing the value of these assets to reflect the alleged tax payments.Â  We disagree. 
At trial, Husband and Wife both submitted financial declarations including the CD valued at $31,934 and the boot money of $90,000.Â  However, on Husbandâ€™s declaration, he indicated he used the proceeds from the CD and $33,120 of the proceeds from the boot to pay the coupleâ€™s 2000 income tax liability.Â  In addition, Husband stated during his testimony that he used the proceeds from the CD and a portion of the boot to pay the tax liability.Â  
Although Husband only cites to his own assertions as evidence of payment, Wife does not offer any evidence to the contrary.Â  Thus, given our deference for the family court, which saw and heard the witness at trial, we find no error by the family court in choosing to believe Husbandâ€™s assertions.Â  See Miles v. Miles, 355 S.C. 511, 516, 586 S.E.2d 136, 139 (Ct. App. 2003) (stating the family court, which saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony).Â  
IV. Attorneyâ€™s Fees and Costs 
Wife argues the family court abused its discretion in only awarding her $15,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees and $15,000 in expert witness fees.Â  She maintains because she obtained a favorable result and incurred $58,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees and $61,000 in expert fees, she should have been awarded these amounts.Â  We disagree. 
Section 20-7-420(38) (Supp. 2005) of the South Carolina Code provides that attorneyâ€™s fees may be awarded in an action brought in family court.Â  â€œAn award of attorneyâ€™s fees rests within the sound discretion of the trial judge and should not be disturbed on appeal unless there is an abuse of discretion.â€Â  Patel v. Patel, 359 S.C. 515, 533, 599 S.E.2d 114, 123 (2004).Â  In determining what amount of attorneyâ€™s fees should be awarded, the court should consider the nature, extent, and difficulty of the services rendered; the time necessarily devoted to the case; the professional standing of counsel; the contingency of compensation; the beneficial results obtained; and the customary legal fees for similar services.Â  Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991). 
In its order, the family court noted Wife had already been awarded $25,000 at a prior hearing.Â  It acknowledged Wife received a favorable result in that she received a greater portion of the marital property than originally proposed by Husband and she received a portion of the life insurance proceeds from Husbandâ€™s fatherâ€™s policy.Â  Considering each partyâ€™s financial condition and ability to pay, the family court noted Husband earned on average $190,000 in the two years prior to the commencement of the marital litigation, while Wife is entitled to receive a substantial lump sum alimony award.Â  
In addition, the family court considered the reasonableness of the fees charged.Â  In its order, the family court called attention to several errors made by Wifeâ€™s expert in valuing Husbandâ€™s ownership interest in various nursing home businesses.Â  During cross-examination, Wifeâ€™s expert admitted he omitted a debt owed by A & R and misvalued a mortgage owed by another entity.Â  In addition, Wifeâ€™s expert admitted to using incorrect ownership percentages for another business.Â  The family court also mentioned some of the charges in the bill submitted by Wifeâ€™s attorney were incurred as a result of the contempt proceeding against both Husband and Wife.Â  In the order finding both Husband and Wife in contempt, the family court instructed both parties to pay their own attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Thus, as the family court stated in its order, these fees â€œshould not be considered in the total attorneyâ€™s fees award as they have been previously denied.â€Â  
Based on our review, the family court properly considered the appropriate factors in awarding Wife $15,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees and $15,000 in expert fees.Â  Accordingly, we do not find the family court abused its discretion in making these awards, rather than awarding Wife the entire amount of fees she incurred.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the above reason, the order of the family court is 
AFFIRMED.
HUFF and WILLIAMS, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.Â 

[1] At oral argument, Wife did argue for the first time that the family court should not have apportioned the proceeds separately from the remainder of the marital estate.Â  We find this argument was not properly presented to this court.Â  See South Carolina Depâ€™t of Social Servs. v. Basnight, 346 S.C. 241, 250, 551 S.E.2d 274, 278 (Ct. App. 2001) (stating an appellant may not use oral argument as a vehicle to argue issues not argued in the appellantâ€™s brief.).

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(D)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Eric Simpson, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â J. Derham Cole, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-069
Submitted January 1, 2006 â€“ Filed February 2, 2006Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Jeffrey Falkner Wilkes and Joseph J. Watson, of Greenville, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General David A. Spencer, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â Eric Simpson appeals a conviction of trafficking in crack cocaine, arguing, inter alia, that the trial court erred in admitting testimony that implied Simpson was a high-level drug trafficker.Â  We affirm.[1] 
FACTS
In August 2002, agents from the South Carolina Department of Probation, Parole, and Pardon Services served a probation warrant on Sharon Smith at her documented residence.Â  Several minutes after knocking on the front door, the agents were met by Vernon Mormon, Smithâ€™s live-in boyfriend, who granted the agents permission to enter and told them Smith was in the back bedroom.Â  After a brief struggle, during which Smith attempted to hold the bedroom door closed, the agents apprehended Smith.Â  In her hand was a pipe containing a partially smoked rock of crack cocaine.Â  Behind the bedroom door, agents found three rifles.
After finding the firearms, the agents performed a security search of the residence.Â  The search yielded small baggies of crack cocaine in both the hallway and near the entrance to a bathroom.Â  An agent entered the bathroom and spotted a third baggie of crack cocaine and some money lying in a clothes hamper.Â  In total, over 18 grams of crack cocaine were found in close proximity of the bathroom.Â  After noticing a pair of shoes under the shower curtain, the agent found Eric Simpson hiding in the bathroomâ€™s shower.Â  Both Simpson and Smith were arrested.
Simpson was subsequently indicted by a Spartanburg grand jury for trafficking in crack cocaine and tried by a jury in December 2004.Â  At trial, the State presented Smithâ€™s testimony to establish the crack cocaine found in the residence belonged to Simpson.Â  According to Smith, Simpson, her regular crack cocaine dealer, stopped by that evening to sell Smith some crack cocaine shortly before the agents arrived to execute the warrant.Â  Smith testified that, as a mere user, she would never have that amount of crack cocaine in her possession.Â  She acknowledged, however, that earlier that evening she purchased a small amount of the drug from another neighborhood dealer, which she promptly consumed to â€œtide [her] overâ€ until Simpson arrived. 
Simpson was convicted and sentenced to ten years incarceration.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW / ANALYSIS
1. Rule 404(b), SCRE
Simpson contends the trail court erred in admitting evidence that implied he was a high-level trafficker, arguing such implication is a violation of Rule 402 and Rule 404(b), SCRE.Â  We find this issue is not preserved for appellate review.
At trial, Doug Harwell, a narcotics officer for the Spartanburg Department of Public Safety, testified generally to the amount of drugs typically carried by different levels of drug traffickers.Â  Defense counsel objected on the grounds the officer was not qualified to give expert testimony.Â  This objection was later withdrawn.
â€œAn issue may not be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€Â  State v. Nichols, 325 S.C. 111, 120-121, 481 S.E.2d 118, 123 (1997).Â  â€œWhere an objection and the ground therefor is not stated in the record, there is no basis for appellate review.â€Â  State v. Morris, 307 S.C. 480, 485, 415 S.E.2d 819, 823 (Ct. App. 1991).Â  â€œThe objection should be sufficiently specific to bring into focus the precise nature of the alleged error so that it can be reasonably understood by the trial judge.â€ State v. Holliday, 333 S.C. 332, 338, 509 S.E.2d 280, 283 (Ct. App. 1998) (quoting McKissick v. J.F. Cleckley & Co., 325 S.C. 327, 344, 479 S.E.2d 67, 75 (Ct. App. 1996)).
Not only was the objection to the testimony in question withdrawn, it was based on entirely different grounds as those raised in Simpsonâ€™s appellate brief.Â  Because there was no contemporaneous objection to this testimony on the grounds asserted on appeal, we conclude this issue is not preserved for our review.
2. Hearsay Testimony
Simpson also argues the trial court erred in admitting testimony from Officer Harwell relating to his prior experiences with user-level drug addicts because the testimony was hearsay.Â  Again, we find this issue is not preserved for appellate review.
The subject of Harwellâ€™s experience dealing with drug addicts was first raised by the defense on cross-examination.Â  The issue was addressed again briefly by the State on re-direct, but the defense made no objection on the ground of hearsay.Â  For the reasons discussed in section one, we conclude this issue is likewise not preserved for our review.
The ruling of the trial court is therefore
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL, KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

PER CURIAM:Â  Demario Nesbit appeals his convictions of armed robbery and possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent crime and his guilty plea to voluntary manslaughter.Â  After a thorough review of the record and counselâ€™s brief pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), and State v. Williams, 305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we dismiss[1] Nesbitâ€™s appeal and grant counselâ€™s motion to be relieved.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        John F. Seibert and Lillian D. Seibert, Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        R. Ann Wilkins Brooks; Charles J. Brooks, II, Niles Brancati, Brancati Builders, Inc., Charles E. Strickland, Jr., and Preferred Home Inspections, Inc., Defendants,
      
    
  


  
    
      
        of whom Charles E. Strickland, Jr. and Preferred Home Inspections, Inc., are Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lexington County
Â Marc H. Westbrook, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-071
Heard January 10, 2006 â€“ Filed February 2, 2006Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Charles E. Carpenter, Jr., and Francis M. Mack, of Columbia, for Appellants. 
        John D. Kassel, and William D. Robertson, III, of Columbia, for Respondents. 
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Charles E. Strickland and Preferred Home Inspections, Inc. (collectively Strickland) appeal from the circuit court order denying their motion to compel arbitration.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS
John and Lillian Seibert lived in Wilton, Connecticut, prior to February of 2000.Â  On February 1, 2000, John Seibert moved to South Carolina and took a job with Capital City Insurance.Â  Capital City Insurance is located in Columbia, South Carolina.Â  In November of 1999, the Seibert family came to Columbia to â€œsee if [they] wanted to make this move.â€Â  Seibert decided to take the job, and he and his wife contacted a real estate agent to find a house.Â  John Seibert moved from Connecticut into an apartment in the Columbia area for a short time.Â  The Seiberts bought a home in Lexington County and Lillian joined John shortly thereafter.Â  
In connection with the real estate transaction, and prior to closing, John Seibert contracted with Strickland to perform a home inspection.Â  Stricklandâ€™s company is located in Richland County, South Carolina.Â  The home inspection agreement contained an arbitration provision.Â  
Strickland performed the inspection on April 18, 2000.Â  After completing the inspection, he handed the report to John and Lillian, who were both at the site with him.Â  The report was also faxed and mailed to the residence in Connecticut.Â  Seibert paid for the inspection with a check drawn on a Connecticut bank.Â  
The underlying dispute in this case arose from the Seibertsâ€™ purchase of the home in Lexington County, which was clad with synthetic stucco siding.Â  John and Lillian Seibert filed an action against Strickland and other defendants on May 21, 2001.Â  The centerpiece of the Seibertsâ€™ suit involves a myriad of alleged problems associated with the synthetic stucco exterior.Â  
Strickland and Preferred Home Inspections moved to dismiss the Complaint and to compel arbitration.Â  It is undisputed that the arbitration provision is unenforceable under South Carolina law because the provision was not capitalized or prominently rubber-stamped on the contract, and thus fails to meet the requirements of section 15-48-10(a) of the South Carolina Code (2005).Â  See Blanton v. Stathos, 351 S.C. 534, 538-39, 570 S.E.2d 565, 567 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Arbitration was therefore sought pursuant to the Federal Arbitration Act (FAA), 9 U.S.C. Â§Â§ 1 to 16 (2003), on the basis that the home inspection agreement evidenced a transaction involving interstate commerce.Â  The circuit court denied the motion to compel arbitration, finding insufficient evidence of interstate commerce to invoke the federal act.Â  This appeal follows. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œThe question of the arbitrability of a claim is an issue for judicial determination, unless the parties provide otherwise.â€Â  Stokes v. Metro. Life Ins. Co., 351 S.C. 606, 609, 571 S.E.2d 711, 713 (Ct. App. 2002) (quoting Zabinski v. Bright Acres Assocs., 346 S.C. 580, 596, 553 S.E.2d 110, 118 (2001)).Â  â€œDeterminations of arbitrability are subject to de novo review.â€Â  Id.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Strickland contends the circuit court erred in finding the arbitration provision unenforceable because the transaction did not involve interstate commerce, and therefore did not trigger the FAA.Â  We disagree.Â  
It is undisputed that the arbitration provision in this case is unenforceable under South Carolina law.Â  Nevertheless, because of the policy favoring arbitration, an arbitration provision may be enforceable under the FAA.Â  Soil Remediation Co. v. Nu-Way Envtl., Inc., 323 S.C. 454, 458, 476 S.E.2d 149, 151 (1996).Â  â€œFor the Federal Act to apply, the commerce involved in the contract must be interstate or foreign.â€Â  Id. at 460, 476 S.E.2d at 152.Â  The scope of the FAA is coextensive with the broadest permissible exercise of the federal Commerce Clause power.Â  Towles v. United Healthcare Corp., 338 S.C. 29, 36, 524 S.E.2d 839, 843 (Ct. App. 1999); see also 9 U.S.C. Â§ 2, U.S. Const. art. I, Â§ 8, cl. 3.Â  â€œIn all cases, determination of whether a transaction involves interstate commerce depends on the facts of the case.â€Â  Thornton v. Trident Med. Ctr., L.L.C., 357 S.C. 91, 95-96, 592 S.E.2d 50, 52 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  
â€œTo ascertain whether a transaction involves commerce within the meaning of the FAA, the court must examine the agreement, the complaint, and the surrounding facts.â€Â  Towles, 338 S.C. at 36, 524 S.E.2d at 843.Â  This determination is made irrespective of whether the parties contemplated an interstate transaction.Â  Munoz v. Green Tree Fin. Corp., 343 S.C. 531, 538-39, 542 S.E.2d 360, 363 (2001).Â  The court should focus on what the terms of the contract specifically require for its performance, looking to the essential character of the contract.Â  Thornton, 357 S.C. at 96, 592 S.E.2d at 52.Â Â  
Strickland first argues the transaction involves interstate commerce because the parties are domiciled in different states.Â  We begin by noting that the Seiberts alleged they were residents of Lexington County in their complaint.Â  Residence is a question of fact and is generally determined by a partyâ€™s intent.Â  Ferguson v. Employers Mut. Cas. Co., 254 S.C. 235, 238, 174 S.E.2d 768, 769 (1970).Â  â€œThe act and intent as to domicile, not the duration of the residence, are the determining factors.â€Â  Id. at 238-39, 149 S.E.2d at 769.Â  
Because only John Seibert signed the inspection contract, we need not consider Lillianâ€™s domicile.Â  At the time John Seibert signed the contract, he had accepted a job in South Carolina and had been living in an apartment in South Carolina for two months.Â  The inspection contract related to the purchase of a home, indicating that John Seibert intended his residence to be in South Carolina.Â  
Moreover, the mere fact that the parties to a contract are from different states is not alone sufficient to trigger the FAA.Â  See, e.g., Timms v. Greene, 310 S.C. 469, 473, 427 S.E.2d 642, 644 (1993) (holding that although one of the parties was domiciled in Delaware, the contract itself did not involve interstate commerce).Â  Contracts involving the sale of real estate have been held not to trigger the FAA when, despite the fact that the contracting parties were domiciled outside this state, there was no nexus between the contract and interstate commerce.Â  Soil Remediation Co., 323 S.C. at 460, 476 S.E.2d at 152 (citing Matthews v. Fluor Corp., 312 S.C. 404, 440 S.E.2d 880 (1994).Â  Accordingly, something more than the domicile of the parties is required to â€œinvolve interstate commerce.â€[1]Â  
Strickland next attempts to rely on the fact that the Seibertsâ€™ check to pay for the inspection was drawn on an out-of-state bank, and that a copy of the report was sent to the Seibertsâ€™ Connecticut residence.Â  We find these facts insufficient to establish a nexus between the contract and interstate commerce.Â  The focus of the determination is on what the terms of the contract specifically require for performance, looking to its essential character.Â  Thornton, 357 S.C. at 96, 592 S.E.2d at 52.Â  Performance of the contract must require activity involving interstate commerce.Â  Id. at 97, 592 S.E.2d at 53.Â  Factors involving interstate commerce that are only incidental to the nature of the contract need not be considered.[2]Â  Id. at 96, 592 S.E.2d at 52.Â  
Here, performance of the contract did not require any activity outside of this state.Â  The location of the bank on which the check was drawn is merely incidental to the nature of the contract.Â  Moreover, the mere fact that copies of the report were sent to Connecticut is of no account because the original report was delivered to the Seiberts in South Carolina.Â  We therefore find no error in the circuit courtâ€™s determination that the transaction was essentially a local one lacking a sufficient nexus to interstate commerce to trigger the FAA.Â  The denial of the motion to compel arbitration isÂ Â  
AFFIRMED. 
STILWELL, KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur. Â 

[1] The cases Strickland cites for the proposition that citizenship in different states is sufficient all involve contracts that required some form of interstate transfer to be performed.Â  See, e.g., Prima Paint Corp. v. Flood & Conklin Mfg. Co., 388 U.S. 395, 401, (1967) (contract related to acquisition of a multi-state paint business); Ideal Unlimited Servs. Corp. v. Swift-Eckrich, Inc., 727 F.Supp. 75, 77 (D.P.R. 1989) (contract involved shipment of goods across state lines).Â  Although some federal cases seem to suggest that mere diversity of citizenship is sufficient, that rule has not been adopted in the Fourth Circuit.Â  
[2] Munoz, which arguably could be read to hold that mere domicile in different states is sufficient, does not require this construction because the contract in Munoz was an installment contract and security agreement secured by a home mortgage to finance a home improvement project.Â  Thus, performance of the project required interstate transfer of both payments and building materials.Â  Munoz, 343 S.C. at 536, 542 S.E.2d at 362.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Lakefhia McCrea, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Jafer Gheraibeh, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
James E. Brogdon, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-072
Heard January 10, 2006 â€“ Filed February 2, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Edward L. Graham, of Florence, for Appellant.Â  
        Charles A. Harris, Jr., of Cheraw, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Lakefhia McCrea brought suit against Jafer Gheraibeh for injuries and property damages suffered in an automobile collision.Â  After receiving a verdict in her favor, McCrea appeals seeking a new trial.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS
McCrea and Gheraibeh were involved in an automobile collision in which Gheraibeh ran a red light and struck McCreaâ€™s vehicle on the driverâ€™s side door.Â  McCrea was taken to the emergency room to be examined, but she was released.Â  She had no cuts or bruises, and the x-rays performed were normal.Â  
McCrea later saw her personal physician.Â  Her physician ordered additional x-rays as well as an MRI.Â  These tests were normal.Â  McCrea attended physical therapy for pain to her back and left side.Â  The therapy was provided by Macleod Physical Therapy, which is also where McCrea worked at the time of the accident.Â  
McCrea brought suit against Gheraibeh seeking compensation for her alleged injuries and damage to her vehicle.Â  At trial, Gheraibeh admitted liability for the accident, but challenged McCreaâ€™s testimony regarding the amount of damages.Â  McCrea did not offer the testimony of any of the treating doctors.Â  She entered a summary of her medical bills showing a total of $9,393.67.Â  
As for the property damage, McCrea testified she purchased the car using financing and admitted the cash price was $1,000 less than she paid.Â  She asserted the value of the car was $7,145.83, which constituted the balance remaining on her loan.Â  Gheraibeh argued the car would depreciate faster than the loan balance and that the excessive mileage she put on the car commuting at least 60 miles a day would decrease the carâ€™s value.Â  
The jury returned a verdict in McCreaâ€™s favor.Â  The jury awarded her $5,985 in personal injury damages and $5,000 in property damages.Â  McCrea made post-trial motions for judgment notwithstanding the verdict (JNOV), new trial absolute, and new trial nisi additur.Â  The court denied the motions and entered judgment on McCreaâ€™s behalf for $6,887.25, after reducing the verdict amount by an offset of $4,097.75 previously paid.Â  McCrea appeals numerous issues involving jury voir dire and selection, the admission of evidence, the failure to give a jury instruction regarding the collateral source rule, and the denial of motions for JNOV and for a new trial.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Voir Dire
McCrea contends the trial court erred in refusing further voir dire of potential jurors regarding any bias stemming from â€œmass media campaignsâ€ favoring tort reform.Â  She contends the court should have asked prospective jurors their opinions regarding tort reform, their involvement in political causes or campaigns, or their belief regarding the appropriateness of bringing a lawsuit for damages in an automobile wreck.Â  We disagree.
The manner and scope of voir dire is largely within the discretion of the trial judge.Â  Crosby v. Southeast Zayre, Inc., 274 S.C. 519, 521, 265 S.E.2d 517, 519 (1980); State v. Middleton, 266 S.C. 251, 256-57, 222 S.E.2d 763, 765 (1976), vacated by 429 U.S. 807 (1976); Norris v. Ferre, 315 S.C. 179, 181, 432 S.E.2d 491, 492 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  On appeal, this court will rely on the judgment of the trial judge who is able to observe the character and demeanor of the jurors, unless the record firmly establishes an abuse of discretion.Â  See Wilson v. Childs, 315 S.C. 431, 437-38, 434 S.E.2d 286, 290 (Ct. App. 1993).
The trial court properly asked questions to determine whether any juror held an underlying bias against any of the parties or their claims.Â  The court determined the jurors could act fairly.Â  The purpose of voir dire is not to probe every possible aspect of the juror, but to seek a fair and impartial jury.Â  Based on the questions asked by the court, we find no abuse of discretion in refusing to ask McCreaâ€™s remaining questions.
II.Â Â Â Â  Batson
McCrea asserts the trial court erred in failing to grant her Batson[1] motion because strikes used by Gheraibehâ€™s attorney were impermissible and racially motivated.Â  She maintains the â€œrace-neutralâ€ explanation given by Gheraibehâ€™s counsel was mere pretext.Â  We disagree.
During the seating of the jury, Gheraibehâ€™s attorney struck three out of six African-American jurors including Mr. Green, an African-American male with dreadlocks.Â  After the use of peremptory strikes was completed, McCreaâ€™s counsel challenged the use of Gheraibehâ€™s strikes as racially discriminatory.Â  In response, the court properly held a Batson hearing to determine the reason for the strikes.Â  Gheraibehâ€™s attorney explained that Mr. Greenâ€™s â€œappearance including - - including the dreadlocksâ€ gave him some pause.Â  
In Purkett v. Elem, 514 U.S. 765 (1995), the United States Supreme Court held that â€œthe prosecutorâ€™s proffered explanation in this case--that he struck juror number 22 because he had long, unkempt hair, a mustache, and a beard--is race neutral and satisfies the prosecutionâ€™s step two burden of articulating a nondiscriminatory reason for the strike.â€Â  Id. at 769.Â  The court explained that long unkempt hair is not characteristic to any particular race.Â  Id.
In light of Purkett, we believe counselâ€™s concern regarding Mr. Greenâ€™s appearance and his dreadlocks is a racially neutral explanation for the strike.Â  The main justification was his appearance and the â€œvery long dreadlocksâ€ which supplied counselâ€™s uneasiness towards Mr. Green.Â  Just as long hair is generally â€œout of the norm,â€ so are very long dreadlocks.Â  The decision to wear an alternative hairstyle is not specific to any race, and therefore, no discriminatory intent is inherent in the explanation.Â  
III.Â Â Â  Impeachment Using Collision Report
McCrea next asserts the trial court improperly denied her motion for a mistrial after Gheraibehâ€™s attorney referenced an accident report regarding a wreck occurring subsequent to the collision in this case.Â  We disagree.
Gheraibehâ€™s attorney stated: â€œThe officer who investigated that accident showed . . . estimated damage . . . of $7,000.â€Â  McCrea objected, and the court sustained McCreaâ€™s objection to the introduction of the testimony.Â  The court further issued a curative instruction for the jury not to consider that information.
â€œAn instruction to disregard incompetent evidence usually is deemed to have cured the error in its admission unless on the facts of the particular case it is probable that notwithstanding such instruction or withdrawal the accused was prejudiced.â€Â  State v. Simpson, 325 S.C. 37, 43, 479 S.E.2d 57, 60 (1996) (citing State v. Craig, 267 S.C. 262, 227 S.E.2d 306 (1976)).Â  We find the curative instruction was more than sufficient to cure any harm caused by the statement by Gheraibehâ€™s attorney.Â  Additionally, there was other evidence entered into the record without objection regarding the subsequent accident.Â  Consequently, McCrea cannot show prejudice resulting from the failure of the court to declare a mistrial. 
IV.Â Â Â  Collateral Source Rule
McCrea next contends the trial court erred by not giving a jury instruction regarding the collateral source rule once testimony was elicited regarding McCreaâ€™s lack of insurance benefits. [2]Â  We disagree.
The testimony McCrea contends required a jury instruction on the collateral source rule barely intimated that she had previously had health insurance.Â  Additionally, there is no evidence in the record of the amount, if any, paid by insurance on McCreaâ€™s behalf.Â  While the collateral source rule is sometimes warranted, the trial judge is allowed discretion in determining an appropriate charge based on the evidence presented in the trial.Â  See Smith  v. Ridgeway Chems., Inc., 302 S.C. 303, 307, 395 S.E.2d 742, 744 (Ct. App. 1990).
V.Â Â Â Â Â  JNOV and New Trial
McCrea maintains the trial court should have granted her motion for JNOV on the grounds that the only evidence in the record supports an award of the full amount of damages she requested.Â  She further contends that the trial court should have granted her a new trial because her award was grossly inadequate in light of the evidence.Â  We disagree.
â€œIn ruling on directed verdict or JNOV motions, the trial court is required to view the evidence and the inferences that reasonably can be drawn therefrom in the light most favorable to the party opposing the motions.â€Â  Sabb v. South Carolina State Univ., 350 S.C. 416, 427, 567 S.E.2d 231, 236 (2002).Â  In the instant case, McCrea presented her testimony and a summary of the doctorâ€™s bills into evidence in support of her claim for personal injury damages.Â  Additionally, she testified regarding the amount she paid for her car, the amount remaining on the loan, and her opinion regarding the carâ€™s value.
However, Gheraibeh extensively cross-examined McCrea regarding the necessity of some of the medical expenses.Â  He had McCrea admit that all the tests performed by various doctors, including x-rays and an MRI, returned normal.Â  McCrea admitted she was in previous automobile accidents in which she suffered soft-tissue injuries and was in a subsequent vehicle collision.Â  While he did not present a definite dollar amount for her damages, Gheraibehâ€™s attorney argued an appropriate amount would be the cost of her emergency room visit and of her doctors, but not the physical therapy.Â  
In addition, Gheraibeh challenged McCreaâ€™s valuation of her vehicle.Â  She admitted she paid $1,000 more than the cash price in order to receive financing.Â  She also stated that she has traveled about 60 miles roundtrip each day to work for several years.Â  When asked about the mileage on the vehicle, she was unable to give a figure, but admitted it could be close to 100,000 miles.Â  Finally, Gheraibeh argued the vehicle may have depreciated faster than the balance on McCreaâ€™s financing was being paid, causing the car to be worth less than was owed.Â  Based upon the evidence in the record and Gheraibehâ€™s extensive cross-examination of McCrea, we find the trial court properly denied McCreaâ€™s motion for JNOV.
Furthermore, the award given McCrea was not so shockingly disproportionate to the injuries suffered that it indicated â€œpassion, caprice, prejudice, partiality, corruptionâ€ or other considerations not reflected by the evidence.Â  Vinson v. Hartley, 324 S.C. 389, 404, 477 S.E.2d 715, 723 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  McCrea contends her evidence showed she sustained $9,393.67 in medical expenses, lost $2,898.55 as a result of being off work, and suffered pain and suffering as a result of the collision.Â  The juryâ€™s award of $5,985 is hardly â€œde minimusâ€ as claimed by McCrea.Â  It is clearly not the result of passion, caprice or prejudice. 
As to her vehicle damage, McCrea presented the figure of $7,145.83 as the debt remaining after financing and as her opinion regarding the value of the vehicle.Â  The jury awarded $5,000 in damage and this figure could easily represent the juryâ€™s opinion that the vehicle was depreciating faster than McCrea was reducing the amount owed.Â  Accordingly, we refuse to hold the juryâ€™s award was grossly inadequate.
CONCLUSION
Based on all of the foregoing, the decision of the trial court is
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL, KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Â Batson v. Kentucky, 476 U.S. 79 (1986).Â  
[2] Under the collateral source rule, compensation received by an injured party from a source wholly independent of the wrongdoer will not reduce damages owed by the wrongdoer.Â  Covington v. George, 359 S.C. 100, 103, 597 S.E.2d 142, 144 (2004).Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Peter G. Oliver, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        AT&T Nassau Metals, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Paul M. Burch, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-073
Submitted January 1, 2006 â€“ Filed February 2, 2006

DISMISSED


  
    
      
        Grady L. Beard and Michael W. Burkett, both of Columbia, for Appellant.Â  
        Preston F. McDaniel, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  AT&T Nassau Metals appeals an order of the circuit court that dismissed AT&Tâ€™s motion to dismiss.Â  We dismiss AT&Tâ€™s appeal.[1]
FACTS
Peter G. Oliver filed an action seeking workerâ€™s compensation benefits.Â  The single commissioner found Oliver totally and permanently disabled.Â  AT&T appealed to the full commission.Â  The commission reversed the single commissionerâ€™s order and remanded for a de novo hearing.Â  Oliver appealed to the circuit court.Â  AT&T moved to dismiss Oliverâ€™s appeal as interlocutory and not immediately appealable.Â  The circuit court denied AT&Tâ€™s motion to dismiss.Â  AT&T appeals.
LAW/ANALYSIS
AT&T argues the circuit court erred in denying its motion to dismiss Oliverâ€™s appeal.Â  We dismiss AT&Tâ€™s appeal.
Section 14-3-330 of the South Carolina Code limits this courtâ€™s ability to hear appeals.Â  Only final judgments and certain interlocutory orders are appealable.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-3-330 (1976 & Supp. 2005).Â  An interlocutory order is not immediately appealable unless it involves the merits of the case or affects a substantial right.Â  Id.Â  The denial of a motion to dismiss is not immediately appealable.Â  McLendon v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Highways & Pub. Transp., 313 S.C. 525, 526, 443 S.E.2d 539, 540 (1994).Â  
The order on appeal in this case involves the denial of a motion to dismiss and does not involve the merits or affect a substantial right.Â  Accordingly, the appeal is
DISMISSED.Â  
STILWELL, KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Kay Biser, individually and as duly appointed Personal Representative of the Estate of Christopher Biser, M.D., Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Medical University of South Carolina, University Medical Associates, John M. Kratz, M.D., and Andrea J. Shaer, M.D., Defendants,
        Of Whom Medical University of South Carolina, University Medical Associates, John M. Kratz, M.D. are the Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-592
Heard September 14, 2005 â€“ Filed November 21, 2005
Withdrawn, Substituted and Refiled February 8, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        J. Edward Bell, III and Kevin R. Dean, both of Sumter and Eugene C. Fulton, Jr., of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Robert H. Hood, Robert H. Hood, Jr., Roy P. Maybank, and Deborah H. Sheffield, all of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Kay Biser appeals a trial court order refusing to add parties previously dismissed from the suit.Â  Because we find the dismissed parties are protected by Section 15-78-70 of the South Carolina Tort Claims Act, we affirm.
FACTS
This case is founded on allegations of medical negligence arising from a procedure performed at the Medical University of South Carolina (hereinafter â€œMUSCâ€) by Dr. John Kratz on Dr. Christopher Biser.Â Â Â  Because the facts surrounding the medical procedure are immaterial to our current determination, we do not recount them here, except to say that Biser did not survive.Â  His wife, in her individual capacity and as the personal representative of her husbandâ€™s estate, brought a medical negligence suit against MUSC, University Medical Associates (hereinafter â€œUMAâ€), John Kratz, M.D., and Andrea Shaer, M.D.Â Â  
Prior to trial, the defendants moved for summary judgment.Â  At the same time, Biser brought a motion to compel against the defendants for failure to comply with discovery requests.Â  The trial court took the unusual step of dismissing all of the defendants without prejudice except for MUSC, while also requiring the original defendants to comply with the discovery requests.Â  The trial court further ordered, that â€œif during the course of discovery, Plaintiffs are able to discover evidence which supports their position in the Complaint, they may upon motion, move to amend to add the parties, Defendants Dr. Kratz, Dr. Shaer, and UMA.â€Â  
The dismissal was rooted in the trial courtâ€™s understanding of Section 15-78-70 of the South Carolina Code (2005) and the holding in Proveaux v. Medical University of South Carolina, 326 S.C. 28, 482 S.E.2d 774 (1997).Â  Proveaux held that a physician employed by MUSC is immune from suit under the provisions of section 15-78-70, notwithstanding MUSC and the physicianâ€™s relationship with UMA.Â  Id. at 30-32, 482 S.E.2d at 775-76.Â  
Biser did not appeal the dismissal of UMA, Dr. Kratz, and Dr. Shaer, but did move to add Dr. Kratz and UMA after discovering evidence detailing the close relationship between MUSC and UMA and new evidence suggesting Dr. Kratz was not an employee of MUSC but UMA.Â  Essentially, Biser argued UMA and MUSC are separate organizations so the tort claims cap would not apply to UMA.Â  Kratz argued in reply that he was employed by MUSC, not UMA and supported his position by arguing that UMA fits within subsection 70(c) as a â€œpractice plan.â€Â  The court denied the motion to amend and concluded Proveaux applied because UMA does not perform any activity that would make it liable for Dr. Kratzâ€™s actions.Â Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Although this appeal is brought to us as a motion to amend, we review it as a grant of summary judgment to Dr. Kratz and UMA.Â  This is the proper standard of review because these parties were originally named but dismissed without prejudice.Â  In addition, the dismissing order specifically contemplated they could be returned to the suit if facts were uncovered in discovery to justify them as parties.Â  As a general rule, amendment is strongly favored and should be applied liberally when it does not cause prejudice.Â  Crestwood Golf Club, Inc. v. Potter, 328 S.C. 201, 218, 493 S.E.2d 826, 835-36 (1997).Â  The prejudice Rule 15 envisions is a lack of notice that the new issue is going to be tried and a lack of opportunity to refute it.Â  Tanner v. Florence County Treasurer, 336 S.C. 552, 559, 521 S.E.2d 153, 156 (1999).Â  The party opposing the amendment has the burden of establishing prejudice.Â  Foggie v. CSX Transp., Inc., 315 S.C. 17, 22, 431 S.E.2d 587, 590 (1993).
While a motion to amend should be liberally granted, the court also ruled Kratz and UMA were immune from suit and not proper parties under Proveaux.Â  This served as the real reason to deny the amendment; therefore, we must examine whether the court correctly ruled as a matter of law that they were not proper parties to the litigation.Â  
In reviewing an order for summary judgment, the appellate court applies the same standard which governs the trial court under Rule 56 of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure: summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  South Carolina Elec. & Gas Co. v. Town of Awendaw, 359 S.C. 29, 34, 596 S.E.2d 482, 485 (2004).Â  When determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, evidence and all reasonable inferences therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Id.
LAW AND DISCUSSION
1.   Dr. Kratz
Biser argues the court erred when it refused to add Dr. Kratz as a defendant.Â  We disagree.
Section 15-78-70 of the South Carolina Code (2005) states: 

  (a)Â  This chapter constitutes the exclusive remedy for any tort committed by an employee of a governmental entity.Â  An employee of a governmental entity who commits a tort while acting within the scope of his official duty is not liable therefor except as expressly provided for in subsection (b).
   (b) Nothing in this chapter may be construed to give an employee of a governmental entity immunity from suit and liability if it is proved that the employeeâ€™s conduct was not within the scope of his official duties or that it constituted actual fraud, actual malice, intent to harm, or a crime involving moral turpitude.

(Emphasis added).
Biser does not contend Dr. Kratz committed fraudulent, malicious, or intentional actions, or any crime involving moral turpitude.Â  Instead, Biser argues the statute should not apply to Dr. Kratz because it appears he was an employee of UMA, which was a private entity providing medical care and treatment.Â Â Â  
Initially, it is necessary to understand that UMA is the MUSC-authorized faculty practice plan.Â  Faculty members at MUSC do not solely teach students, they also deliver medical care in the course of their teaching.Â  This means that extensive amounts of money are generated by faculty members for the treatment they provide in the course of their employment at MUSC.Â  MUSC has authorized UMA as the faculty practice plan, and in that capacity, UMA performs billing and collection functions for the faculty physicians.Â  Faculty members are paid through MUSC and also receive separate pay checks from UMA for services rendered in their professional capacity to patients.Â  
Subsection (c) of section 15-78-70 addresses the existence of physician immunity when part of their income is received from a practice plan.Â  It states, in pertinent part, the following: 

  The provisions of this section in no way shall limit or modify the liability of a licensed physician or dentist, acting within the scope of his profession, with respect to any action or claim brought hereunder which involved services for which the physician or dentist was paid, should have been paid, or expected to be paid at the time of the rendering of the services from any source other than the salary appropriated by the governmental entity or fees received from any practice plan authorized by the employer whether or not the practice plan is incorporated and registered with the Secretary of State.Â  

(Emphasis added).Â  This section clearly establishes that physician immunity exists even when the physician receives money from a practice plan.
Proveaux v. Medical University of South Carolina, 326 S.C. 28, 482 S.E.2d 774 (1997), addressed this provision and clearly established that a faculty member at MUSC retains the immunity provided by section 17-78-70 when they receive part of their compensation through UMA.Â  In Proveaux, the physician received his annual income from two sources: MUSC and UMA.Â  Id. at 31, 482 S.E.2d at 775-76.Â  The supreme court found that because MUSC had to approve the maximum compensation of all physicians, the defendant-physician qualified for immunity under section 15-78-70(c).Â  Id. at 32, 482 S.E.2d at 776.Â  
Proveaux is directly on point and requires this court to find that Dr. Kratz qualifies for immunity under section 15-78-70.Â  Therefore, the trial court did not err in either dismissing him from the case or refusing to amend the complaint to include him as a defendant.
2.   UMA
Biser argues the court erred when it denied the motion to add UMA as a defendant.Â  We disagree.
Proveaux does not directly address the potential liability of UMA; however, after reviewing the legislative intent behind section 15-78-70 and UMAâ€™s ability to control and direct the actions of Dr. Kratz, we find UMA cannot be found liable for Dr. Kratzâ€™s actions. 
A partial purpose of section 15-78-70 is to shield government physicians from personal liability arising from the medical care they deliver as government physicians.Â  Although Dr. Kratz is clearly covered, Biser seeks to escape the liability limits created by the Tort Claims Act by holding UMA liable for Kratzâ€™s actions.Â  However, UMA was created to bill and collect revenue generated by faculty physicians in the course of their work.Â  See Baird v. Charleston Cnty, 333 S.C. 519, 536, 511 S.E.2d 69, 78 (1999) (â€œUMA is described as a non-profit corporation formed as a billing and collection agent for the clinical practice of medicine at MUSC.Â  UMA is an operation of MUSCâ€™s Clinical Practice Plan.â€) (citations omitted).Â  Section 15-78-20(g) of the South Carolina Code (2005) recognizes that â€œgovernmental entities, in order to attract qualified physicians . . . , must be able to offer an affordable compensation and employment package, including liability insurance.â€Â  
The impact of allowing suits to proceed against UMA, which is not protected by the state Tort Claims Act, would be to eviscerate the careful balance between liability and immunity created by the Act.Â  A successful plaintiff could pursue an unlimited recovery against UMA.Â  This unlimited recovery would negatively impact the compensation paid through UMA for the services the faculty physicians perform as employees of MUSC.Â  The result would be that the objectives of 15-78-20(g) and 15-78-70(c) would be either diminished or obliterated.Â  
Additionally, although Biser argues UMA is the â€œrealâ€ employer of Dr. Kratz, an examination of his relationship with UMA demonstrates that it does not exercise the level of control we normally associate with an employee-employer relationship.Â  Control is the general test used to determine if a worker is an employee.Â  Nelson v. Yellow Cab Co., 349 S.C. 589, 594, 564 S.E.2d 110, 112-13 (2002).Â  
Although we recognize Nelson sought to distinguish between an independent contractor and employee, we find the factors it enumerated to be useful in judging the relationship between UMA and Dr. Kratz, and the appropriateness of holding UMA liable for his actions.Â  Because we must focus on control, there are factors we must consider: 1) direct evidence of the right or exercise of control, 2) furnishing of equipment, 3) right to fire, and 4) method of payment.Â  Id. at 594, 564 S.E.2d at 113.Â  Dr. Kratz has an employment contract with MUSC and not UMA.Â  He was hired by MUSC and is subject to being fired solely by MUSC.Â  MUSC is the only entity with the ability to control and direct Dr. Kratzâ€™s activities.Â  Therefore, MUSC is his employer and, as such, should be the party subject to liability for his actions.Â  
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, J., STILWELL and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        R.J. Casale, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Stivers Chrysler-Jeep, Inc., Stivers Automotive of Lexington, Inc., John Stivers, and Tommy M. Storey, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â Reginald I. Lloyd, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-074
Submitted February 1, 2006 â€“ Filed February 9, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Joseph Gregory Studemeyer, of Columbia; for Appellants.
        Robert T. Strickland, of Columbia; for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Stivers Chrysler-Jeep, Inc., Stivers Automotive of Lexington, Inc., John Stivers, and Tommy M. Storey (collectively â€œStiversâ€) appeal from an order of the circuit court denying their motion to compel arbitration for the time being and allowing the parties to conduct discovery on issues related solely to the agreement to arbitrate.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
R.J. Casale, who resides in California, purchased a 1994 Jaguar XJS from Stivers, a car dealership in South Carolina.Â  Because Casale lived so far away from the dealership, the transaction occurred via facsimile.Â  After the purchase, Casale filed an action against Stivers asserting nine causes of action, all of which essentially arise from Casaleâ€™s claim that Stivers had misrepresented the condition of the car.Â  
Stivers moved to stay the action and to compel arbitration.Â  Attached to the motion to compel were an affidavit from Tommy Storey, who is the salesman who completed the sale, and a copy of the Motor Vehicle Purchase Agreement, the second page of which contained an arbitration agreement.[1]Â  Storey stated that he faxed the purchase agreement to Casale and received the agreement back via fax with Casaleâ€™s signature on it.Â  In response to Stiversâ€™ motion to compel, Casale submitted an affidavit in which he claims to have only received the first page of the agreement.
The circuit court issued a Form 4 Order with the following ruling: â€œMotion to compel arbitration is denied at this point in time with parties free to conduct discovery on issues related solely to agreement of acceptance to arbitrate.â€Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Stivers argues the circuit court erred in denying its motion to stay and to compel arbitration because the arbitration agreement is binding against Casale.Â  We disagree.
Initially, Casale argues this issue is not immediately appealable.Â  However, section 15-48-200 of the South Carolina Code permits the immediate appeal from an order denying an application to compel arbitration.Â  Furthermore, in Towles v. United Healthcare Corp., 338 S.C. 29, 35, 524 S.E.2d 839, 842-43 (Ct. App. 1999), our court considered the appealability of a circuit court order which stated: â€œ[D]efendantsâ€™ motion to compel arbitration is denied, at this time, with leave to refile it at the completion of discovery in this action.â€Â  Our court concluded such an order was immediately appealable.Â  Likewise, we find the order in this case, which denies Stiversâ€™ motion until further discovery can be conducted, is subject to immediate review.
However, even though this order is immediately appealable, we find that Stiversâ€™ particular argument â€“ that the arbitration agreement is binding against Casale â€“ is not preserved for our review.Â  In the Form 4 order denying Stiversâ€™ motion to compel, the circuit court did not make a ruling on whether Casale would be bound to arbitrate his causes of action against Stivers.Â  Rather, the court permitted the parties to conduct further discovery on the limited issue of whether Casale accepted the arbitration agreement.Â  After receiving this order, Stivers did not make a Rule 59(e) motion requesting the circuit court make a ruling on whether the arbitration agreement was binding on Casale.Â  Thus, this issue is not preserved for review.Â  Summersell v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Pub. Safety, 337 S.C. 19, 22, 522 S.E.2d 144, 145-46 (1999) (â€œ[W]here an issue presented to the circuit court in a civil case is not explicitly ruled upon in the final order, the issue must be raised by an appropriate post-trial motion to be preserved for appellate review.â€). 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., ANDERSON and KITTREDGE, JJ. concur.

[1] The actual agreement is only one page with two sides.Â  However, if both sides were faxed, the document would have been two pages long.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        City of Beaufort, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Quais L. Shuler, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â J. Cordell Maddox, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-075
Submitted February 1, 2006 - Filed February 9, 2006Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Eric J. Erickson, of Beaufort, for Appellant.
        William B. Harvey, III, of Beaufort, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Quais Shuler appeals his conviction for driving under the influence, arguing the trial court erred in (1) denying him the opportunity to have a character witness testify in his defense and (2) refusing to charge the jury on good character and reputation.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Officers pulled Shuler at 2 a.m. after observing him speeding, swerving, and running through a red light.Â Â  Shuler admitted to the officers that he had consumed five drinks, but refused to take a blood alcohol test when it was offered.Â  The officers testified they gave Shuler three field sobriety tests and that he failed two of them.Â  Shuler was charged with driving under the influence.
At trial, Shuler testified he drank five beers during the day, and then went to a nightclub from 11 p.m. to 2 a.m.Â  Shuler denied drinking any alcohol while at the nightclub.Â  Shuler admitted to speeding and swerving, but denied running a red light.Â  
Shuler attempted to call a witness who would testify regarding Shulerâ€™s good character and reputation for veracity.Â  The trial court declined to allow such testimony because the character witness would not be testifying that Shulerâ€™s character was inconsistent with driving under the influence.Â  Shuler made no attempt to proffer the character witnessâ€™s testimony.Â  
While discussing jury instructions, Shuler submitted a request to charge the jury as follows:

  An accused, when charged with a crime, has the right of proving his general good character.Â  He may introduce evidence of his good character which is inconsistent with the crime charged against him.
  Evidence of the general good character of the accused is for the purpose of showing the improbability that the defendant would have committed the crime charged.Â  The good character of the accused is like all other evidence in the case and is entitled to such effect and weight as you, the jury, may determine.
  Good character evidence alone may create a reasonable doubt as to the commission of the crime charged.Â  Thus, under some circumstances, a person might be entitled to a verdict of not guilty when his good reputation is taken into consideration even though a verdict of guilty might be authorized without the evidence of good character.

The trial court refused this request to charge because, again, the character witness was purportedly going to testify about Shulerâ€™s propensity for truthfulness rather than a character trait of Shuler that was inconsistent with driving under the influence.Â  
The jury found Shuler guilty of driving under the influence.Â  This appeal followed. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A trial courtâ€™s ruling on the admissibility of evidence will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion or the commission of legal error that results in prejudice to the defendant.Â  State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 377, 580 S.E.2d 785, 793 (Ct. App. 2003).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Shuler argues the trial court erred in refusing to allow his character witness to testify.Â  We find this argument is not preserved for appeal because Shuler failed to proffer his witnessâ€™s testimony.Â  State v. Simmons, 360 S.C. 33, 46, 599 S.E.2d 448, 454 (2004) (finding appellant failed to preserve argument regarding excluded witness because testimony of witness was not proffered).Â  
Moreover, this is not a situation where we can overlook the failure to proffer testimony because clear prejudice would result from the ruling.Â  See, e.g., State v. Myers, 301 S.C. 251, 258 n.1, 391 S.E.2d 551, 554 n.1 (1990) (reaching the merits of appellantâ€™s argument regarding the trial courtâ€™s failure to allow his â€œblood spattersâ€ expert to testify despite the fact that no proffer of the testimony was offered because â€œdepriving the jury of expert testimony regarding the blood spatters clearly hampered its ability to evaluate the facts before it in this case.â€).Â  Pursuant to Rule 608 of the South Carolina Rules of Evidence:

  The credibility of a witness may be . . . supported by evidence in the form of opinion or reputation, but subject to these limitations: (1) the evidence may refer only to character for truthfulness or untruthfulness, and (2) the evidence of truthful character is admissible only after the character of the witness for truthfulness has been attacked by opinion or reputation evidence or otherwise.Â  

(Emphasis added.)
Nothing in the record indicates the city attacked Shulerâ€™s character for truthfulness.Â  Thus, the trial court did not err in refusing to allow Shuler to present testimony regarding his reputation for veracity.Â  See also State v. Weaverling, 337 S.C. 460, 473, 523 S.E.2d 787 (Ct. App. 1999) (explaining that a defendant does not have an automatic right to introduce evidence of his character for truthfulness simply because he testifies in his defense).
Shuler next argues the trial court erred in refusing to charge the jury regarding his good character and reputation for truthfulness.Â  We disagree.
â€œThe law to be charged must be determined from the evidence presented at trial.â€Â  State v. Knoten, 347 S.C. 296, 302, 555 S.E.2d 391, 394 (2001).Â  Because no witness testified regarding Shulerâ€™s good character and Shuler failed to proffer the testimony of his character witness, there is no evidence in the record to support such a charge.Â  Accordingly, we find no error in the trial courtâ€™s refusal to include this charge in its jury instruction.Â 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and ANDERSON and KITTREDGE, JJ. concur.
