THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Tammy Matthews Kay, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Ben Franklin Kay, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Â Robert E. Guess, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-076
Heard February 6, 2006 -Â  Filed February 9, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Stephen D. Schusterman, of Rock Hill, for Appellant.
        Michael Benjamin Smith and Thomas F. McDow, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: In this appeal from a final divorce order, Ben Franklin Kay (Husband) argues the family court erred in (1) determining Husband was capable of representing himself and (2) awarding Tammy Matthews Kaye (Wife) a special equity interest in property the partiesâ€™ purchased during the course of their marriage.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Husband and Wife married on June 21, 1980, and separated on September 6, 2001.Â  Wife sought a divorce on the grounds of adultery and one year continuous separation. 
When Wife initiated this action, Husband retained counsel.Â  However, his counsel was relieved on May 27, 2004 on the grounds that Husband failed to communicate with her after requests, thereby rendering representation unreasonably difficult.Â  In the order relieving Husbandâ€™s counsel, the family court scheduled a final hearing for June 17, 2004, and specifically found that Husbandâ€™s â€œfailure to obtain counsel shall not be a reason for a continuance of the final hearing.â€Â  
The final hearing was not actually held until October 5, 2004, and at the hearing, Husband appeared pro se.Â  The family court asked Husband if he planned to hire an attorney, and Husband explained that he could not afford one.Â  After ascertaining that Husband was forty-four years old, had a ninth grade education, and worked most of his adult life, the family court found Husband was capable of representing himself.Â  
Wife testified that during the marriage, she inherited a house from her aunt.Â  Wife sold this house and used the $25,000 in proceeds to purchase property at 1955 Pfaff Drive, which the parties used for rental income.[1]Â  Wife also presented testimony regarding Husbandâ€™s adultery and the special needs of the partiesâ€™ younger daughter.
After Wife presented her case, the family court explained to Husband that he too could call witnesses.Â  Husband declined to do so.
The family court granted the divorce on the ground of one year continuous separation, though it noted that Wife proved Husband committed adultery, and ordered Husband to pay child support for the partiesâ€™ younger daughter. The court also divided the marital property equally between the parties, and granted Wife a $25,000 special equity interest in the 1955 Pfaff Drive property.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When considering an appeal from an order of the family court, our court may find facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 204, 414 S.E.2d 157, 160 (1992).Â  Despite this broad scope of review, however, we recognizeÂ  that the family court judge saw and heard the witnesses and was therefore in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign weight to their testimony.Â  Cherry v. Thomasson, 276 S.C. 524, 525, 280 S.E.2d 541, 541 (1981).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Husband first argues he was denied due process because the trial court erred in determining Husband was capable of representing himself.Â  We find this issue is not preserved for our review as Husband never lodged an objection to appearing pro se.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€).
Husband next argues the trial court erred in granting Wife a special equity interest in the 1955 Pfaff Drive property.Â  We disagree.
At trial, Wife testified that her aunt had houses in Charlotte, and before her aunt died, she sat down with Wife and Wifeâ€™s sister, Debra, and said: â€œThe will is made out to where [the houses] go to Debra, but Debra, I want you to give [Wife] her half.â€Â  Wife testified that Debra followed through with their auntâ€™s wishes, and after Debra inherited the houses, she gifted one to Wife.Â  Wife then sold the house, made $25,000, and used the money to buy the 1955 Pfaff Drive property.Â  
Husband did not present any testimony at the hearing,[2] and for the first time on appeal, he claims the parties purchased the property in Charlotte from Debra.Â  Because the only evidence in the record indicates Wife used proceeds from property she inherited to purchase the 1955 Pfaff Drive property, we find no error in the family courtâ€™s decision to award Wife a special equity interest in that property.Â  Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 204, 414 S.E.2d 157, 160 (1992) (explaining that the appellate courts consider the preponderance of the evidence when reviewing family court orders); see also Hough v. Hough, 312 S.C. 344, 347, 440 S.E.2d 387, 387 (Ct. App. 1994) (finding that husband could not complain on appeal about the valuation of the coupleâ€™s household goods when he presented no evidence regarding their valuation to the family court).
Accordingly, the order of the family court is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and ANDERSON and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1] The partiesâ€™ marital home was also located on Pfaff Drive.
[2] When the trial court announced that it was awarding a special equity interest to Wife, Husband did not request the right to re-open the testimony; rather, Husband only stated his intention to appeal the ruling.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        South Carolina Department of Social Services, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Willie Doe and Vivian Doe, Appellants.
        In the Interests of:
        Brittany Roe DOB 05/20/90,
        R. Doe DOB 3/31/95, and 
        L. Doe DOB 03/30/98,
        Minors of the age of 18. 
      
    
  


Appeal From Williamsburg County
Â George M. McFaddin, Jr., Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-077
Submitted February 1, 2006 â€“ Filed February 9, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        John D. Elliott, of Columbia, for Appellants. 
        Ernest Joseph Jarrett, of Kingstree, for Respondent. 
        James Darrell Dotson, of Lake City, for Guardian Ad Litem. 
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Willie and Vivian Doe[1] appeal from a family court order removing his then fourteen year old daughter, Brittany, from their custody based upon a finding of sexual abuse against him.Â  The family court permitted, over objection, the minor child to testify outside Willie Doeâ€™s presence, and the sole ground asserted on appeal is that â€œthe evidence did not justify any legally sufficient necessity for doing so.â€Â  We affirm. [2] 
FACTS
Willie Doe (Father) is the biological father of Brittany.Â  For the first twelve years of her life, Brittany had little contact with Father and lived with her mother.Â  When Brittanyâ€™s mother died in 2002, Brittany began living with Father and his wife, Vivian Doe, in South Carolina.Â  On September 22, 2003, the South Carolina Department of Social Services (DSS) brought this action seeking custody of Brittany, alleging that Father sexually abused her.Â  DSS moved to allow the minor child to testify outside the presence of Father at trial.Â  
In consideration of the motion, expert testimony was presented by the childâ€™s therapist, who testified that requiring the child to testify in the presence of Father, a police officer, would be traumatic and might cause a regression in her functioning.Â  The therapist testified that the child had expressed anxiety about testifying in front of Father, saying she â€œdidnâ€™t know if she could handle [it]â€ because she was afraid of Father.Â  
Without objection from either party, the family court judge also heard testimony in camera with only the minor child and the guardian ad litem present.Â  The family court judge observed that the child was â€œextremely articulate in expressing her concerns about testifying with [Father] present.â€Â  The judge further noted that the child expressed, without solicitation, that this matter was a very serious concern for her and that she felt like she could testify more fully and freely if Father were absent.Â  Finding that she was afraid to testify in front of Father, and that requiring testimony under those circumstances would potentially negatively affect the child, the family court judge granted the motion to permit the child to testify outside Fatherâ€™s presence.Â Â Â  
Once the motion was granted, counsel for both parties agreed on the procedure for taking the childâ€™s testimony.Â  It was agreed that during the childâ€™s testimony at trial, Father would remain in an adjacent room in which he would be able to hear the proceedings via a speaker, and to knock on the door to stop the proceedings should he need to consult with his attorney.Â  The child then testified regarding the allegations, describing episodes of fondling, masturbation, and intercourse.Â  DSS presented corroborating testimony, and Father presented witnesses who testified on his behalf.Â  
The family court judge found that Father sexually abused his daughter and granted custody to DSS.Â  Father was ordered to pay child support and his name was entered in the Central Registry of Child Abuse and Neglect.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
ANALYSIS
Father argues his confrontation rights were violated by allowing his daughter to testify outside his presence, limiting his challenge on appeal to the claim that â€œthe evidence did not justify any legally sufficient necessity for doing so.â€Â  In criminal cases, the right of an accused to confront, face to face, witnesses against him at trial is constitutionally protected.[3]Â  Coy v. Iowa, 487 U.S. 1012, 1016 (1988); U.S. Const. amend. VI; S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 14.Â  â€œHistorically, the right of confrontation and cross examination has been held to apply in criminal prosecutions.â€  State ex rel. Medlock v. Nest Egg Soc. Today, Inc., 290 S.C. 124, 130, 348 S.E.2d 381, 385 (Ct. App. 1986).Â  The right of confrontation has additionally found limited application in civil cases.Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Social Services on Behalf of State of Tex. v. Holden, 319 S.C. 72, 78-79, 459 S.E.2d 846, 849-850 (1995).Â  The area of child abuse and neglectâ€”family court intervention proceedingsâ€”is one area where the right of confrontation is implicated.Â  The standard for criminal cases involving child witnesses, while not directly applicable, was found by our supreme court to provide useful guidance in establishing a standard for intervention proceedings in family court.Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Social Services v. Wilson, 352 S.C. 445, 455, 574 S.E.2d 730, 735 (2002).
The Wilson court set forth the following guidelines.Â  First, the family court must make case-specific findings of need for special accommodations, and place those findings on the record.Â  Id.Â  The court may consider the childâ€™s age, mentality, and any other pertinent information, and should consider the testimony of the child and other relevant witnesses in making its determination.Â  Id.Â  Second, if the child witness is allowed to testify outside the defendantâ€™s presence, arrangements must be made to ensure that testimony is given in an environment that indicates the seriousness of the matter.Â  Id.Â  The defendant must be able to hear the childâ€™s testimony, and to confer with counsel, who must be able to cross-examine the child witness.Â  Id. at 455-56, 574 S.E.2d at 735.Â  
Because no objection was raised at trial to the procedure used during testimony in this case,[4] the only issue is whether the family courtâ€™s findings complied with Wilson.Â  The family court made case-specific findings on the record.Â  Although the findings could have been more fully developed, we find they were sufficient to satisfy the Wilson standard.Â  The judge considered expert testimony that the childâ€™s functioning and ability to testify would be adversely affected by the physical presence of Father in the courtroom.[5]Â  The judge considered the childâ€™s age, her concerns that she would not be able to testify freely with Father present, and the fact that her academic performance, which had suffered during the period the alleged incidents occurred but had progressively improved since then, might be adversely affected.Â  We find no abuse of discretion in the family court judgeâ€™s decision to permit the child to testify outside the presence of Father. 
CONCLUSION
We hold that the family court complied with the Wilson standard in permitting the minor child to testify outside of Fatherâ€™s presence.Â  We thus find no abuse of discretion, and the decision of the family court is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., ANDERSON, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1] Â We find the use of the name Doe is appropriate in light of the allegations and findings of sexual abuse.
[2] Â Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[3] Â Even in criminal cases, however, this right must occasionally give way to considerations of public policy, such as the trauma suffered by a child victim of sexual abuse when testifying in the presence of the defendant.Â  Maryland v. Craig, 497 U.S. 836, 857 (1990).Â  
[4] Â The procedure used during trial was suggested by Fatherâ€™s attorney.Â  
[5] Â Father did not object to the therapistâ€™s qualification as an expert witness.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE. IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Gerald Ballard and Linda Ballard, Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Maria Barbee Ballard and Jerald Wayne Ballard, Jr., Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Alvin D. Johnson, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-078
Submitted February 1, 2006 â€“ Filed February 10, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Andrew G. Goodson, of Fountain Inn, for Appellants.
        W. Daniel Yarborough, Jr., of Greenville, for Respondent Maria Barbee Ballard.
        Jerald Wayne Ballard, Jr., of Pelzer, Pro Se.
        Vanessa L. Hartman, of Greenville, Guardian ad Litem.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM: Â Gerald Ballard and Linda Ballard (Grandparents) appeal from the family courtâ€™s order refusing to terminate the parental rights of their son, Jerald Wayne Ballard, Jr. (Father) and Maria Barbee Ballard (Mother) and in altering the previously ordered visitation schedule.Â  We affirm.
Facts
Mother and Father were married in October of 1997.Â  On June 17, 1998, Christopher Wayne Ballard, was born to Mother and Father. Christian Marie Pearl Ballard was born on November 21, 2000.Â  Father began using drugs early in the marriage.Â  Eventually, Mother began using drugs. Â Mother and Father separated and reconciled numerous times.Â  In July of 2001, Mother asked Grandparents â€œto watch over the kids for [her] to go to the hospital and get some help to get clean.â€
There were approximately fifteen months, June 2002 to September 2003, when Mother had no contact with the children. Â According to Mother, when she was released from the hospital, Grandparents prevented her from seeing the children.Â  Mother attempted two interventions by the court to enforce her visitation rights.Â  Neither of these attempts were successful.Â  Mother admitted this period of time where she was out of contact with her children occurred during a time in which she was actively addicted to drugs.Â  It was difficult for Mother to maintain employment and an appropriate lifestyle. Â Mother claims she tried to speak to her children during this period of time.Â  The evidence is contradictory as to whether the children were being prevented from speaking to Mother.
On March 28, 2002, the family court granted custody of Christopher and Christian to Grandparents, with supervised visitation to Mother and Father from 1:00 p.m. until 4:00 p.m. every Sunday. Â The judge ordered that visitation was to be supervised by Margie Ballard, the paternal great-grandmother of the children.Â  The judge ordered Mother and Father to each pay $56.00 per week as child support.Â  Grandparents had custody of the minor children on a de facto basis since July 24, 2001.
Mother and Father paid no child support from January of 2002 until October of 2002.Â  According to the testimony, Father was not paying child support because he had already given up his parental rights in his mind by executing papers provided by Grandparents to this effect. Â Mother was incarcerated at least two times for failing to pay child support.
On December 31, 2002, the Grandparents brought this action for termination of parental rights of Mother and Father and for the adoption of Christopher and Christian.
Neither Mother nor Father retained legal counsel or filed any responsive pleadings prior to September 24, 2003. Â Further, Father executed a document consenting to the termination of his parental rights and to adoption by Grandparents. Â This matter was scheduled for a hearing on September 24.Â  By order dated October 1, 2003, the court continued this matter because Mother had hired an attorney and informed the court she opposed termination of her parental rights. Â Motherâ€™s attorney filed an answer and counterclaim seeking increased visitation with the minor children.
At the final hearing, the family court judge heard numerous witnesses for each party, including testimony by the guardian ad litem and submission of a guardian ad litem report.Â  The court received documentary evidence.Â  Father was not present at the hearing and did not participate in any way.Â  The family court denied termination of parental rights of Mother and Father and altered the visitation schedule established by the March 28, 2002 order.Â  Grandparents filed a motion for reconsideration, which the court denied. 
Standard of Review
In a termination of parental rights (TPR) case, the paramount consideration is the best interests of the children.Â  See South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Sims, 359 S.C. 601, 598 S.E.2d 303 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Grounds for TPR must be proved by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Hooper v. Rockwell, 334 S.C. 281, 513 S.E.2d 358 (1999); see also Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745, 747-48 (1982) (â€œBefore a State may sever completely and irrevocably the rights of parents in their natural child, due process requires that the State support its allegations by at least clear and convincing evidence.â€).
In a TPR case, the appellate court may review the record and make its own findings of whether clear and convincing evidence supports termination.Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Parker, 336 S.C. 248, 519 S.E.2d 351 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  However, our broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the findings below or ignore the fact that the trial judge was in a better position to assess the credibility of the witnesses.Â  Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 477 S.E.2d 476 (Ct. App. 1996).
Discussion
I.Â  Termination of Parental Rights
A.Â  Father
Grandparents argue the family court erred by failing to terminate Fatherâ€™s parental rights where Father consented to the termination and adoption and â€œhad no contact with the minor children since birth.â€Â  We find this issue is not preserved for review.
 In declining to terminate Fatherâ€™s rights, the family court held: â€œI do find that the [Grandparents] have established their right to terminate the parental rights of [Father] and the minor children, but for the reasons expressed herein, the Court determines that it is not appropriate to terminate the natural fatherâ€™s parental rights, inasmuch as the parental rights of the natural mother have not been terminated.â€Â  In their Rule 59(e) motion, Grandparents fail to raise any issues regarding the family courtâ€™s ruling as to Father.Â  The issue regarding Fatherâ€™s consent to the termination is therefore not preserved for appeal.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (requiring appellants to make a rule 59(e) motion requesting the trial court to rule upon an issue the trial court neglected in order to preserve the argument for appellate review).Â  Furthermore, in their brief to our court, Grandparents merely make a cursory argument regarding the family courtâ€™s failure to terminate Fatherâ€™s parental rights, and they cite to no authority for their position.Â  Thus, their arguments as to Father are deemed abandoned.Â  See State v. Addison, 338 S.C. 277, 285, 525 S.E.2d 901, 906 (Ct. App. 1999) (â€œConclusory arguments constitute an abandonment of the issue on appeal.â€).Â  
B.Â  Mother
Grandparents argue the family court erred in failing to terminate Motherâ€™s parental rights.Â  Grandparents claim they proved Mother willfully failed to visit or support the minor children for periods in excess of six months.
Section 20-7-1572(3) and (4) of the South Carolina Code provides:
The family court may order the termination of parental rights upon a finding of one or more of the following grounds and a finding that termination is in the best interest of the child:

  . . . .
  (3) The child has lived outside the home of either parent for a period of six months, and during that time the parent has wilfully failed to visit the child.Â  The court may attach little or no weight to incidental visitations, but it must be shown that the parent was not prevented from visiting by the party having custody or by court order.Â  The distance of the childâ€™s placement from the parentâ€™s home must be taken into consideration when determining the ability to visit;
  (4) The child has lived outside the home of either parent for a period of six months, and during that time the parent has wilfully failed to support the child.Â  Failure to support means that the parent has failed to make a material contribution to the childâ€™s care.Â  A material contribution consists of either financial contributions according to the parentâ€™s means or contributions of food, clothing, shelter, or other necessities for the care of the child according to the parentâ€™s means.Â  The court may consider all relevant circumstances in determining whether or not the parent has wilfully failed to support the child, including requests for support by the custodian and the ability of the parent to provide support.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(3) & (4) (Supp. 2005).Â  The court must find willfulness both in the failure to visit and the failure to support.
Whether a parentâ€™s failure to visit or support a child is â€œwillfulâ€ within the meaning of Â§ 20-7-1572 is a question of intent to be determined from all the facts and circumstances in each case.Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Broome, 307 S.C. 48, 413 S.E.2d 835 (1992).Â  The trial judge is given wide discretion in making this determination.Â  Id.Â  However, the element of wilfulness must be established by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Richberg v. Dawson, 278 S.C. 356, 296 S.E.2d 338 (1982); South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Parker, 336 S.C. 248, 519 S.E.2d 351 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  A parentâ€™s conduct which evinces a settled purpose to forego parental duties may fairly be characterized as â€œwillfulâ€ because it manifests a conscious indifference to the rights of the child to receive support and consortium from the parent.Â  Hamby v. Hamby, 264 S.C. 614, 216 S.E.2d 536 (1975).
In the instant case, the judge heard the testimony of Grandparents, the paternal great-grandmother, Mother, and a number of other witnesses.Â  The great-grandmotherâ€™s testimony showed that there were a couple of times when Mother tried to visit with the children around July of 2002 but there was some obstacle that prevented the visit, such as when great-grandmotherâ€™s sister was in the hospital. Â According to the great-grandmother and Mother, since September of 2003, Mother has exercised her visitation regularly.
Grandparents admit to having notice of Motherâ€™s filing of a pro se motion for violation of visitation in November of 2002, even though they state in their testimony that the period that Mother failed to visit was from June of 2002 to September of 2003.Â  During this time, Mother telephoned three or four times and left messages on Grandparentsâ€™ voice mail, saying â€œhello, tell the children I love them.â€
Mother testified that she made child support payments in 2001, 2002, and 2003, as is demonstrated by the payment history submitted into evidence.Â  Â She denied willfully failing to pay support.Â  Over this three year period of time, Mother paid over $6000 in child support, even though during much of this time she was unemployed.Â  During this time, Grandparents required no support from Father. Â There is nothing in the record to indicate Grandparents specifically requested support from either Mother or Father.Â  Section 20-7-1572(4) specifically states that the court â€œmay consider all relevant circumstances in determining whether or not the parent has wilfully failed to support the child, including requests for support by the custodian and the ability of the parent to provide support.â€Â  As of the date of the hearing in this case, although she was still in arrears, Mother was making steady routine child support payments.Â  The payment records indicate Mother has been consistent in making payments once she obtained employment.
The guardian ad litem stated: â€œI think [Motherâ€™s] extremely tenacious and sheâ€™s gone a lot further than a lot of others that Iâ€™ve seen in the same situation.â€ Â The guardian declared: â€œIâ€™ve been doing Guardian work for seven years and I think sheâ€™s probably the most rehabilitat[ed] defendant Iâ€™ve ever met.Â  She is completely convincing.Â  Sheâ€™s completely honest and forthright.Â  She doesnâ€™t hide anything from me.â€Â  The guardian felt Mother had been â€œtotally honestâ€ with her.
The court held: â€œI find that it is not appropriate to terminate the parental rights of [Mother], in and to her children by the facts presented at this hearing.Â  I find [Mother] has fully rehabilitated herself as to prior drug problems.â€Â  The judge further declared: â€œ[Mother] has presented a strong case that she has totally turned her life around and has made excellent progress in her life.Â  She is now working full-time at Wal-Mart.Â  She has been drug free for many months.Â  She is fully participating in an intensive lifestyle changing program at her church, which appears to be very successful.â€Â  The judge noted: â€œ[T]he guardian ad litem in this case states that she has not seen such a total turn around in a case such as this in her entire seven (7) years of guardian ad litem experience.â€ Â The judge stated â€œthe payment records indicate that [Mother] has been consistent in making payments once she obtained employment.â€ Â The judge found: â€œ[O]n these facts, there has been no willful failure to visit by [Mother] nor is there a willful failure to provide support.â€
The family court judge did not err in finding Grandparents did not prove, by clear and convincing evidence, the willful failure to visit or the willful failure to provide support to the minor children.
II.Â  Visitation Schedule
Grandparents argue the family court erred â€œin altering the previously ordered visitation schedule.â€Â  Grandparents claim the court further erred in failing to alter the visitation schedule to accommodate the activities of the minor children because, on motion to alter or amend, Grandparents â€œshowed modification of the visitation schedule by the court interfered with activities of at least one of the minor children.â€
The court held: â€œI find it appropriate that visitation for [Mother] shall be increased from the present three (3) hours on alternating Sundays to three (3) Saturdays per month from 9:00 a.m. until 5:00 p.m.Â  Visitation should be accomplished on the 1st, 2nd, and 4th Saturdays of the month.Â  The [Grandparents] and [Mother] shall exchange the child for visitation purposes at the Hardees Restaurant in Fountain Inn , South Carolina . . . .â€Â  It is within the courtâ€™s discretion to alter the visitation schedule in light of the dramatic change in circumstances.Â  Mother has a good job at Wal-Mart and has rehabilitated herself in a significant way.
The record does not disclose any conflicting extracurricular activities of the minor children from the expanded visitation ordered by the court.Â  Therefore, it is appropriate for the court to deny the reconsideration motion of the Grandparents.
Conclusion
Accordingly, the order of the family court is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., ANDERSON and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Beverly M. Ffrench, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Adolph F. Ffrench, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
W. Jeffrey Young, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-079
Submitted February 1, 2006 â€“ Filed February 10, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        William Michael Duncan, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Herbert E. Buhl, III, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Beverly Ffrench (Wife) appeals the family courtâ€™s order finding her in contempt of a decree of separate maintenance (the Decree).Â  On appeal, Wife contends the family court erred in failing to grant a continuance and in finding Wife owed Adolph Ffrench (Husband) $59,770.82 pursuant to the Decree.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Husband and Wife married on May 2, 1975, and the couple separated on June 11, 2002.Â  Wife filed a complaint in the family court requesting a decree of separate maintenance.Â  Husband and Wife reached an agreement (the Agreement) on September 30, 2002 that provided, in relevant part:

  [Wife] agrees to give [Husband] forty nine (49 %) percent her [sic] share in the Corporation [Bevad], Inc.Â  The corporation [sic] sole asset is the property located at 308 Whitehurst Way, Columbia, SC 29229 with an approximate value of $110,000.00.Â  The parties agree to share the proceeds of the sale: 51% to [Wife] and 49 % to [Husband].

The family court held a hearing, at which Husband and Wife presented the Agreement to the court for approval.Â  On February 7, 2003, the family court issued the Decree, which provided, in relevant part:

  The marital residence which is titled in the corporate name of Bevad, Inc., shall be sold and the net proceeds of the sale shall be divided between the parties.Â  [Wife] shall receive fifty one (51 %) percent of the net proceeds of sale and [Husband] shall receive forty nine (49 %) percent of the net proceeds of sale.

The Decree incorporated the Agreement, which the family court attached.Â  On March 28, 2003, Bevad, Inc. sold the property at Whitehurst Way and received $121,981.28 in net proceeds.Â  Wife signed the settlement statement as the president of Bevad, Inc. 
On October 9, 2003, Husband and Wife again appeared before the family court, this time to receive a final divorce decree.Â  Wife testified at this hearing that all financial matters had been dealt with by the Decree, and further affirmed that â€œ[t]hereâ€™s nothing left to be exchanged . . . .â€Â  On cross-examination, Husbandâ€™s attorney asked Wife about the sale of the property.Â  Wife explained it had been sold in March of 2003, and Husband received his share of the proceeds in April of 2003.Â  Furthermore, she testified a check was written to him from Bevad, Inc., and he cashed the check.[2]Â  The family court granted a divorce, but did not address the issue of outstanding financial obligations between the parties.
On August 4, 2004, Husband filed a complaint and rule to show cause in the family court, alleging Wife violated the Decree.Â  On August 9, 2004, the family court issued a rule to show cause, ordering Wife to appear and explain why she should not be held in contempt of the Decree.Â  The family court held a hearing on August 24, 2004, at which Wife appeared pro se. 
At the hearing, Husband testified he received no money from the sale of the property and no one else owned an interest in the property.Â  Wife asserted she deposited $27,005.04 of the proceeds in Husbandâ€™s bank account with South Carolina Federal Credit Union.Â  However, she also indicated she took $24,000 of that money out of the account and transferred it into a certificate of deposit (COD) in Husbandâ€™s name.Â  A bank statement shows a deposit of $27,000.00, and a withdrawal four days later of $24,000.00.Â  Wife admitted she authorized the transfer to the COD, but she provided no documents evidencing the COD at the hearing. 
As an explanation for why she only transferred $27,000 to Husband, Wife initially asserted she had to pay all of the people from whom she borrowed the money to buy the property.Â  She explained she had proof of these loans, but did not bring it to court.Â  Later at the hearing, Wife testified the corporation owned the property, she only owned fifty-one percent of the corporation, the coupleâ€™s son owned the other forty-nine percent of the corporation, and their son received his proceeds.[3]
On September 14, 2004, the family court issued an order finding Wife in willful contempt of the Decree.Â  The order stated: â€œThe parties testified that although the former marital home was titled in the name of Bevad, Inc. that this was a corporation completely owned by [Husband and Wife], and this property was used as the marital residence and it was in their control.â€Â  The order further stated the terms of the Decree were clear and unambiguous, and Wife was required under its terms to pay Husband forty-nine percent of the sale proceeds, which equaled $59,770.82.
The family court sentenced Wife to ten days in the Richland County Detention Center, suspended upon the payment of $59,770.82 to Husband by November 1, 2004, and attorneysâ€™ fees to Husband by December 1, 2004.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Wife contends the family court erred in denying her a continuance at the contempt hearing.Â  We find this issue is not preserved for our review.
An issue must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court to be preserved for appellate review.Â  Floyd v. Floyd, 365 S.C. 56, 73, 615 S.E.2d 465, 474 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  At the contempt hearing, the following colloquy took place between the family court and Wife:

  The court: Did you have time to get an attorney?
  Ms. Ffrench: No; I did not, I got papers on Thursday night, I was at the hospital on Friday, and I have documentation to prove that.Â  My blood pressure was 180/106, I was having trembling in my arm, andâ€”
  The court: Okay.
  Ms. Ffrench: So, I brought what I have to prove to the court.
  The court: Okay; you may proceed.

Even assuming Wife properly raised the issue of a continuance to the family court, she did not assert a legal basis for this motion, and the judge did not make a ruling.Â  Therefore, this issue is not preserved for our review.
Wife also argues the family court erred in finding she owed $59,770.82 in accordance with the Decree.Â  Specifically, Wife argues the family court erred in interpreting the Decree.Â  We disagree.
A contempt hearing lies in equity, and an appellate court may thus make its own findings of fact.Â  See Lindsay v. Lindsay, 328 S.C. 329, 340, 491 S.E.2d 583, 589 (Ct. App. 1997) (â€œInasmuch as this [action for contempt] is an action in equity, we may make our own findings of fact.â€).Â  â€œHowever, we are not required to ignore the fact that the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.â€Â  Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 452, 477 S.E.2d 476, 480 (Ct. App. 1996).
Wife testified at the contempt hearing that her son owned forty-nine percent of Bevad, Inc., and she had to pay people who loaned her money to purchase the property.Â  However, Wifeâ€™s testimony is the only evidence of either of these assertions. Â Based on its findings, the family court clearly gave Wifeâ€™s testimony no credence.Â  Wife previously testified that Husband cashed a check written to him from Bevad, Inc.Â  In the contempt hearing, however, she testified the proceeds of the sale were put into a checking account to which she had access.Â  Wife never offered any explanation for the inconsistencies in these two statements.Â  Wifeâ€™s equivocations support the family courtâ€™s refusal to give any credibility to her bald assertion that her son owns an interest in Bevad, Inc., or that she had to pay creditors with respect to the sale of the property.Â  We find the family court properly disregarded Wifeâ€™s testimony in interpreting the Decree.Â  We therefore hold the family court did not err in finding Wife owed $59,770.82 in accordance with the Decree.
AFFIRMED.
BEATTY, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Husband did not appear at this hearing, but his attorney appeared on his behalf.
[3] In the record on appeal, Wife included the affidavit of her son, Bradley M. Ffrench, corroborating this testimony.Â  However, Rule 210(c), SCACR, provides â€œ[t]he Record [on Appeal] shall not . . . include matter which was not presented to the lower court or tribunal.â€Â  Therefore, we give this affidavit no efficacy.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Robert David Johnson, Employee, Respondent,
        v.
        Santee Cooper, Employer, and South Carolina Public Service Authority, Carrier, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Berkeley County
Thomas L. Hughston, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-0081
Heard February 7, 2006 â€“ Filed February 10, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Kirsten L. Barr, of Mt. Pleasant, for Appellants.
        Stephen B. Samuels, of Sumter, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â In this Workersâ€™ Compensation case, the employer, Santee Cooper, and its insurance carrier, South Carolina Public Service Authority (collectively referred to as Santee Cooper) appeal the circuit courtâ€™s affirmance of the appellate panelâ€™s rulings that Robert David Johnson (1) sustained a compensable back injury caused by the repetitive trauma of his job at Santee Cooper; (2) gave timely notice to Santee Cooper of his back injury; and (3) was entitled to temporary disability benefits.Â  We affirm.
Facts
In 1991, Johnson began working as an Equipment Operator I with Santee Cooper.Â  He was eventually promoted to Equipment Operator III.Â  That job required operating heavy equipment used to clear the right of way for power lines.Â  Johnson had a part-time seasonal job with Rickenbaker Cotton Gin and was a volunteer firefighter.Â  At Rickenbaker, Johnson ran the office, did paperwork on the bale weights, and occasionally drove a truck.
In March of 2000, Johnson underwent back surgery.Â  The surgery was not claimed under Workersâ€™ Compensation.Â  Johnson returned to work with no restrictions in May of 2000.
Around late September or early October of 2001, Johnson was transferred to the â€œVersatileâ€ crew.Â  A Versatile is similar to a log skidder with big tires and a big cutting deck.Â  Johnsonâ€™s job required operating the Versatile on â€œrough swampy areas.â€Â  A month or two after Johnson started on the Versatile, about November 2001, he informed David Duke, his crew leader, he was having â€œextreme back painâ€ and asked Duke to take him off the Versatile.Â  He told Duke he thought running the Versatile was causing his back pain because of the way it rocks and bounces all the time.Â  According to Johnson, Duke refused to take him off the Versatile, telling Johnson he had no one else to run it.
Johnsonâ€™s back problems worsened.Â  On December 7, 2001, he returned to Dr. Kenneth S. Kammer, the surgeon who performed his first back surgery.Â  At that time, Johnson was having â€œextreme back pain.â€Â  Dr. Kammer advised Johnson he would need another operation and gave him a letter to take to Santee Cooper advising he would be out for surgery.Â  A day or two later, Johnson gave the letter to Duke.Â  He also gave the letter to Benjamin Baggette, a â€œ[s]upervisor right of way clearing,â€ who â€œsent it to medical.â€
Johnson had his surgery on January 3, 2002.Â  After his surgery, Johnson retained a lawyer.Â  His attorney mailed a letter to the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission and Santee Cooper filing Johnsonâ€™s claim on February 27, 2002.
On March 4, 2002, Johnson had a meeting at Santee Cooper with Baggette, Duke, and Joe Hutchinson.Â  Hutchinson is a senior safety specialist with Santee Cooper.Â  At the meeting, Hutchinson asked Johnson about making a Workersâ€™ Compensation claim.Â  Johnson told the men he hurt his back operating the Versatile and that was the reason for his claim.Â  Johnson stated he had told Duke the previous fall about the Versatile bothering his back and asked Duke to take him off the Versatile.
Santee Cooper filed a 12-A listing the date of injury as December 7, 2001, with notice being given at the safety meeting on March 1, 2002.Â  Santee Cooper denied the claim based on lack of notice.
Dr. Kammer kept Johnson out of work or on light duty until at least January 2003.Â  Johnson was restricted to no lifting greater than thirty pounds.Â  His job description required lifting up to fifty pounds.Â  Johnson was unable to return to work as an equipment operator because of his work restrictions.Â  Santee Cooper had no work within his restrictions.Â  Johnson returned to light duty work at Rickenbaker Cotton Gin on August 8, 2002.
The single commissioner determined the claim was compensable and found: â€œ[D]ue to the repetitive trauma attendant to his operation of the â€œVersatile,â€ [Johnson] suffered compensable injuries by accident to his lower back and left leg (radiculopathy). This injury was an aggravation of a pre-existing condition.â€Â  The commissioner awarded causally related medical treatment and temporary disability compensation from January 3, 2002 through December 18, 2002.Â  The single commissioner made no conclusions of law.Â  The appellate panel affirmed with modifications.Â  The appellate panel added Conclusions of Law.Â  The panel amended the award of temporary partial disability during the period when Johnson had not reached maximum medical improvement, but had returned to light duty work at his second job.Â  The circuit court affirmed the order of the appellate panel in its entirety.
Standard of Review
The substantial evidence rule of the Administrative Procedures Act governs the standard of review in a Workersâ€™ Compensation decision.Â  Frame v. Resort Servs., Inc., 357 S.C. 520, 593 S.E.2d 491 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  An appellate court must affirm the findings of fact made by the appellate panel if they are supported by substantial evidence and not controlled by legal error.Â  Tiller v. National Health Care Ctr., 334 S.C. 333, 513 S.E.2d 843 (1999); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) (2005).Â  Substantial evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence, nor the evidence viewed blindly from one side of the case, but is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the administrative agency reached in order to justify its action.Â  Pratt v. Morris Roofing, Inc., 357 S.C. 619, 594 S.E.2d 272 (2004).Â  The findings of an administrative agency are presumed correct and will be set aside only if unsupported by substantial evidence.Â  Anderson v. Baptist Med. Ctr., 343 S.C. 487, 541 S.E.2d 526 (2001).Â  It is not within our province to reverse findings of the appellate panel which are supported by substantial evidence.Â  Broughton v. South of the Border, 336 S.C. 488, 520 S.E.2d 634 (Ct. App. 1999).
Discussion
I.Â  Repetitive Trauma Injury
Santee Cooper argues the circuit court erred in affirming the appellate panelâ€™s finding that due to the repetitive trauma of operating the Versatile, Johnson suffered a compensable injury to his back.Â  Santee Cooper claims â€œ[t]here is absolutely no evidence in the record that [Johnson] suffered any back injury while working for Santee Cooper.â€Â  We disagree.
Generally, a repetitive trauma injury is compensable under the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.Â  See Pee v. AVM, Inc., 352 S.C. 167, 573 S.E.2d 785 (2002).Â  Further, back injuries caused by repetitive trauma are compensable when supported by substantial evidence.Â  See White v. Medical University of South Carolina, 355 S.C. 560, 586 S.E.2d 157 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Repetitive trauma injuries have a gradual onset caused by the cumulative effect of repetitive traumatic events or â€œmini-accidents.â€Â  Schurlknight v. City of North Charleston, 352 S.C. 175, 574 S.E.2d 194 (2002).Â  It is well established that causation can be proven by both expert and lay testimony.Â  Tiller v. National Health Care Ctr., 334 S.C. 333, 513 S.E.2d 843 (1999).Â  Indeed, lay testimony of the employee unsupported by any medical evidence can be sufficient to support the finding of a causal connection.Â  Id.; Arnold v. Benjamin Booth Co., 257 S.C. 337, 185 S.E.2d 830 (1971).
There is substantial evidence to support the appellate panelâ€™s finding that, â€œ[d]ue to the repetitive trauma of operating the Versatile, [Johnson] aggravated his pre-existing back condition.â€
Following Johnsonâ€™s first back surgery in March 2000, he was cleared to work full duty with no restrictions by Dr. Kammer.Â  Johnson had no complaints throughout the remainder of 2000 and most of 2001.Â  About one or two months after Johnson began working on the Versatile in the fall of 2001, Johnson started â€œhaving extreme, more harder back pain . . .Â  in the low of [his] backâ€ and experienced some numbness in his left leg.Â  The pain â€œc[a]me on gradually.â€Â  Johnson told Duke he was having â€œback painsâ€ and â€œwanted to get off of [the Versatile].â€Â  Johnson specifically informed Duke his back pain was caused by â€œ[r]unning the Versatile, because [of] the way it rocks and bounces on me all the time . . . [o]n the rough terrain on the right-of-ways itâ€™s more bouncier, itâ€™s not more comfortable than the tractors.â€Â  Duke confirmed the Versatile was a â€œbumpy ride.â€
Johnson saw Dr. Kammer regarding his back problems on December 7, 2001.Â  After an examination, Dr. Kammer immediately recommended back surgery.Â  The exacerbation of the back pain by Johnsonâ€™s job is documented in Dr. Kammerâ€™s report of December 7, 2001:

  He is a heavy equipment operator for Santee Cooper and works heavy equipment mostly in a sitting position. . . . He understood that the primary purpose of surgery [in 2000] was to get rid of the sciatic pain but that it would not necessarily prevent future back pain especially in a heavy industrial job. . . . His pain is primarily exacerbated by long periods of sitting . . . He has not missed any work but he has a lot of discomfort at work.

Dr. Kammer signed off on a Santee Cooper Industrial Work Availability Form (IWA) on July 17, 2002.Â  The IWA contained a question asking whether the injury was work-related.Â  The form was marked â€œyes.â€Â  The form had a space after the word â€œyesâ€ for a brief description, in which was written â€œBack pain.â€Â  On July 22, 2002, an internal Santee Cooper e-mail was sent from Lynne Jamison to Baggette noting receipt of â€œIWA from Dr. Kammerâ€ and stating â€œ[t]he IWA also indicated that his back pain was work related.â€Â  Santee Cooper pointed out that two earlier IWAs indicated the problem was not work-related.Â  However, Duke admitted he may have checked that the problem was not work-related on these two earlier forms. 
Substantial evidence supports the appellate panelâ€™s finding that Johnson sustained a compensable injury to his back as a result of the repetitive trauma of operating the Versatile in his job at Santee Cooper.
II.Â  Statutory Notice
Santee Cooper maintains the appellate panelâ€™s finding that Johnson satisfied the statutory notice requirement is not supported by substantial evidence.Â  We disagree.
Section 42-15-20 of the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act requires that every injured employee or his representative give the employer notice of a job-related accident within ninety days after its occurrence.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-20 (1985).Â  In applying section 42-15-20 to a repetitive trauma injury, the appellate panel shall determine the statutory notice requirement from the time of disablement of the claimant.Â  Bass v. Isochem, 365 S.C. 454, 617 S.E.2d 369 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Notice begins to run when the employee becomes disabled and could discover with reasonable diligence his condition is compensable.Â  Id.Â  The burden is upon the claimant to show compliance with the notice provisions of section 42-15-20.Â  Id.
Johnson testified that, a month or two after Johnson started on the Versatile, he informed Duke he was experiencing back pain and asked Duke to take him off the Versatile.Â  Johnson declared that Duke denied his request.Â  On March 4, 2002, Johnson attended a meeting at Santee Cooper with Baggette, Duke, and Hutchinson.Â  At the meeting, Hutchinson asked Johnson about his injury, how it happened, and about making a Workersâ€™ Compensation claim.Â  When Hutchinson asked Johnson whether he told anyone at Santee Cooper about hurting his back, Johnson responded: â€œI spoke with David Duke about it . . . [and] asked him to take me off the machine.â€Â  According to Johnson, Duke â€œverified that [Johnson] asked him to take [Johnson] off of [the Versatile]â€ in the fall before the surgery.Â  In addition, Baggette stated that, at the meeting, Johnson advised Baggette that in the fall of 2001 he told Duke about the Versatile bothering his back.Â  Baggette further professed that Duke â€œverified . . . that that fall before [Johnson] had the surgery he had told Duke about the Versatile bothering his back.â€Â  Although Duke did not deny he and Johnson had a conversation in October 2001 about the Versatile hurting Johnsonâ€™s back, Duke stated he did not â€œrecallâ€ Johnson reporting this information to him.
On cross-examination, the following colloquy occurred between defense counsel and Johnson:

  Q:Â  When you took [Duke Dr. Kammerâ€™s December 7, 2001] letter, did you tell him then that your problems were work related or that your surgery was caused by your employment at Santee Cooper? 
  A.Â  Not right then at that point in time.Â  It was a couple weeks later that I talked to him about that. . . . It was before surgery right after I gave him that letter.
  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  . . . . 
  Q.Â  What specifically did you tell [Duke]?
  A.Â  That I wantâ€”this oneâ€™s going to be covered under Workmenâ€™s Comp. and he was going to look into it.

Substantial evidence supports the appellate panelâ€™s finding that Johnson gave timely notice to Santee Cooper of his injury.
III.Â  Temporary Disability Benefits
Santee Cooper argues the appellate panel erred in awarding Johnson temporary disability benefits because â€œthere is no evidence to support a finding that [Johnson] was incapable of earning his pre-accident wages after April 29, 2002.â€Â  We disagree.
The appellate panel awarded Johnson temporary disability benefits from January 3, 2002 through December 18, 2002.Â  It is undisputed that Johnson was under work restrictions during the period from January 3, 2002 through December 18, 2002.Â  On July 17, 2002, Dr. Kammer filled out Santee Cooperâ€™s own IWA form.Â  Dr. Kammer wrote: â€œThis employee has been unable to work since January â€˜02 [and] will be able to return to full-duty work on possibly January â€™03.â€Â  Dr. Kammer further noted: â€œLight duty only.Â  May not lift or carry more than thirty pounds (30 lbs.).Â  Will reassess patient in Decemberâ€™02.â€Â  On the same form, Duke noted a fifty pound lifting requirement and indicated no light duty work was available.
Johnson was on light duty and Santee Cooper offered no employment within Johnsonâ€™s restrictions.Â  Santee Cooper contends, notwithstanding its failure to offer suitable employment, that â€œ[h]aving failed to make any effort to secure employment, [Johnson] cannot satisfy his burden of proof that he is entitled to any temporary disability compensation.â€Â  This assertion is meritless.
The Workersâ€™ Compensation Act provides that the employer must either offer suitable employment within the injured workerâ€™s capacity, or pay temporary total disability compensation.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-190 (1985); Last v. MSI Constr. Co., 305 S.C. 349, 409 S.E.2d 334 (1991).Â  An employer is required to pay temporary compensation â€œ[w]hen the incapacity for work resulting from an injury is total.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-10 (Supp. 2005).Â  The term â€œdisabilityâ€ is defined as â€œincapacity because of injury to earn the wages which the employee was receiving at the time of injury in the same or any other employment.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-120 (1985).Â  â€œDisability is presumed to continue until the employee returns to work.â€Â  25A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 67-502(B)(2) (Supp. 2005); 25A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 67-506(A) (Supp. 2005).Â  Temporary total disability benefits are available up until the date of maximum medical improvement.Â  See Hendricks v. Pickens County, 335 S.C. 405, 517 S.E.2d 698 (Ct. App. 1999).
Per Dr. Kammer, Johnson was disabled from his job at Santee Cooper until December 18, 2002, when Dr. Kammer released him at maximum medical improvement.Â  Santee Cooper offered no suitable employment within Johnsonâ€™s capacity.Â  Because he was still disabled due to his injury, Johnson was entitled to temporary compensation until he reached maximum medical improvement.
The appellate panel correctly awarded temporary total disability when Johnson was completely out of work and then temporary partial disability when Johnson returned to his part-time job at Rickenbaker Cotton Gin.
Conclusion
Accordingly, we
AFFIRM.
HEARN, C.J., ANDERSON, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Ex Parte: Safety National, Surety for South Carolina Bonding Company Surety, Appellant,
        In Re: State of South Carolina, Respondent,
        v.
        Abdul Dunham, Defendant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Edward W. Miller, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-082
Submitted February 1, 2006 â€“ Filed February 10, 2006Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        David Lloyd Thomas, of Greenville, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia, and Solicitor Robert Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this bond estreatment case, Safety National, Surety for South Carolina Bonding Company (Safety National), appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order finding that Abdul Dunham violated the terms of his bond and ordering a partial estreatment of the bond to the State.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Dunham was arrested and charged with trafficking in crack cocaine and possession with intent to distribute marijuana.Â  Shortly thereafter, Dunham was released from custody when the South Carolina Bonding Company signed a $65,000 surety bond on September 30, 2002.Â  
On May 12, 2003, the circuit court issued a bench warrant for Dunhamâ€™s arrest when, after proper notice, he failed to appear in court on that date.Â  On June 10, 2003, the circuit court issued a conditional order to estreat Dunhamâ€™s bond unless the South Carolina Bonding Company appeared on July 11, 2003, to show cause why the bond should not be remitted in whole or in part.Â  At the hearing, Dunhamâ€™s counsel claimed that Dunham, who lived in New Jersey, did not appear in court on the scheduled date because he did not receive a roll call notification card until after he was supposed to appear.Â  Counsel further explained that three days later, on May 15, 2003, Dunham appeared in court for another scheduled roll call.Â  Based on these circumstances, counsel argued that Dunham had complied with the conditions of his bond and, thus, the bond should not be estreated.
At the conclusion of the hearing, the circuit court ordered that $20,000 of the bond be estreated to the State on the ground Dunham failed to comply with the conditions of the bond.Â  This appeal followed.
DISCUSSION
Safety National asserts the circuit court erred in confirming a partial estreatment of Dunhamâ€™s bond against the South Carolina Bonding Company.Â  In support of this assertion, Safety National argues the circuit court failed to consider the requisite factors before reaching its decision.Â  Additionally, Safety National contends that Dunhamâ€™s failure to appear at a single roll call was insignificant given Dunham appeared three days later and the only cost incurred by the State in this case was the issuance of a bench warrant.Â Â  
Section 38-53-70 of the South Carolina Code outlines the procedure governing bond forfeitures.Â  This section provides:

  If a defendant fails to appear at a court proceeding to which he has been summoned, the court must issue a bench warrant for the defendant.Â  If the surety fails to surrender the defendant or place a hold on the defendantâ€™s release from incarceration, commitment, or institutionalization within thirty days of the issuance of the bench warrant, the bond shall be forfeited.Â  At any time before execution is issued on a judgment of forfeiture against a defendant or his surety, the court may direct that the judgment be remitted in whole or in part, upon conditions as the court may impose, if it appears that justice requires the remission of part or all of the judgment.Â  In making a determination as to remission of the judgment, the court shall consider the costs to the State or any county or municipality resulting from the necessity to continue or terminate the defendantâ€™s trial and the efforts of law enforcement officers or agencies to locate the defendant.Â  The court in its discretion may permit the surety to pay the estreatment in installments for a period of up to six months . . . . If at any time during the period in which installments are to be paid the defendant is surrendered to the appropriate detention facility and the surety complies with the re-commitment procedures, the surety is relieved of any further liability.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-53-70 (Supp. 2005).
â€œThe issue of whether a bond forfeiture should be remitted, and if so, to what extent, is vested in the discretion of the trial judge.â€Â  Ex parte Polk, 354 S.C. 8, 11, 579 S.E.2d 329, 330 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  â€œ[T]he exercise of that discretion by the trial judge will not be set aside unless it is made to appear that it was abused.â€Â  State v. Holloway, 262 S.C. 552, 555, 206 S.E.2d 822, 823 (1974).Â  â€œAmong the factors to be considered in determining whether and to what extent relief will be granted are (1) the purpose of the bond; (2) the nature and wilfulness of the default; [and] (3) any prejudice or additional expense resulting to the State.â€Â  State v. Workman, 274 S.C. 341, 343, 263 S.E.2d 865, 866 (1980).
We find the circuit court did not abuse its discretion in ordering a partial estreatment of Dunhamâ€™s bond.Â  Dunhamâ€™s release on bond was conditioned upon his appearance in court on the dates set by the State.Â  Although Dunhamâ€™s counsel claimed Dunham appeared in court on May 15, 2003, this appearance was three days after the scheduled date of May 12, 2003.Â  Because Dunham failed to appear on the scheduled date, he violated a condition of his bond.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-15-20 (2003) (â€œEvery appearance recognizance or appearance bond will be conditioned on the person charged personally appearing before the court specified to answer the charge or indictment and to do and receive what shall be enjoined by the court, and not to depart the State, and to be of good behavior toward all the citizens thereof, or especially toward any person or persons specified by the court.â€).
As a result of Dunhamâ€™s default, Safety National became liable and, in turn, subject to forfeiture of the bond.Â  See Pride v. Anders, 266 S.C. 338, 341, 223 S.E.2d 184, 186 (1976) (â€œ[T]he obligation of appellant-surety was not to the State to produce defendants at the time to be later set, but was rather an obligation to answer, to the extent of the penalty, for the default of the defendants, as principals, in the event they did not appear on the date set for trial.Â  When the defendants defaulted by their failure to appear, the liability of the appellant, as surety, became fixed.â€); Ex parte Polk, 354 S.C. at 11, 579 S.E.2d at 330 (â€œAs guarantor, the surety on an appearance bond undertakes the risk of forfeiture in the event the defendant does not appear for trial.â€).
The question then becomes to what extent relief should have been granted due to the default.Â  Despite the circuit courtâ€™s failure to specifically enunciate either orally or in its written order the requisite factors, we find the court properly exercised its discretion in partially estreating the bond.Â  We believe implicit in the courtâ€™s ruling was a consideration of the factors.Â  First, Dunhamâ€™s failure to appear at the scheduled date or at the hearing date violated the purpose of the appearance bond.Â  Secondly, Safety National offered no explanation as to why Dunham was not transported from New Jersey to South Carolina on the date of the bond estreatment hearing.Â  Finally, we reject Safety Nationalâ€™s assertion that the State was not prejudiced by Dunhamâ€™s failure to appear at a single roll call.Â Â  Dunhamâ€™s failure to appear on May 12, 2003, in conjunction with Safety National failure to present Dunham at the hearing, created a delay for the State sufficient to constitute prejudice.Â  Holloway, 262 S.C. at 557, 206 S.E.2d at 824 (â€œCertainly, prejudice to the State appears when a defendant, without excuse, fails to appear at the time set for trial, thereby obstructing and delaying the orderly administration of justice.â€).Â  Furthermore, given the circuit court only estreated $20,000 of the $65,000 bond, we find the amount estreated was not so excessive to constitute an abuse of discretion.
Accordingly, the order of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED.
BEATTY, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Tarrie J. Powell, Respondent,
        v.
        Talbots, Inc., and Travelers Indemnity Company, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â J. Mark Hayes, II, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-083
Submitted February 1, 2006 â€“ Filed February 10, 2006Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Byron P. Roberts, Tally & Roberts, LLC, of Columbia, for Appellants.
        A. Parker Barnes, Jr., A. Parker Barnes, Jr. & Assoc., of Beaufort, Andrew Nathan Safran, Andrew N. Safran, LLC, of Columbia, Ann McCrowey Mickle, Law Offices of Ann McCrowey Mickle, of Rock Hill, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this workersâ€™ compensation action, the single commissioner and an appellate panel of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission determined that the employer did not offer, and claimant did not refuse, suitable employment.Â  The circuit court affirmed.Â  Appellants argue to us that there exists substantial evidence to support their position that claimant failed to respond to the employerâ€™s offer of employment, rendering her ineligible to receive further compensation.Â  We affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR.[1]Â  
1.  Appellants misapprehend the applicable standard of review in an appeal from the Commission.Â  This case presents the typical factual dispute where evidence could be reasonably interpreted to support the position of either party.Â  In such circumstances, the factfinderâ€”the Commissionâ€”must make the decision.Â  Jones v. Georgia-Pacific Corp., 355 S.C. 413, 417, 586 S.E.2d 111, 113 (2003) (â€œSubstantial evidence is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion that the administrative agency reached to justify its action.â€ (quoting Howell v. Pacific Columbia Mills, 291 S.C. 469, 354 S.E.2d 384 (1987))).Â  Thus, the mere presence of some evidence supporting the position of an appellant does not entitle the appellant to a reversal of the Commissionâ€™s decision.Â  It is the absence of substantial evidence supporting the Commissionâ€™s decision that entitles an appellant to relief.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 135, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981) (finding that the Commissionâ€™s decision will not be overturned unless unsupported by substantial evidence). 
2.   We have reviewed the record and conclude substantial evidence supports the Commissionâ€™s determination that the employer failed to establish that it offered suitable employment to the claimant.
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., ANDERSON, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1] Â Â We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Caroline C. McKee, Respondent,
        v.
        Jesse C. Brown, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lexington County
Â Clyde N. Davis, Jr., Master-in-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-084
Submitted February 1, 2006 â€“ Filed February 10, 2006Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        James Randall Davis, of Lexington, for Appellant.
        Paul D. Harrill and Andrew G. Melling, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Appellant Jesse C. Brown appeals the Master-in-Equityâ€™s order declaring Respondent Caroline C. McKee the owner of a twenty-seven acre tract of land.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
This action involves a dispute between Brown and McKee over the ownership of a twenty-seven-acre tract of land in Lexington County.Â  The tract lies between Brownâ€™s and McKeeâ€™s properties.Â  Brownâ€™s land is north of the tract, and McKeeâ€™s parcel is to the south.Â  McKeeâ€™s land includes some 340 acres which she inherited from her parents in 1973.Â  Brown has sold his land with the exception of the twenty-seven acres which he claims.Â  
McKee commenced this action to quiet title claiming to be the legal owner of the parcel.Â  She additionally claimed the land through adverse possession and acquiescence.Â  The matter was referred to a Lexington County Master-in-Equity.Â  The master found that McKee was the record owner of the tract, and that even if Brown had ever owned the property, McKee had proven ownership by adverse possession and acquiescence.Â  
McKee presented documentation dating back to 1929 which demonstrated her predecessors in title divided the property she now owns into four tracts.Â  The northern-most of the four tracts was a fifty-acre parcel which borders Brownâ€™s land.Â  The deeds refer to a family home place, or â€œold dwelling,â€ situated approximately 200 yards from a family cemetery.Â  McKee and witness Franklin Corley each testified that their uncle, O.C. Crout, lived in the home place in the 1930s and 1940s.Â  Both McKee and Corley remembered visiting their uncle at the home place.Â Â Â  
McKee entered into evidence a plat worksheet from 1929 which references the 1929 deed that conveyed the fifty-acre parcel from Sarah Crout to O.C. Crout.Â  Grover and Gladys Corley purchased the 340 acres, which included the disputed parcel, in 1948.Â  In 1969, Grover Corley leased the home place and surrounding property to a motorcycle club. Â After the land passed to McKee, she employed Westvaco, Inc. to plant, grow, and harvest timber on the disputed tract.Â  In 1978, Westvaco clear cut the twenty-seven acres and planted six-inch seedling pine trees.Â  
A deed in Brownâ€™s chain of title lists the property as consisting of 139 acres and belonging to Thad Shealy.Â  In 1949, Shealy conveyed 157 acres to J. Collie Amick, ostensibly selling more land than he had received.Â  The 1949 plat states that it copies a 1920 plat, yet it inexplicably changes the southern boundary of the 139-acre parcel, increasing the tract to 157 acres.Â  All deeds after 1949 refer to Brownâ€™s tract as consisting of 157 acres.
Brown and McKee are both in their late 60s or early 70s, and they both grew up around the property in question.Â  As long as either party can recall, a fence has existed along the northern boundary of the twenty-seven acres and the southern boundary of Brownâ€™s land.Â  Brown subdivided and sold all of his property north of the fence prior to this lawsuit.Â  However, heÂ  never attempted to subdivide or sell the disputed tract. Indeed, McKee introduced the deeds and surveys showing that Brown has sold over 150 acres of his property.Â  
The property in question has been surveyed numerous times throughout the years.Â  In 1988 George Todd performed a survey of McKeeâ€™s land and provided her with a plat.Â  Todd discovered a discrepancy in the tax maps, which indicated Brown owned the twenty-seven acre tract.Â  
Subsequently, Brown hired Mike Arant to survey the disputed tract.Â  Arant testified that Brown directed him to prepare a survey of a specific tax map parcel; he was not asked to research ownership issues.Â  In performing the survey, Arant placed two markers along the southern boundary of the disputed parcel.Â  He then discovered a survey which indicated McKeeâ€™s father, Grover Corley, was the owner of the twenty-seven acres.Â  Arant testified that he determined McKee was the rightful owner of the property, and upon informing Brown of his discovery, Arant was told not to complete his survey.Â  Arant did not remove the two markers which he claims he erroneously placed along the southern boundary.Â  
In 2001, McKee hired Cobb to survey her property.Â  Cobb did not utilize the deeds given to McKee or Brown, and he did not refer to the 1920 survey of Brownâ€™s property or the 1929 survey of McKeeâ€™s land.Â  Cobb relied on the property markers erroneously placed by Arant.Â  Ultimately he redrew the tax map, omitting the home place from McKeeâ€™s property and leaving her with 308 acres.Â  McKee disagreed with Cobbâ€™s survey and commenced this action against Brown.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Initially, Brown asserts this is an appeal from an equitable action and that this Court may find facts in accordance with our own view of the evidence.Â  We disagree.
The instant case involves an action at law, not equity.Â  As stated by this Court in Eldridge v. City of Greenwood, 331 S.C. 398, 416, 503 S.E.2d 191, 200 (Ct. App. 1998), â€œWhile an action to quiet title is usually one in equity, the main purpose of the complaint determines the character of the action.â€Â  â€œThe determination of title to real property is a legal issue.â€Â Â  Wigfall v. Fobbs, 259 S.C. 59, 367 S.E.2d 156 (1988) (citing May v. Jeter, 245 S.C. 529, 141 S.E.2d 655 (1965); Capell v. Moses, 36 S.C. 559, 15 S.E. 711 (1892)); see also Eldridge, 331 S.C. 398, 503 S.E.2d 191.Â  â€œTherefore, in a case tried without a jury, the factual findings of a judge regarding title will not be disturbed on appeal unless found to be without evidence which reasonably supports the judgeâ€™s findings.â€Â  Wigfall at 60-61, 367 S.E.2d at 157; see also Townes Assâ€™n v. The City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976) (â€œIn an action at law, on appeal of a case tried without a jury, the findings of fact of the judge will not be disturbed upon appeal unless found to be without evidence which reasonably supports the judgeâ€™s findings.â€).
 Accordingly, our inquiry is limited whether the evidence reasonably supports the masterâ€™s findings.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Title
McKee presented evidence that she inherited 340 acres from her parents.Â  Absent the disputed tract, she would be left with only 308 acres.Â  Brownâ€™s chain of title, in contrast, reveals that Thad Shealy was deeded 139 acres and later conveyed the identical tract which inexplicably contained 157 acres rather than 139.Â  The survey performed by Todd establishes McKee as the owner of the tract.Â  The survey by Arant was not completed, and Arantâ€™s error in placing survey markers causedÂ  Cobbâ€™s survey to go awry.Â  
Furthermore, the evidence showed that the home place was referenced in McKeeâ€™s chain of title, was occupied and leased by McKeeâ€™s ancestors, and was located on the twenty-seven acres.Â  Due to an apparent error in the tax assessors office, both partiesâ€™ paid taxes on the land.Â  Therefore, the payment of taxes does not help either partyâ€™s claim.Â  The evidence amply supports the masterâ€™s ruling that McKee is the legal owner of the disputed tract.
Adverse Possession
The master found that in addition to her claim by chain of title, McKee had proved ownership by adverse possession both under color of title and by demonstrating proof of actual, open, notorious, hostile, continuous, and exclusive possession of the property for the statutory period. Â 
Pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-67-220 (1976), 

  Whenever it shall appear (a) that the occupant or those under whom he claims entered into possession of premises under claim of title, exclusive of any other right, founding such a claim upon a written instrument as being a conveyance of the premises in question or upon the decree or judgment of a competent court and (b) that there has been a continued occupation and possession of the premises, or of some part of such premises, including in such instrument, decree or judgment under such claim for ten years, the premises so included shall be deemed to have been held adversely[.]

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-67-220 (1976).
McKee established through her chain of title that, at the very least, she possessed the land by color of title.Â  She further demonstrated continued occupation of the land for at least ten years.Â  McKee has been harvesting and growing trees on the twenty-seven acres since 1982.Â  Under section 15-67-230, â€œland shall be deemed to have been possessed and occupied . . . when it has been usually cultivated or improved.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-67-230 (1976).Â  Therefore, having met both (a) and (b) of section 15-67-220, â€œthe premises so included shall be deemed to have been held adversely.â€Â  
In addition, the master detailed evidence of actual, open, notorious, hostile, continuous, and exclusive possession by McKee for ten years or more.Â  See Miller v. Leaird, 307 S.C. 56, 413 S.E.2d 841 (1992) (outlining the elements of adverse possession).Â  Brown and another witness testified they planted trees on the tract in 1958.Â  However, any claim of adverse possession by Brown fails to survive McKeeâ€™s use of the land since 1982.Â  Thus, the evidence reasonably supports the masterâ€™s findings. 
Acquiescence
Finally, the master ruled that if Brown ever had owned the disputed tract, McKee proved her acquiescence claim, which was pled in the alternative.Â  
Knox v. Bogan, 322 S.C. 64, 71-72, 472 S.E.2d 43, 47 (Ct. App. 1996), provides:

  It is well established that if adjoining landowners occupy their respective premises up to a certain line which they mutually recognize and acquiesce in for a long period of timeâ€”usually the time prescribed by the statute of limitationsâ€”they are precluded from claiming that the boundary line thus recognized and acquiesced in is not the true one.Â  In other words, such recognition of, and acquiescence in, a line as the true boundary line, if continued for a sufficient length of time, will afford a conclusive presumption that the line thus acquiesced in is the true boundary line.

Evidence established that both McKee and Brown treated the fence line as the true property boundary for more than ten years.Â  Moreover, Brown subdivided and sold all of his property up to the fence line.Â  McKee clear cut the land and planted trees with no objection by Brown.Â  This evidence reasonably supports the masterâ€™s finding that the parties treated the fence line as the boundary.Â  
CONCLUSION
 
The record contains sufficient evidence to support the masterâ€™s findings of fact.Â  Accordingly, the masterâ€™s order is 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., ANDERSON, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
