THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Fatima Shaikh, Appellant,
        v.
        State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Company, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-086
Submitted December 1, 2005 â€“ Filed February 10, 2006Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Eric Holcombe Philpot, of Greenville, for Appellant.
        William W. Kehl, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This is an appeal from an order of the trial court granting summary judgment to State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Company (State Farm), and denying summary judgment to Fatima Shaikh.Â  The trial court found Shaikh was not entitled to $25,000 in personal injury protection (PIP) from her motherâ€™s State Farm automobile insurance policy because her injury was precluded by an unambiguously other owned vehicle exclusion in that policy.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
FACTS
On September 18, 2003, Shaikh was severely injured in an automobile accident while driving her 2000 Honda CR-V.[2]Â  The adverse driverâ€™s insurer paid Shaikh the policy limits of $50,000.Â  Because Shaikhâ€™s medical expenses and lost wages exceeded $86,000, she sought $25,000 in PIP from her motherâ€™s State Farm automobile insurance policy (the Policy).Â  Shaikh resided with her mother, but the Policy did not cover her Honda.Â  Rather, the Policy covered her motherâ€™s 1995 Ford Taurus, which was not involved in the accident.Â  
Shaikh made a claim for PIP coverage under the Policy, which State Farm denied.Â  State Farm argued her claim was precluded by a provision of the Policy that excluded PIP coverage for a resident relative injured while driving a vehicle owned by the resident relative but not covered under the Policy.Â  Shaikh disagreed, and brought a declaratory judgment action against State Farm.Â  Shaikh alleged she was entitled to the PIP coverage under the Policy, and her claim was not precluded by any provisions of the Policy.Â  State Farm answered, and both parties moved for summary judgment.Â  The trial court granted summary judgment to State Farm and denied summary judgment to Shaikh.Â  This appeal followed. Â Â  Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, the appellate court applies the same standard that governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  Pittman v. Grand Strand Entmâ€™t, 363 S.C. 531, 536, 611 S.E.2d 922, 925 (2005).Â  Summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Id.Â  On appeal, all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Id.Â  When a motion for summary judgment presents a question as to the meaning of a written contract, the question is one of law if the language employed by the contract is plain and unambiguous.Â  MCG Mgmt. of Charleston, Inc. v. Kinghorn Ins. Agency, 336 S.C. 542, 546, 520 S.E.2d 820, 822 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS 
Shaikh argues the trial court erred in granting summary judgment to State Farm, because the exclusion in the Policy does not unambiguously preclude her from recovering PIP coverage under the Policy.Â  We disagree.Â  
Insurance policies must conform to general rules of contract construction.Â  Coakley v. Horace Mann Ins. Co., 363 S.C. 147, 152, 609 S.E.2d 537, 540 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Accordingly, an insurance policy should be given its plain, ordinary, and popular meaning.Â  Id.Â  The meaning should not be tortured to allow for coverage that was not intended by the parties.Â  Id.Â  Thus, an unambiguous policy must be construed according to the terms used by the parties.Â  Century Indem. Co. v. Golden Hills Builders, Inc., 348 S.C. 559, 565, 561 S.E.2d 355, 358 (2002).Â  However, an ambiguous policy must be â€œconstrued liberally in favor of the insured and strictly against the insurer.â€Â  Diamond State Ins. Co. v. Homestead Indus., Inc., 318 S.C. 231, 236, 456 S.E.2d 912, 915 (1995).Â  In construing an insurance policy, all of its provisions must be considered together and â€œread as a whole, giving appropriate weight to all provisions.â€Â  Yarborough v. Phoenix Mut. Life Ins. Co., 266 S.C. 584, 592, 225 S.E.2d 344, 349 (1976).Â  Therefore, courts should consider the entire policy to determine the meaning of its provisions; the construction that reasonably gives effect to the whole instrument and each of its various parts will be adopted.Â  MCG Mgmt. of Charleston, Inc. v. Kinghorn Ins. Agency, 336 S.C. 542, 548, 520 S.E.2d 820, 823 (Ct. App. 1999). Â 
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  In South Carolina, PIP coverage is not statutorily mandated, and may be excluded by insurance carriers.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-144 (2002); Smith v. Liberty Mut. Ins. Co., 313 S.C. 236, 239, 437 S.E.2d 142, 144 (Ct. App. 1993) (â€œSouth Carolina does not require any PIP coverage under its automobile insurance laws and has no public policy regarding such coverage.â€).Â  The provision at the center of this dispute is one such PIP coverage exclusion.Â  The provision states:

  
    What Is Not Covered Under [PIP]
    THERE IS NO COVERAGE . . . 
    FOR BODILY INJURY . . .Â  
    SUSTAINED WHILE OCCUPYING OR THROUGH BEING STRUCK BY A VEHICLE OWNED BY OR LEASED TO YOU, YOUR SPOUSE OR ANY RELATIVE, WHICH IS NOT INSURED FOR THIS COVERAGE UNDER THIS POLICY . . . .
  

The relevant portion of this provision is â€œthere is no coverage . . . for bodily injury sustained while occupying . . . a vehicle owned by . . . any relative, which is not insured for [PIP] coverage under [the Policy].â€Â  
We find this provision unambiguously excludes PIP coverage for a resident relative who is injured while driving a vehicle owned by a resident relative but not covered by the insurance policy offering the PIP coverage.Â  We must consider this provision as it applies to Shaikh.Â  First, because Shaikh resided with her mother, she was a resident relative under the Policy.Â  Second, because Shaikh was injured while driving her Honda, she sustained bodily injury while occupying a vehicle not covered by the Policy.Â  The Policy insured her motherâ€™s Ford, not Shaikhâ€™s Honda, as evidenced by the fact that the Ford was described on the declarations page of the Policy, while the Honda was not.Â  Consequently, Shaikh falls under the exclusionary provision, and is not entitled to the $25,000 in PIP coverage under the Policy.Â  
The order of the trial court is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  Shaikhâ€™s Honda was insured by Interstate Indemnity Company.Â  Her policy with Interstate Indemnity Company did not provide PIP coverage.Â

title: State v. Rivera
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
John J. Rivera, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Edward W. Miller, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-087
Heard November 9, 2006 â€“ Filed February 10, 2006

 
AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Jessica Ann Salvini, of Greenville; for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville; for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  John J. Rivera appeals his conviction for criminal sexual conduct (CSC) with a minor, first degree.Â  He contends the trial court erred in:Â  (1) denying his motion to sever the two indictments charging him with CSC with a minor, first degree, and lewd act upon a child; (2) denying one of his voir dire requests; (3) admitting certain testimony of three State witnesses; and (4) denying his motion for a mistrial.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Since June of 1998, the victim lived with her mother, Melissa Gail Duncan, and her younger brother in Greenville, South Carolina.Â  The victim has a learning disability, and at the time of trial, she was ten years old.Â  Mrs. Duncan is still married to the victimâ€™s father, Brad Duncan, and he sporadically lived with the family over this time frame.Â Â  
Mrs. Duncan has been a waitress at Waffle House since December of 1998, and it was while working that she met John Rivera.Â  Rivera was already a regular Waffle House customer when Mrs. Duncan began working, and the two of them quickly began a friendly relationship.Â  During a time of separation between Mr. and Mrs. Duncan, Mrs. Duncan began a romantic relationship with Rivera in April of 2000.Â  In May of 2000, Rivera moved into Mrs. Duncanâ€™s mobile home and lived there with the family until January of 2001 when the couple amicably ended their relationship.Â  During the time of their relationship, Rivera watched the children while Mrs. Duncan worked, and no problems were reported to, or observed by, Mrs. Duncan.Â  
Beginning in February of 2001, Mrs. Duncan hired Margaret Hunter to baby-sit her children while she was at work.Â  In July of 2001, Mrs. Duncan and Rivera reconciled and began seeing each other again.Â  On July 31, 2001, Rivera, Mrs. Duncan, the victim, and her brother went to Stone Mountain, Georgia.Â  Due to the late hour of their return from this trip, everyone stayed at Riveraâ€™s house in Travelers Rest, South Carolina. Rivera watched the children while Mrs. Duncan worked the following day.Â  
On August 4, 2001, Hunter baby-sat the victim while Mrs. Duncan worked.Â  The victim told Hunter that Rivera had been abusing her because, as she testified at trial: â€œ[M]y private part . . . was hurting so bad that I told her what was the matter.â€Â  When Mrs. Duncan arrived to pick up her daughter, Hunter instructed the victim to tell Mrs. Duncan about the abuse.Â  The victim explained that on multiple occasions Rivera had made her take off her clothes, fondled her, forced her to fondle him, and forced both oral and vaginal sex.Â  She also informed Mrs. Duncan that Rivera: â€œ[P]ut white stuff all over me,â€ and the white stuff was â€œfrom his private part down there.â€Â  The victim further stated that Rivera had shown her pornographic pictures on the internet, and asked her if she wanted to perform similar acts.Â  
Mrs. Duncan took her daughter to the hospital emergency room, but no examination was performed because too much time had elapsed since the last alleged abuse.Â  The hospital called the Travelers Rest Police Department, which referred Mrs. Duncan to the Child Advocacy Center.Â  On August 14, 2001, the victim was examined and interviewed at the Child Advocacy Center and also began receiving counseling.Â  Subsequently, the victim was interviewed by the Greenville County Sheriffâ€™s Office on October 16, 2001.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Ultimately, a Greenville County grand jury indicted Rivera for CSC with a minor, first degree, and committing a lewd act upon a child.Â  After the jury found Rivera guilty of both charges, the trial court sentenced him to eighteen years imprisonment.[1]Â  This appeal followed.
DISCUSSION
I.Â  Severance of the Trial
Rivera argues the trial court erred when it refused to sever the indictments against him into two separate trials.Â  Specifically, he contends that consolidation of the two indictments was improper because the alleged sexual misconduct took place on different occasions and possibly in different places.Â  We disagree.
A motion for severance is addressed to the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  State v. Tucker, 324 S.C. 155, 164, 478 S.E.2d 260, 265 (1996); State v. Simmons, 352 S.C. 342, 350, 573 S.E.2d 856, 860 (Ct. App. 2002). The courtâ€™s ruling will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of that discretion.Â  Tucker, 324 S.C. at 164, 478 S.E.2d at 265; Simmons, 352 S.C. at 350, 573 S.E.2d at 860. 
Where the offenses charged in separate indictments are of the same general nature involving connected transactions closely related in kind, place and character, the trial court has the power, in its discretion, to order the indictments tried together if the defendantâ€™s substantive rights would not
be prejudiced.Â  State v. Jones, 325 S.C. 310, 315, 479 S.E.2d 517, 519, (Ct. App. 1996); Simmons, 352 S.C. at 350, 573 S.E.2d at 860.Â  â€œFurther, joinder of offenses in one trial is â€˜proper if the offenses (1) are of the same general nature or character and spring from the same series of transactions, (2) are committed by the same offender, and (3) require the same or similar proof.â€™â€ Simmons, 352 S.C. at 351, 573 S.E.2d at 861 (quoting State v. Carter, 324 S.C. 383, 386, 478 S.E.2d 86, 88 (Ct. App. 1996)).Â  â€œ[O]ffenses are considered to be of the same general nature where they are interconnected.â€Â  Simmons, 352 S.C. at 350, 573 S.E.2d at 860.
Applying the foregoing to the facts of this case, we find the joinder of the two offenses was proper.Â  The two indictments levied against Rivera, CSC with a minor, first degree, and committing a lewd act upon a child, are of the same general nature in that they are interconnected.Â  They arose from an on-going series of events in a pattern of sexual abuse, i.e., â€œa single criminal course of conduct.â€Â  City of Greenville v. Chapman, 210 S.C. 157, 161, 41 S.E.2d 865, 867 (1947).Â  Moreover, these acts were committed by the same offender and were proved by the same evidence and witnesses.Â  Finally, we discern no evidence in the record that any right of Rivera was prejudiced by the consolidation of these indictments.Â  Accordingly, the trial court did not abuse its discretion in declining to sever the indictments.
II.Â  Voir Dire
Rivera contends the trial court erred in denying his request to voir dire the potential jury panel as to their personal beliefs regarding whether or not a minor child could make up a story of sexual abuse without having experienced it.Â  We disagree.
â€œIn general, the scope of voir dire and the manner in which it is conducted are within the trial judgeâ€™s sound discretion.Â  To constitute reversible error, a limitation on questioning must render the trial â€˜fundamentally unfair.â€™â€ State
v. Hill, 361 S.C. 297, 308, 604 S.E.2d 696, 702 (2004), cert. denied, 125 S. Ct. 1977 (2005) (citations omitted).Â  Our supreme court has stated:

A juror should not, prior to trial, be required to assert which witnesses he will believe nor what type of witness he will believe. This is true because a juror should believe those witnesses whose credibility appeal to him after he has heard all of the testimony.Â  The question invades the province of the jury to determine individual credibility in the context of the entire case.Â  

State v. Adams, 279 S.C. 228, 235, 306 S.E.2d 208, 212 (1983), overruled, in part, on other grounds by State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 406 S.E.2d 315 (1991). 
During voir dire, Rivera submitted three questions for the court to ask the jury.Â  The court agreed to question the jury on all but the following request:Â  â€œIs there any member of the jury panel who does not believe a child could make up a story of sexual abuse without having experienced it?â€Â  
We find the trial court did not abuse its discretion in refusing to submit this question to the jury.Â  In declining the request, the court properly exercised its discretion in that it questioned the jury with two of Riveraâ€™s other requests.Â  Furthermore, we believe, as did the trial court, that the question at issue invaded the province of the jury on a credibility question.Â  Thus, we find the courtâ€™s limitation of Riveraâ€™s questions did not render the trial â€œfundamentally unfair.â€
III.Â  Admissibility of Evidence
Rivera asserts the trial court erred when it admitted the testimony of State witnesses pursuant to hearsay exceptions to the South Carolina Rules of Evidence.Â  We disagree.Â  
â€œThe admission or exclusion of evidence is within the discretion of the trial court and will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of that discretion.â€Â 
State v. Foster, 354 S.C. 614, 620-21, 582 S.E.2d 426, 429 (2003). â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when the trial courtâ€™s ruling is based on an error of law.â€Â  Id. at 621, 582 S.E.2d at 429.Â  To warrant reversal, an appellant must show not only an alleged error, but also resulting prejudice.Â  State v. Fulton, 333 S.C. 359, 363-64, 509 S.E.2d 819, 821 (Ct. App. 1998).

A.Â  Â Â Â  Admissibility of Testimony Pursuant to South Carolina Rule of Evidence 801(d)(1)(B)

Rivera contends the trial court erred, when pursuant to Rule 801(d)(1)(B), SCRE, it admitted the testimony of two State witnesses, Sandy Fehrman and Ty Bracken, regarding the victimâ€™s prior consistent statements.Â  We disagree.
Under the hearsay exception noted in Rule 801(d)(1)(D), SCRE, a corroborating witnessâ€™s testimony in a criminal sexual conduct case is generally limited to the time and place of the incident.Â Â  However, an alternate exception noted in Rule 801(d)(1)(B) states: 

A statement is not hearsay if . . . [t]he declarant testifies at the trial or hearing and is subject to cross-examination concerning the statement, and the statement is consistent with the declarantâ€™s testimony and is offered to rebut an express or implied charge against the declarant of recent fabrication or improper influence or motive; provided, however, the statement must have been made before the alleged fabrication, or before the alleged improper influence or motive arose.

The declarant, the victim in this case, testified, and Rivera cross- examined her by stating: 

  
    
      
        Q:
         And did you talk about what you talked about today with Sandy
          [Fehrman]?
      
      
        A:
         Yes.
      
      
        Q: 
         Okay.Â  And did she help you get ready to talk today?
      
      
        A:
         Yes.
      
      
        Q:
         Okay.Â  And do you know the police ladyâ€™s name?Â 
          [Ty Bracken]
      
      
        A: 
         I forgot.
      
      
        Q: 
         Okay.Â  Did she help you to get ready to talk today?
      
      
        A: 
         Yes.
      
      
        Q:  
         Okay.Â  And did you â€“ did she talk to you about what you talked about a lot today?
      
      
        A:
         Yes.
      
      
        
         . . .
      
      
        Q:
         Okay.Â  [Name of victim], did a lot of people talk to you to tell you how to talk today?
      
      
        A:  
         Yes.
      
    
  

The trial court found this line of questioning clearly implied that there had been a recent fabrication and, therefore, the door had been opened to the 801(d)(1)(B) hearsay exception.Â  

In discussing Rule 801(d)(1)(B), our supreme court has stated: 
  
The plain language of Rule 801(d)(1)(B) only permits evidence of a prior consistent statement when the witness has been charged with recent fabrication or improper motive or influence.Â  Although questioning a witness about a prior inconsistent statement does call the witnessâ€™s credibility into question, that is not the same as charging the witness with â€œrecent fabricationâ€ or â€œimproper influence or motive.â€ 
  

State v. Saltz, 346 S.C. 114, 124, 551 S.E.2d 240, 245 (2001)(quoting Rule 801(d)(1)(B), SCRE).Â  â€œ[E]vidence of a prior consistent statement is only permitted when the elements of Rule 801(d)(1)(B) are met.â€Â  Foster, 354 S.C. at 621, 582 S.E.2d at 430.Â  â€œThis rule renders a hearsay statement potentially admissible if it is consistent with the declarantâ€™s trial testimony and â€˜is offered to rebut an express or implied charge against the declarant of recent fabrication or improper influence or motive.â€™â€ State v. Jeffcoat, 350 S.C. 392, 396, 565 S.E.2d 321, 323 (Ct. App. 2002)(quoting Rule 801(d)(1)(B), SCRE).Â  â€œWhen all requirements of the rule are met, the whole of the prior statement, including specific details, is admissible in evidence.â€Â  Jeffcoat, 350 S.C. at 396, 565 S.E.2d at 323.
We agree with the trial courtâ€™s assessment that defense counselâ€™s cross-examination of the victim implied improper influence or coaching, particularly by asking the victim, â€œdid a lot of people talk to you to tell you how to talk todayâ€ as well as whether Fehrman and Bracken helped her â€œget ready to talk today.â€Â  Because defense counsel â€œopened the door,â€ we affirm the courtâ€™s decision to admit the witnessesâ€™ testimony pursuant to Rule 801(d)(1)(B).Â  See Jeffcoat, 350 S.C. at 397, 565 S.E.2d at 324 (affirming trial courtâ€™s decision to admit testimony of minor victimâ€™s mother and post-trauma therapistâ€™s testimony regarding victimâ€™s out-of-court statements concerning sexual abuse pursuant to Rule 801(d)(1)(B) where defense counsel â€œraised the issue of improper influence or â€˜coachingâ€™ by asking Victim whether she â€˜practicedâ€™ before testifying and whether anyone had told the Victim what to sayâ€); see also State v. Beam, 336 S.C. 45, 52, 518 S.E.2d 297, 301 (Ct. App. 1999) (â€œ[W]hen a party introduces evidence about a particular matter, the other party is entitled to explain it or rebut it, even if the latter evidence would have been incompetent or irrelevant had it been offered initially.â€).Â  Accordingly, we find no abuse of discretion by the trial court in allowing Fehrman and Bracken to testify to the victimâ€™s prior consistent statements.
Alternatively, Rivera contends if we find that his line of questioning â€œopened the doorâ€ to the above hearsay exception, the testimony of Bracken and Fehrman was still improper because it was not consistent with the declarantâ€™s testimony.Â  We disagree.
Bracken testified:Â  â€œShe [the victim] also stated that he had put her finger â€“ his finger in her crotch and touched me for a long time.â€Â  Rivera contends that this was inconsistent because the victim never testified to this fact.Â  Although Rivera generally raised the issue of consistency in a conference held outside of the jury, he did not specify which statements he felt would be inconsistent, and he made no objection to the consistency of either Brackenâ€™s or Fehrmanâ€™s testimony at the time their statements were offered.Â  Thus, we do not believe this issue is preserved for our review.Â  State v. Burton, 326 S.C. 605, 611-12, 486 S.E.2d 762, 765 (Ct. App. 1997) (recognizing that a ruling during an in camera hearing still requires losing party to renew his or her objection at trial when the evidence is presented in order to preserve the issue for appeal); see also State v. Johnson, 324 S.C. 38, 41, 476 S.E.2d 681, 682 (1996) (noting a contemporaneous objection is required at trial to preserve an issue for appellate review); State v. Hoffman, 312 S.C. 386, 393, 440 S.E.2d 869, 873 (1994) (stating an issue that is not properly preserved cannot be raised for the first time on appeal); State v. Black, 319 S.C. 515, 521-22, 462 S.E.2d 311, 315 (Ct. App. 1995) (stating failure to object when evidence is offered constitutes a waiver of the right to raise issue on appeal).
Even if this issue were preserved for appeal, we find any inconsistency in the testimony was harmless.Â  In light of the other testimony in the record that established the necessary elements for the crimes charged, there is no evidence that the defendant was prejudiced.Â  See State v. Whisonant, 335 S.C. 148, 156, 515 S.E.2d 768, 772 (Ct. App. 1999) (finding â€œ[a]n improper introduction of hearsay evidence constitutes reversible error only if its admission is prejudicial to the defendantâ€); State v. Reeves, 301 S.C. 191, 194, 391 S.E.2d 241, 243 (1990) (stating â€œ[e]rror is harmless when it could not reasonably have affected the result of the trialâ€).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

B.Â Â Â Â Â  Admissibility of Testimony Pursuant to South Carolina Rule of Evidence 803(4)

Rivera argues the trial court erred when pursuant to Rule 803(4), SCRE, it admitted the testimony of State witness, Dr. Nancy Henderson, regarding the victimâ€™s statements made to her during a medical examination.Â  Specifically, Rivera contends that because Dr. Henderson did not provide a diagnosis based on medical conclusions or a physical examination of the victim and relied exclusively on the victimâ€™s statements to her, there was no diagnosis made which would trigger this hearsay exception. We disagree.

The hearsay exception noted in Rule 803(4) states: 
  
The following are not excluded by the hearsay rule, even though the declarant is available as a witness:Â  Statements made for purposes of medical diagnosis or treatment and describing medical history, or past or present symptoms, pain, or sensations, or the inception or general character of the cause or external source thereof insofar as reasonably pertinent to diagnosis or treatment; provided, however, that the admissibility of statements made after commencement of the litigation is left to the courtâ€™s discretion.
  

Rule 803(4) requires only that the statements be provided for the purpose of medical diagnosis.Â  We agree with the trial court that the statements the victim provided to Dr. Henderson were for the purpose of diagnosis.Â  The victimâ€™s statements regarding how and when she was abused provided the doctor with specific areas to focus on, and specific conditions to search for when she performed the diagnostic physical exam.Â  Therefore, we find the trial court did not abuse its discretion in admitting this testimony.Â  See State v. Burroughs, 328 S.C. 489, 501, 492 S.E.2d 408, 414 (Ct. App. 1997) (â€œCertainly, a statement that the victim had been raped or that the assailant had hurt the victim in a particular area would be pertinent to the diagnosis and treatment of the victim.â€).Â Â Â  
Additionally, Rivera claims that Dr. Henderson testified to statements made to her by the victim that were not necessary for medical diagnosis.Â  Rivera cites the following statements:Â  â€œShe [the victim] also said that he [Rivera] put his finger on her chest.Â  And also that he wanted her to put her hand down his pants, but she didnâ€™t.â€Â  Rivera never made any objection to this testimony, and therefore, this issue is not preserved for appeal.Â  See Johnson, 324 S.C. at 41, 476 S.E.2d at 682 (noting a contemporaneous objection is required at trial to preserve an issue for appellate review); Black, 319 S.C. at 521-22, 462 S.E.2d at 315 (stating failure to object when evidence is offered constitutes a waiver of the right to raise issue on appeal).
IV.Â  Mistrial
Rivera contends the trial court erred in denying his motion for a mistrial resulting from the Stateâ€™s expert witness, Laurie Pinckney, revealing the name of the alleged perpetrator of the sexual abuse in violation of the trial courtâ€™s order.Â  We disagree.
The decision to grant or deny a mistrial is within the sound
discretion of the trial court.Â  State v. Vazsquez, 364 S.C. 293, 299, 613 S.E.2d 359, 362 (2005). Â â€œâ€˜The power of a court to declare a mistrial ought to be used with the greatest caution under urgent circumstances, and for very plain and obvious causesâ€™ stated into the record by the trial judge.â€Â  State v. Simmons, 352 S.C. 342, 354, 573 S.E.2d 856, 862 (Ct. App. 2002)(quoting State v. Kirby, 269 S.C. 25, 28-29, 236 S.E.2d 33, 34 (1977)).Â  â€œA mistrial should only be granted when â€˜absolutely necessary,â€™ and
a defendant must show both error and resulting prejudice in order to be entitled to a mistrial.â€Â  Simmons, 352 S.C. at 354, 573 S.E.2d at 862.Â  â€œA mistrial should be ordered only when an incident is so grievous that prejudicial effect cannot be removed.â€Â  Vazsquez, 364 S.C. at 299, 613 S.E.2d at 362.
Pinckney, by the courtâ€™s direction, was limited to discussing the alleged sexual assault in terms of time and place and was not permitted to identify Rivera.Â  Pinckney was questioned on direct examination and answered as follows:

  
    
      
        Q:
         And, again, pursuant to the Court rules, just answer very specifically.Â  Did she [the victim] tell you where she had been abused?
      
      
        A: 
         She stated that it was while her mom was â€“ while John [Rivera] was baby sitting her.
      
    
  

Rivera objected and the jury was removed from the courtroom. Rivera then moved for a mistrial.Â  The judge denied this motion, but did offer Rivera an opportunity to suggest a curative instruction.Â  Rivera suggested an instruction that was given to the jury.Â  Rivera did not object to the sufficiency of the instruction.[2]  
Because Rivera suggested and accepted the curative instruction, we find this issue is not preserved for appeal.Â  See State v. Moyd, 321 S.C. 256, 263, 468 S.E.2d 7, 11 (Ct. App. 1996) (stating if objecting party accepts ruling of trial court and does not contemporaneously object to sufficiency of curative instruction or move for mistrial, error deemed cured and issue not preserved for appellate review).Â  
CONCLUSION
We hold the trial court did not abuse its discretion in:Â  declining to sever the indictments; refusing Riveraâ€™s voir dire request; and admitting certain testimony under hearsay exceptions.Â  We also affirm the trial courtâ€™s denial of Riveraâ€™s motion for a mistrial.Â  Based on the foregoing, Riveraâ€™s conviction and sentence for CSC with a minor, first degree, are
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] Although the jury convicted Rivera of both charges, the trial court granted Riveraâ€™s motion to set aside the conviction for lewd act upon a child on the ground the State failed to prove every element of the charge.Â  Therefore, only the charge of CSC with a minor, first degree is at issue in this appeal.
[2] Rivera only submitted a specific curative instruction once his motion for mistrial was denied.Â

title: Meehan v. Meehan
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
John Thomas Meehan, Jr., Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Jerry Andrew Meehan, individually and as member of Lebanon Road, LLC; Robert N. Newton, individually and as member of Lebanon Road, LLC; James B. Rogers, individually and as member of Lebanon Road, LLC; A South Carolina Limited Liability Company; GrandSouth
Bancorporation; Mountainbank; and Janet Elizabeth Kelly Dorado, Defendants,
of whom Jerry Andrew Meehan, individually and as member of Lebanon Road, LLC; Robert N. Newton, individually and as member of Lebanon Road, LLC; James B. Rogers, individually and as member of Lebanon Road, LLC; A South Carolina Limited Liability Company; GrandSouth
Bancorporation; and Janet Elizabeth Kelly Dorado, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Anderson County
Â J. Cordell Maddox, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-088
Heard January 11, 2006 â€“ Filed February 10, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Robert Wallis Cone, of Greenwood, for Appellant.
D. Sean Faulkner, of Greenville, Harold P. Threlkeld and J. Calhoun Pruitt, Jr., of Anderson, for Respondents.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  John Thomas Meehan, Jr. appeals the circuit courtâ€™s dismissal of his action for lack of standing pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
The respondents, Jerry Andrew Meehan (Jerry) and Janet Elizabeth Kelly Dorado (Janet), and the appellant, John Thomas Meehan, Jr. (Meehan), are the children of Mary Meehan (Mother), who is not a party to this action.Â  Mother owned several large parcels of real estate located in Pendleton, South Carolina.Â  Two of those parcels, the Dickson Place tract and the Harris Place tract, are directly involved in this dispute.Â  The Dickson Place property contains approximately 115 acres and the Harris Place property consists of 70.2 acres.Â  In May of 1983, Mother conveyed fee simple title to Dickson Place to Jerry.Â  In 2003, Mother conveyed fee simple title to Harris Place to Jerry and Janet.Â  
In May 2003, Jerry conveyed his entire interest in Dickson Place plus an additional 18.6 acres to Lebanon Road, LLC, for the purchase price of $554,000.Â  Lebanon Road simultaneously granted GrandSouth Bank a first mortgage on the property acquired from Jerry.[1]Â  After mortgaging the Harris Place property, Jerry and Janet re-conveyed the property back to Mother who then sold the property to Robert Newton.Â  At no time did Meehan acquire an interest in either Dickson Place or Harris Place.
Meehan claims Mother made numerous verbal and written representations to him that he would receive Dickson Place as his sole property either during Motherâ€™s lifetime or upon her death.Â  Meehan relies on a 2001 letter in which Mother promised him Dickson Place.Â  He also claims Jerry and Janet mortgaged Harris Place against Motherâ€™s wishes.Â  According to Meehan, Mother stated that she wanted the Harris Place property to be divided equally between her three children.Â  
Meehan filed this action to set aside the deeds of conveyance to Jerry and Janet from Mother based on fraud, duress, and undue influence.Â  Meehan also sought a constructive trust for his benefit on Dickson Place and Harris Place because Mother promised or intended to convey an interest in both to him.Â  The circuit court dismissed, finding Meehan lacked the standing necessary to bring the actions.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Under Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, a defendant may move to dismiss based on a failure to state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action.Â  Flateau v. Harrelson, 355 S.C. 197, 201, 584 S.E.2d 413, 415 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  A trial judge may dismiss a claim when the defendant demonstrates the plaintiff has failed to state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action in the pleadings.Â  Williams v. Condon, 347 S.C. 227, 233, 553 S.E.2d 496, 500 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Generally, in considering a 12(b)(6) motion, the circuit court must base its ruling solely upon allegations set forth on the face of the complaint. Stiles v. Onorato, 318 S.C. 297, 300, 457 S.E.2d 601, 602-03 (1995).Â  Upon review of a dismissal of an action pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), the appellate court applies the same standard of review implemented by the circuit court.Â  Doe v. Marion, 361 S.C. 463, 470, 605 S.E.2d 556, 560 (Ct. App. 2004).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Meehan argues the circuit court erred in dismissing his action pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP.Â  Specifically, Meehan contends the circuit court erred in finding he lacked the standing necessary to maintain the action.[2]Â  We disagree.
To have standing, one must have a personal stake in the subject matter of the lawsuit; one must be a real party in interest. Â Charleston County Sch. Dist. v. Charleston County Election Commâ€™n, 336 S.C. 174, 181, 519 S.E.2d 567, 571 (1999).Â  â€œA real party in interest is one who has a real, material, or substantial interest in the subject matter of the action, as opposed to one who has only a nominal or technical interest in the action.â€Â  Anchor Point, Inc. v. Shoals Sewer Co., 308 S.C. 422, 428, 418 S.E.2d 546, 549 (1992).Â  A private person does not have standing unless he has sustained, or is in immediate danger of sustaining, prejudice from an executive or legislative action.Â  Baird v. Charleston County, 333 S.C. 519, 530, 511 S.E.2d 69, 75 (1999).Â  â€œSuch imminent prejudice must be of a personal nature to the party laying claim to standing and not merely of general interest common to all members of the public.â€Â  Id. at 530, 511 S.E.2d at 75 (citing Citizens for Lee County, Inc. v. Lee County, 308 S.C. 23, 416 S.E.2d 641 (1992)).Â  Moreover, the injury in fact cannot be a â€œprospective concern of future harm.â€Â  Beaufort Realty Co. v. S.C. Coastal Conservation League, 346 S.C. 298, 303, 551 S.E.2d 588, 590 (Ct. App. 2001).
In Sea Pines Association for Protection of Wildlife, Inc. v. South Carolina Department of Natural Resources, our supreme court set out the three â€œirreducible constitutional minimums of standing.â€Â  345 S.C. 594, 601, 550 S.E.2d 287, 291 (2001) (quoting Lujan v. Defenders of Wildlife, 504 U.S. 555, 559-61 (1992) (internal citations omitted)).Â  First, the plaintiff must have suffered an â€œinjury in fact.â€Â  The court defined â€œinjury in factâ€ as â€œan invasion of a legally protected interestâ€ which is â€œconcrete and particularizedâ€ and â€œactual or imminent,â€ not â€œconjectural or hypothetical.â€Â  Second, a causal connection must exist between the alleged injury and the conduct from which the plaintiff complains.Â  The injury must be â€œtraceable to the challenged action of the defendant,â€ and not â€œthe result of the independent action of some third party not before the court.â€Â  Third, it must be â€œlikelyâ€ rather than merely â€œspeculative,â€ that the injury will be â€œredressed by a favorable decision.â€Â  Id.Â  
Here, Meehan does not satisfy the â€œirreducible constitutional minimumâ€ of standing.Â  Meehan fails to satisfy both the first and second prongs of the Lujan test.Â  First, Meehan cannot establish an injury in fact.Â  Meehan admits he did not own the Dickson Place or Harris Place properties at the time Mother transferred them to Jerry and Janet.Â  Moreover, Meehan admits Mother did not own the properties at the time she wrote the 2001 letter in which she promised to devise Dickson Place to Meehan.Â  The only interest Meehan claims in the properties is the mere possibility that Mother might have given the Dickson Place property to him in the future.Â  Therefore, the mere expectancy or future interest in the properties fails to satisfy the Lujan requirement that the injury be â€œconcrete and particularizedâ€ and â€œactual or imminent,â€ not merely â€œconjectural or hypothetical.â€Â  
Second, Meehan fails to establish a causal connection between his alleged injury and the conduct of Jerry and Janet.Â  The injury complained of is that Jerry and Janet committed unlawful acts against a third partyâ€”Motherâ€” or that Mother conveyed the property to Meehanâ€™s siblings in contravention of the 2001 letter promising him the property.Â  Therefore, if Jerry and Janet committed the acts alleged by Meehan in his complaint, only Mother could seek redress for those tortious actions; or, in the alternative, because it was Mother who promised Meehan the property, he might have a claim against Mother, but not one against his siblings.Â  As a result, the injury Meehan complains of is merely the result of the independent action of some third party not before the court.Â  Because Meehan has not suffered an injury in fact and has failed to establish a causal connection between his injury and the conduct of Jerry and Janet, we find no error in the circuit courtâ€™s conclusion that Meehan lacks the standing necessary to maintain.
Meehan next argues the complaint adequately sets forth a claim against Jerry and Janet for intentional interference with inheritance rights.Â  We find this issue not preserved for appellate review.[3]
â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€Â  Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998).Â Â  An argument is not preserved for review when it is presented it to the court for the first time in a motion to alter or amend the judgment pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP.Â  Hickman v. Hickman, 301 S.C. 455, 457, 392 S.E.2d 481, 482 (1990).Â  A party cannot use Rule 59(e), SCRCP, to present to the trial court an issue the party could have raised prior to judgment but did not. Â Id.
In this case, Meehan neither alleged a cause of action for intentional interference with inheritance rights in his amended complaint, nor sought to proffer any further amendment to the complaint at the hearing.Â  The first mention of an allegation supporting an action for intentional interference with inheritance rights came in Meehanâ€™s Rule 59(e), SCRCP motion to alter or amend the judgment.Â  Therefore, this issue is not preserved for our review.
Additionally, Meehan argues the circuit court erred in dismissing his action rather than affording him the opportunity to add Mother as an indispensable party.Â  Again, we find this issue not preserved for appellate review.

Rule 15(a), SCRCP, provides, in part:
  
A party may amend his pleading once as a matter of course at any time before or within 30 days after a responsive pleading is served or, if the pleading is one to which no responsive pleading is required and the action has not been placed upon the trial roster, he may so amend it at any time within 30 days after it is served.Â  Otherwise a party may amend his pleading only by leave of court or by written consent of the adverse party.
  

Accordingly, a party seeking to amend his pleadings at trial must proffer the amendment before the court, and must obtain a ruling from the circuit court denying the amendment.Â  See Keels v. Pierce, 315 S.C. 339, 343, 433 S.E.2d 902, 904 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  
Here, Meehan did not seek to add Mother as a party, nor did he proffer any amendment to the circuit court at the hearing.Â  Meehan simply stated to the court â€œif we go on, Iâ€™ll have to amend the complaint anyway.â€Â  Even assuming this could be construed as an oral motion to amend, and we do not believe it can, Meehan did not receive a ruling from the circuit court.Â  Therefore, the issue is not preserved for our review.
Lastly, Meehan alleges the circuit court erred in considering an affidavit of Mother in ruling on the dismissal.Â  We disagree.
It is well settled that in considering a Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP motion, the circuit court must base its ruling solely upon the allegations set forth in the pleadings.Â  Stiles v. Onorato, 318 S.C. 297, 457 S.E.2d 697 (1995).Â  If the circuit court considers matters outside of the pleadings, the 12(b)(6) motion will be converted to one for summary judgment under Rule 56, SCRCP.Â  See Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP.
There is no evidence that the circuit court relied on Motherâ€™s affidavit in dismissing Meehanâ€™s action under Rule 12(b)(6).Â  The affidavit was introduced pursuant to Motherâ€™s contemporaneous Motion to Quash the Deposition Subpoena of Meehan.Â  While there was some dialogue between the circuit court and Meehanâ€™s attorney concerning the affidavit, nothing indicates the circuit court considered the contents of the affidavit when it dismissed the action.Â  The findings of fact and conclusions of law contained in the order dismissing the action make no reference to the affidavit or the facts contained in the affidavit, and Meehan cannot point to any evidence that the circuit court relied on the affidavit of Mother.Â  Therefore, the action was not converted to a motion for summary judgment, and the circuit court correctly dismissed the action pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP.
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s dismissal of Meehanâ€™s action pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6) is hereby
 AFFIRMED.
HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] Lebanon Road thereafter conveyed approximately 42.6 acres of the Dickson Place property to Coastal Plains Development Co., an entity not a party to this action.Â  The remainder of Dickson Place is currently owned by Lebanon Road.
[2] We need not address the other Respondents, Lebanon Road, LLC, and GrandSouth Bancorporation, as any liability they may incur is derivative to that of Jerry and Janet.Â  Because we affirm the circuit courtâ€™s finding that Meehan lacked the standing to bring the action against Jerry and Janet, we also affirm the dismissal of the remaining Respondents.
[3] South Carolina has yet to recognize intentional interference with inheritance rights as a valid cause of action.Â

title: Walls v. Reed Porter & RAF, LLC
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Teddy Walls, formerly d/b/a Crafts Unlimited, Appellant/Respondent,
v.
Reed Porter & RAF, LLC, Respondent/Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
G. Edward Welmaker, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-089
Heard November 9, 2005 â€“ Filed February 10, 2006

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Weston Trey Merck, of Piedmont, for Appellant-Respondent.
Thomas Elihue Dudley, III, of Greenville, for Respondent-Appellant.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â Contractor Teddy Walls appeals the trial courtâ€™s dismissal of his mechanicâ€™s lien action for failing to timely file his notice and certificate of mechanicâ€™s lien and foreclosure action where the notice and action were erroneously brought in the name of Crafts Unlimited Contractors, Inc., a corporation Walls formed after entering into the construction contracts.Â  Reed Porter & RAF, LLC filed a cross-appeal asserting the trial court erred in denying their request for attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We reverse the dismissal of Wallsâ€™ action and remand.[1]
FACTS
On July 28, 2003, Teddy Walls, as the Owner of Crafts Unlimited, a sole proprietorship, entered into two construction contracts with Reed Porter & RAF, LLC (Reed/Porter).Â  One contract price was $150,000.00.Â  The other was $740,000.00.Â  In December of 2003, Walls incorporated his business under the name Crafts Unlimited Contractors, Inc (the Corporation).Â  Walls was terminated from the projects in January of 2004. Although Walls performed the work under the contracts doing business as Crafts Unlimited, the sole proprietorship, he filed a notice and certificate of mechanicâ€™s lien that he had signed on behalf of the Corporation on February 24, 2004.Â  The Corporation subsequently brought this action on May 4, 2004 seeking foreclosure of the mechanicâ€™s lien as well as claims for breach of contract and unjust enrichment.Â  In its answer, Reed/Porter asserted the corporation lacked standing to bring the action as it could not establish an agreement with Reed/Porter to perform work.Â  
On June 7, 2004, Walls filed an amended summons and complaint and lis pendens under his own name, doing business as Crafts Unlimited, asserting claims for breach of contract, unjust enrichment, and foreclosure of a mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  Reed/Porter moved for partial summary judgment on the claim for foreclosure of the mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  It asserted as the Corporation did not contract to provide labor and materials, it never acquired any lien rights. 
The trial court found that it was undisputed that the Corporation did not contract to provide labor and materials, and therefore never acquired any lien rights upon which to base a lien claim.Â  It ruled Walls, the current plaintiff, was a different, distinct entity from the Corporation.Â  It held that since it had been more than ninety days since Walls had done any work on the subject property, the error in naming the wrong party could not be cured.Â  Thus, as Walls did not timely file a notice of mechanicâ€™s lien, the mechanicâ€™s lien action must be dismissed.
As an additional sustaining holding, the court held that since the entity that filed the mechanicâ€™s lien was not properly licensed, it lacked standing to assert such a lien or lawsuit.Â  The court denied Reed/Porterâ€™s request for attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Walls argues the trial court erred in holding his notice of mechanicâ€™s lien and foreclosure action were not timely filed.Â  We agree.Â  
As a mechanicâ€™s lien is purely statutory, the requirements of the statute must be strictly followed.Â  Muller v. Myrtle Beach Golf & Yacht Club, 303 S.C. 137, 140, 399 S.E.2d 430, 432 (Ct. App. 1990), overruled on other grounds by Myrtle Beach Hosp., Inc. v. City of Myrtle Beach, 341 S.C. 1, 532 S.E.2d 868 (2000).Â  If any one of these requirements is not met, the lien against the property is dissolved.Â  Id.Â  at 141, 399 S.E.2d at 432.Â  However, as the mechanicâ€™s lien statutes are remedial, they are to be given a liberal construction. Â Clo-Car Trucking Co. v. Clifflue Estates of S.C., 282 S.C. 573, 575-76, 320 S.E.2d 51, 53 (Ct. App. 1984). 
The mechanicâ€™s lien statutes set forth the time limits in which a person seeking to enforce a mechanicâ€™s lien must serve and file the notice and certificate of lien and foreclosure action.Â  Section 29-5-90 of the South Carolina Code provides the time limits for serving and filing the notice and certificate of lien: 

[A mechanicâ€™s] lien shall be dissolved unless the person desiring to avail himself thereof, within ninety days after he ceases to labor on or furnish labor or materials for such building or structure, serves upon the owner or, in the event the owner cannot be found, upon the person in possession and files in the office of the register of deeds or clerk of court of the county in which the building or structure is situated a statement of a just and true account of the amount due him, with all just credits given, together with a description of the property intended to be covered by the lien sufficiently accurate for identification, with the name of the owner of the property, if known, which certificate shall be subscribed and sworn to by the person claiming the lien or by someone in his behalf and shall be recorded in a book kept for the purpose by the register or clerk who shall be entitled to the same fees therefor as for recording mortgages of equal length. . . . 

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-90 (Supp. 2005).Â  
A suit to enforce the lien must be commenced within six months of the cessation of labor. S.C.Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-120 (1991). 
In the present case, Walls filed his amended summons and complaint and lis pendens within six months of his cessation of labor.Â  Thus, he complied with section 29-5-120 in timely commencing his suit to enforce the mechanicâ€™s lien.Â Â  The amended action, however, was served and filed well after the 90-day time limit set forth in section 29-5-90 for serving and filing the notice of mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  Therefore, we must decide whether the notice served and filed on February 24, 2004 meets the requirements of the statute to preserve Wallsâ€™ lien.Â  
Walls, â€œthe person desiring to avail himselfâ€ of the lien, signed the notice himself, albeit on behalf of the Corporation.Â  He also signed the affidavit of mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  Walls merely captioned the notice with the Corporationâ€™s name.

Where the purpose of the requirement that a particular statement be included in the claim of lien has been achieved and no one is prejudiced, technical requirements should not stand in the way of achieving the purposes of the mechanicâ€™s lien law.Â  Even though a claim contains some defect or error it will be upheld where the owner is informed of the claim and not misled by it or prejudiced.Â  

53 Am.Jur. 2d Mechanicâ€™s Liens Â§ 235 (1996).
Reed/Porter presented no evidence that it was misled by this caption or that it was prejudiced in any manner.Â  In fact, it is impossible to discern how it could have been misled considering the documents were signed by Walls and the Corporationâ€™s name is the same as the name of Wallsâ€™ sole proprietorship.Â  We find under the facts of this case, Walls timely perfected his mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  
As an additional holding, the trial court held that since the entity that filed the mechanicâ€™s lien, the Corporation, was not properly licensed, it lacked standing to assert such a lien or lawsuit.Â  The Corporation, however, is no longer a party in this suit.Â  Walls, who is properly licensed, is the only party seeking to enforce the lien.Â Â  The Corporationâ€™s lack of a license has no bearing on Wallsâ€™ claim against Reed/Porter.
Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s dismissal of Wallsâ€™ action to foreclose the mechanicâ€™s lien is 
REVERSED AND REMANDED.[2]
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.Â  

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.Â  
[2] As we reverse the trial courtâ€™s dismissal of Wallsâ€™ foreclosure action, we need not address Reed/Porterâ€™s claims that it was entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees.Â

title: Safety National Surety v. Hernandez
text:
PER CURIAM:


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Ex Parte:  Safety National, Surety for South Carolina Bonding Company Surety,
Appellant,
In Re:Â  State of South Carolina Respondent,
v.
Alfredo Hernandez Defendant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Edward W. Miller, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-094
Submitted February 1, 2006 â€“ Filed February 14, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
David Lloyd Thomas, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this bond estreatment case, Safety National, Surety for South Carolina Bonding Company (Safety National), appeals the circuit courtâ€™s decision ordering a partial estreatment of Alfredo Hernandezâ€™s bond.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Hernandez, a foreign national, was arrested in South Carolina for grand larceny.Â  On October 31, 2002, Hernandez was released from custody when the South Carolina Bonding Company signed a $4,000 surety bond.Â  
On March 26, 2003, the circuit court issued a bench warrant for Hernandezâ€™s arrest when, after proper notice, he failed to appear in court on that date.Â  On June 10, 2003, the circuit court issued a conditional order to estreat Hernandezâ€™s bond unless the South Carolina Bonding Company appeared on July 11, 2003, to show cause why the bond should not be remitted in whole or in part.Â  
At the hearing, counsel informed the court that the United States Bureau of Citizenship and Immigration Services picked up Hernandez on March 11, 2003, and ultimately deported him.Â  As a result, counsel argued the court should not estreat the bond because the bond company could not bring Hernandez into court on the scheduled date.Â  In response, the State asserted that Safety National assumed the risk of forfeiture by signing a bond for a non-citizen. 
At the conclusion of the hearing, the court estreated $2,000 of the $4,000 bond on the ground Hernandez violated the conditions of his bond.Â  This appeal followed.
DISCUSSION
Safety National argues the circuit court erred in partially estreating Hernandezâ€™s bond.Â  Because the federal government detained and deported Hernandez, Safety National contends it was impossible to bring Hernandez into court.Â  Thus, Safety National asserts it was no longer bound to perform its obligation under the bond contract.
Section 38-53-70 of the South Carolina Code outlines the procedure governing bond forfeitures.Â  This section provides:

If a defendant fails to appear at a court proceeding to which he has been summoned, the court must issue a bench warrant for the defendant.Â  If the surety fails to surrender the defendant or place a hold on the defendantâ€™s release from incarceration, commitment, or institutionalization within thirty days of the issuance of the bench warrant, the bond shall be forfeited.Â  At any time before execution is issued on a judgment of forfeiture against a defendant or his surety, the court may direct that the judgment be remitted in whole or in part, upon conditions as the court may impose, if it appears that justice requires the remission of part or all of the judgment.Â  In making a determination as to remission of the judgment, the court shall consider the costs to the State or any county or municipality resulting from the necessity to continue or terminate the defendantâ€™s trial and the efforts of law enforcement officers or agencies to locate the defendant.Â  The court in its discretion may permit the surety to pay the estreatment in installments for a period of up to six months . . . . If at any time during the period in which installments are to be paid the defendant is surrendered to the appropriate detention facility and the surety complies with the re-commitment procedures, the surety is relieved of any further liability.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-53-70 (Supp. 2005).
â€œThe issue of whether a bond forfeiture should be remitted, and if so, to what extent, is vested in the discretion of the trial judge.â€Â  Ex parte Polk, 354 S.C. 8, 11, 579 S.E.2d 329, 330 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  â€œ[T]he exercise of that discretion by the trial judge will not be set aside unless it is made to appear that it was abused.â€Â  State v. Holloway, 262 S.C. 552, 555, 206 S.E.2d 822, 823 (1974).Â  â€œAmong the factors to be considered in determining whether and to what extent relief will be granted are (1) the purpose of the bond; (2) the nature and wilfulness of the default; [and] (3) any prejudice or additional expense resulting to the State.â€Â  State v. Workman, 274 S.C. 341, 343, 263 S.E.2d 865, 866 (1980).Â  â€œIf bond is forfeited because of ignorance or unavoidable impediment rather than willful default, the trial court may, on affidavit showing cause or excuse, remit the forfeiture in full or in part.â€Â  State v. Boatwright, 310 S.C. 281, 283, 423 S.E.2d 139, 140 (1992) (citing S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-15-180 (1985)).
We find the circuit court did not abuse its discretion in ordering a partial estreatment of Hernandezâ€™s bond.Â  Hernandezâ€™s release on bond was conditioned upon his appearance in court on the date set by the State.Â  Because Hernandez failed to appear on the scheduled date, it is undisputed that he violated the principle condition of his bond.Â  Additionally, Hernandez violated the â€œgood behaviorâ€ condition of the bond given he was deported.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-15-20 (2003) (â€œEvery appearance recognizance or appearance bond will be conditioned on the person charged personally appearing before the court specified to answer the charge or indictment and to do and receive what shall be enjoined by the court, and not to depart the State, and to be of good behavior toward all the citizens thereof, or especially toward any person or persons specified by the court.â€).
As a result of Hernandezâ€™s default, Safety National became liable and, in turn, subject to forfeiture of the bond.Â  See Pride v. Anders, 266 S.C. 338, 341, 223 S.E.2d 184, 186 (1976) (â€œ[T]he obligation of appellant-surety was not to the State to produce defendants at the time to be later set, but was rather an obligation to answer, to the extent of the penalty, for the default of the defendants, as principals, in the event they did not appear on the date set for trial.Â  When the defendants defaulted by their failure to appear, the liability of the appellant, as surety, became fixed.â€); Ex parte Polk, 354 S.C. at 11, 579 S.E.2d at 330 (â€œAs guarantor, the surety on an appearance bond undertakes the risk of forfeiture in the event the defendant does not appear for trial.â€).
The question then becomes to what extent relief should have been granted due to the default.Â  Despite the circuit courtâ€™s failure to specifically enunciate either orally or in its written order the requisite factors, we find the court properly exercised its discretion in partially estreating the bond.Â  We believe implicit in the courtâ€™s ruling was a consideration of the factors.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
First, Hernandezâ€™s failure to appear at the scheduled date or at the hearing date violated the purpose of the appearance bond.Â  Secondly, although Safety National claimed it could not apprehend Hernandez, it did not present any evidence to show that Hernandezâ€™s default was â€œan uncontrollable circumstance that arose through no faultâ€ on its part.Â  Reyes v. State, 31 S.W.3d 343, 346 (Tex. Ct. App. 2000) (affirming trial courtâ€™s order forfeiting bail bond where defendant had been deported to Mexico and did not appear in court on the scheduled date given Appellants did not establish â€œthe circumstances arose through no fault of the principalâ€); see Hillsborough County v. Roche Surety & Cas. Co., 805 So. 2d 937, 939 (Fla. Dist. Ct. App. 2001) (ordering bond forfeited where principal had fled to Mexico when the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service had revoked his work permit and the surety did not satisfy the requirement that it â€œsubstantially attempted to procure or cause the apprehensionâ€ of the principal). 
Furthermore, we find Safety Nationalâ€™s reliance on Taylor v. Taintor, 83 U.S. 366 (1872) and State v. Boatwright, 310 S.C. 281, 423 S.E.2d 139 (1992) is misplaced.
In Taylor, the defendant was arrested and charged for a crime committed in Connecticut.Â  He was then released on bond at which time he returned to New York, the state of his residence.Â  Shortly thereafter, he was extradited to Maine where he was tried and convicted of another charge.Â  Because the defendant failed to appear in court for his trial in Connecticut, the trial court forfeited the bond.Â  Taylor, 83 U.S. at 369.Â  On appeal, the surety claimed it had no notice of the charges against the defendant in Maine and, therefore, it could not be obligated on the bond because the performance of the bond had been rendered impossible.Â  Id.Â  The United States Supreme Court affirmed the decision of the trial court.Â  The Court found the surety was not discharged from liability given the defendantâ€™s default was not effectuated by an act of the State, but rather the defendantâ€™s own actions that could have been prevented by the surety.Â  Id. at 373.
In Boatwright, the defendant was arrested and charged with forgery.Â  He was subsequently released on an appearance bond.Â  Prior to the trial of his case, the defendant pled guilty to a charge in Georgia.Â  He was extradited and released from South Carolina to the Georgia authorities.Â  As a result, the defendant failed to appear for his forgery trial in South Carolina.Â  After a hearing, the circuit court estreated one-half of the bond amount.Â  
On appeal, the surety argued the State should have been estopped from estreating any part of the bond because the release of the defendant to Georgia prevented him from appearing in court.Â  Additionally, the surety asserted the circuit court erred in estreating a portion of the bond because the defendantâ€™s failure to appear was not willful.Â  Boatwright, 310 S.C. at 283, 423 S.E.2d at 140.Â  Our supreme court affirmed the decision of the circuit court.Â  Although the court recognized that a â€œsurety should be released from liability when estreatment is ordered for non-appearance after defendant has been extradited,â€ it relied on the fact that the bond was estreated not only for the defendantâ€™s non-appearance but also for his violation of the â€œgood behaviorâ€ condition of the bond.Â  Id. at 283, 423 S.E.2d at 140.Â  Thus, the court found the bond had been properly estreated due to the breach of the bond contract.Â  Id.Â  The court further concluded the circuit court did not abuse its discretion in estreating only half of the bond given the Stateâ€™s extradition aided in preventing the defendant from appearing on the scheduled date.Â  Id. at 283, 423 S.E.2d at 141.
In relying on Boatwright, Safety National merely references the following statement, â€œ[w]hen extradition is accomplished, the surety is no longer able to perform his obligation under the contract to deliver the defendant to court.â€Â  Id. at 283, 423 S.E.2d at 140.Â  Although this quote is accurate, it does not reflect the basis for the courtâ€™s decision.
In our view, the precedent established in Boatwright and Taylor supports the circuit courtâ€™s decision rather than Safety Nationalâ€™s argument.Â  The Boatwright decision stands for the proposition that bond is contractual in nature and the principle of estoppel does apply, however, any violation of the contract, i.e., the conditions of the bond, provides the Stateâ€™s right to bond estreatment.Â  Taylor stands for a corollary principle that the Stateâ€™s action must create the violation of the bond in order for the surety to be exonerated from liability.
In the instant case, it is undisputed that Hernandez, through no action of the State, violated the appearance condition and the good behavior condition of the bond.Â  Therefore, regardless of any government involvement in deportation, the breach of the bond contract supported the estreatment.Â  Moreover, as in Boatwright, the circuit court took into consideration the circumstances surrounding the detainment and deportation in deciding only to estreat one-half of Hernandezâ€™s bond.Â  
Turning to the final factor in bond estreatment analysis, we find the State was prejudiced by Hernandezâ€™s failure to appear on the scheduled date.Â  Hernandez failure to appear on March 26, 2003, in conjunction with Safety Nationalâ€™s failure to present Hernandez at the hearing, created a delay for the State sufficient to constitute prejudice.Â  Holloway, 262 S.C. at 557, 206 S.E.2d at 824 (â€œCertainly, prejudice to the State appears when a defendant, without excuse, fails to appear at the time set for trial, thereby obstructing and delaying the orderly administration of justice.â€).Â  Furthermore, given the circuit court only estreated $2,000 of the $4,000 bond, we find the amount estreated was not so excessive to constitute an abuse of discretion.
We acknowledge the disposition of this case may seem harsh.Â  However, in view of the statutory guidelines and the above-outlined precedent, we are constrained to find the circuit court did not abuse its discretion.
Accordingly, the order of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED.
BEATTY, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Walls v. RAF
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Teddy Walls, formerly d/b/a Crafts Unlimited, Appellant/Respondent,
v.
RAF Enterprises of Greenville, LLC, Ryan Arnold, Red Brick
Caf'e, Inc., and Synovus Financial Corp. d/b/a The National Bank of South Carolina, Defendants,/Of whom RAF Enterprises of Greenville, LLC, Ryan Arnold, Red Brick
Caf'e, Inc.are, Respondents/Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
G. Edward Welmaker, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-095
Heard November 9, 2006 â€“ Filed February 14, 2006Â Â Â 

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Weston Trey Merck, of Piedmont, for Appellant-Respondent.
Thomas Elihue Dudley, III, of Greenville, for Respondents/Appellants.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Contractor Teddy Walls appeals the trial courtâ€™s dismissal of his mechanicâ€™s lien action for failing to timely file his notice and certificate of mechanicâ€™s lien and foreclosure action where the notice and action were erroneously brought in the name of Crafts Unlimited Contractors, Inc., a corporation Walls formed after entering into the construction contracts.Â  RAF Enterprises of Greenville, LLC, Ryan Arnold and Red Brick CafÃ©, Inc. (collectively Defendants) filed a cross-appeal asserting the trial court erred in denying their request for attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We reverse the dismissal of Wallsâ€™ action and remand.[1]
FACTS
On July 8, 2003, Teddy Walls, as the Owner of Crafts Unlimited, a sole proprietorship, entered into a contract with Ryan Arnold for construction of a restaurant, the Red Brick CafÃ©, in a strip mall owned by RAF Enterprises.Â  The contract price was $62,000.00.Â  Wallsâ€™ last day of work on the project was December 22, 2003.Â  In December of 2003, Walls incorporated his business under the name Crafts Unlimited Contractors, Inc (the Corporation).Â  Although Walls performed the work under the contract doing business as Crafts Unlimited, the sole proprietorship, he served and filed a notice and certificate of mechanicâ€™s lien he signed on behalf of the Corporation against RAF Enterprises on February 24, 2004.Â  The Corporation subsequently brought this action against RAF Enterprises seeking foreclosure of the mechanicâ€™s lien as well as claims for breach of contract and unjust enrichment.Â  In its answer, RAF Enterprises claimed Walls contracted with The Red Brick CafÃ©, Inc and not RAF Enterprises.Â  Thus, it asserted The Red Brick CafÃ©, which was the proper party to the action, was not named as a party.Â  Furthermore, it alleged the Corporation was not a party to the written agreement and thus lacked standing to bring the action as it could not establish an agreement with it to perform work.Â  
On June 7, 2004, Walls filed an amended summons and complaint and lis pendens under his own name, formerly doing business as Crafts Unlimited, asserting claims for breach of contract, unjust enrichment, and foreclosure of a mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  In this complaint, he named RAF Enterprises, Ryan Arnold, and Red Brick CafÃ©, Inc. as defendants.[2]Â  The Defendants moved for partial summary judgment on the claim for foreclosure of the mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  
The trial court found it was undisputed the Corporation did not contract to provide labor and materials, nor did Walls produce any document evidencing a novation wherein the Defendants agreed that its contract was to be assigned to the Corporation.Â  The court held the Corporation never acquired any lien rights upon which to base a lien claim.Â  The court noted that Wallsâ€™ counsel admitted that Walls mistakenly used the corporate name when filing the mechanicâ€™s lien. It ruled Walls, the current plaintiff, was a different, distinct entity from the Corporation.Â  It held that since it had been more than ninety days since Walls had done any work on the subject property, the error in naming the wrong party could not be cured.Â  Thus, as Walls did not timely file a notice of mechanicâ€™s lien, the mechanicâ€™s lien action must be dismissed.
As an additional sustaining ground, the court held that since the entity that filed the mechanicâ€™s lien was not properly licensed, it lacked standing to assert such a lien or lawsuit.Â  The court denied the Defendantsâ€™ request for attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Walls argues the trial court erred in holding his notice of mechanicâ€™s lien and foreclosure action were not timely served and filed.Â  We agree.Â  
As a mechanicâ€™s lien is purely statutory, the requirements of the statute must be strictly followed.Â  Muller v. Myrtle Beach Golf & Yacht Club, 303 S.C. 137, 140, 399 S.E.2d 430, 432 (Ct. App. 1990), overruled on other grounds by Myrtle Beach Hosp., Inc. v. City of Myrtle Beach, 341 S.C. 1, 532 S.E.2d 868 (2000).Â Â  If any one of these requirements is not met, the lien against the property is dissolved.Â  Id. at 141, 399 S.E.2d at 432.Â  However, as the mechanicâ€™s lien statutes are remedial, they are to be given a liberal construction. Â Clo-Car Trucking Co. v. Clifflue Estates of S.C., 282 S.C. 573, 575-76, 320 S.E.2d 51, 53 (Ct. App. 1984). 
The mechanicâ€™s lien statutes set forth the time limits in which a person seeking to enforce a mechanicâ€™s lien must serve and file the notice and certificate of lien and foreclosure action.Â  Section 29-5-90 of the South Carolina Code provides the time limits for serving and filing the notice of lien: 

[A mechanicâ€™s] lien shall be dissolved unless the person desiring to avail himself thereof, within ninety days after he ceases to labor on or furnish labor or materials for such building or structure, serves upon the owner or, in the event the owner cannot be found, upon the person in possession and files in the office of the register of deeds or clerk of court of the county in which the building or structure is situated a statement of a just and true account of the amount due him, with all just credits given, together with a description of the property intended to be covered by the lien sufficiently accurate for identification, with the name of the owner of the property, if known, which certificate shall be subscribed and sworn to by the person claiming the lien or by someone in his behalf and shall be recorded in a book kept for the purpose by the register or clerk who shall be entitled to the same fees therefor as for recording mortgages of equal length. . . . 

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-90 (Supp. 2005).Â  
A suit to enforce the lien must be commenced within six months of the cessation of labor.Â  S.C.Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-120 (1991). 
In the present case, Walls filed his amended summons and complaint and lis pendens within six months of his cessation of labor.Â  Thus, he complied with section 29-5-120 in timely commencing his suit to enforce the mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  The amended action, however, was served and filed well after the 90-day time limit set forth in section 29-5-90 for serving and filing the notice of mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  Therefore, we must decide whether the notice served and filed on February 24, 2004 meets the requirements of the statute to preserve Wallsâ€™ lien.Â  
Walls, â€œthe person desiring to avail himselfâ€ of the lien, signed the notice himself, albeit on behalf of the Corporation.Â  He also signed the affidavit of mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  Walls merely captioned the notice with the Corporationâ€™s name.

Where the purpose of the requirement that a particular statement be included in the claim of lien has been achieved and no one is prejudiced, technical requirements should not stand in the way of achieving the purposes of the mechanicâ€™s lien law.Â  Even though a claim contains some defect or error it will be upheld where the owner is informed of the claim and not misled by it or prejudiced.Â  

53 Am.Jur. 2d Mechanicâ€™s Liens Â§ 235 (1996).
The Defendants presented no evidence that they were misled by this caption or that they were prejudiced in any manner.Â  In fact, it is impossible to discern how they could have been misled considering the documents were signed by Walls and the Corporationâ€™s name is the same as the name of Wallsâ€™ sole proprietorship.Â  We find under the facts of this case, Walls timely perfected his mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  
As an additional holding, the trial court held that since the entity that filed the mechanicâ€™s lien, the Corporation, was not properly licensed, it lacked standing to assert such a lien or lawsuit.Â  The Corporation, however, is no longer a party in this suit.Â  Walls, who is properly licensed, is the only party seeking to enforce the lien.Â  The Corporationâ€™s lack of a license has no bearing on Wallsâ€™ claim against the Defendants.
Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s dismissal of Wallsâ€™ action to foreclose the mechanicâ€™s lien is 
REVERSED AND REMANDED.[3]
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.Â Â Â  

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Synovus Financial Corporation, d/b/a The National Bank of South Carolina was also named as a defendant.Â  The bank is not a party to this appeal.Â  
[3] As we reverse the trial courtâ€™s dismissal of Wallsâ€™ foreclosure action, we need not address the Defendantsâ€™ claims that they were entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees.Â
