title: Smith v. Bloome
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Louise Smith, Respondent,
v.
Larry Bloome, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Orangeburg County
Â Olin D. Burgdorf, Master- In- Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-096
Submitted February 1, 2006 â€“ Filed February 14, 2006Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
H. Wayne Floyd, of W. Columbia, for Appellant.
William T. Toal, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Larry Bloome appeals from an order finding he was not the owner of 9.9 acres of land in Orangeburg County, alleging that he is the owner of the land because he paid the purchase price, he has title by adverse possession, and he is entitled to money under the betterment statute.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Ada Johnson died in 1992, devising all of her property to Fred Johnson, who then died in 1993.Â  After his death, Louise Smith, a resident of New York, was appointed as the personal representative of Fredâ€™s estate and became the sole heir of a 9.9-acre piece of land located in Orangeburg County.Â  Ada owned the land originally, but Fred inherited it when she died. 
Smith testified that before Ada died she told her she was going to sell some of the property, but then Ada became sick, and as a result, she did not pursue it any further.Â  Smith further testified she knew that Bloome, her distant cousin, kept animals on the land; however, Bloome began building a house on the land without her prior knowledge.Â  Smith said she was going to give Bloome the one-acre section of land on which he built his house, but Bloome failed to hire a surveyor and then became rude to her, so she told him he had to buy the land from her.Â  When Bloome refused to pay Smith for the land she sent a realtor to make him pay rent, which he also refused to do. 
On January 16, 2001, Smith brought an action in Magistrateâ€™s Court to evict Bloome as a tenant from the property.Â  Bloome counterclaimed, alleging he was the owner of the land because he paid the purchase price, he had title by adverse possession, he had greatly increased the value of the property when he built a house on it, Smith was unjustly enriched, and Smith should be estopped from asserting Bloome did not own the property.Â  After being transferred to the Court of Common Pleas per Bloomeâ€™s motion, a hearing was held on December 5, 2001.Â  On May 10, 2002, the judge entered a judgment for Smith and ordered that Bloome be ejected from the premises.Â  Bloome filed a Motion for Rehearing, Reconsideration and for a New Trial on May 23, 2002, which was denied by an Order filed on November 10, 2004.Â  On December 14, 2004, Bloome filed his Notice of Appeal with this court.Â  Subsequently, on December 30, 2004, Bloome filed a motion to stay ejection in the Court of Common Pleas.Â  The judge issued an order on February 28, 2005, staying ejectment, but requiring Bloome to pay $750 per month into escrow pending the outcome of the appeal. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn an action at law, on appeal of a case tried without a jury, the findings of fact of the judge will not be disturbed upon appeal unless found to be without evidence which reasonably supports the judgeâ€™s findings.â€Â 
Townes Assoc., Ltd. v. City of Greenville,
266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Bloome argues the trial court erred when it ruled that he did not own the land by adverse possession.Â  We disagree.
â€œA plaintiffâ€™s title by adverse possession requires proof of actual, open, notorious, hostile, continuous, and exclusive possession by the claimant, or by one or more persons through whom he claimed, for the full statutory period.â€Â 
Miller v. Leaird, 307 S.C. 56, 61, 413 S.E.2d 841, 844 (1992).Â  Bloome claims that he occupied the property for the ten-year statutory period; however, the trial judge found that Bloomeâ€™s possession was not hostile because he lived on the property with Adaâ€™s permission and Smith continued Bloomeâ€™s permissive use for a period of time after she inherited the land.Â  Therefore, the trial judge was correct in finding that Bloome did not gain possession of the land by adverse possession.
Bloome argues the trial court erred when it ruled that he did not own the land because he paid the purchase price for the land.Â  We disagree.
At trial, Bloome testified that he purchased the 9.9 acres of land from Ada before she died and he had two receipts from her for the sale of the land.Â  However, the trial judge determined that Ada did not write the receipts because the handwriting on the receipts differed from a sample of Adaâ€™s signature that was admitted at trial as an exhibit.Â  Furthermore, the judge stated that even if he accepted the authenticity of the receipts, they did not describe the property to be conveyed nor did they show the purchase price.Â  Additionally, the judge held that because Bloome did not have a deed to the land and has never had a deed to the land, or any other written document signed by Ada, he failed to satisfy the Statute of Frauds.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 32-3-10(4) (1991).Â  Thus, the trial judge was correct in finding that Bloome did not acquire the property by paying the purchase price.Â Â Â  
Bloome argues the trial court erred when it ruled that he was not entitled to reimbursement for his substantial improvements to the property under the betterments statute.Â  We disagree.
To recover under the betterments statute, â€œit is incumbent on [Bloome] not merely to show the value of his improvements, but he must present evidence from which the jury can find a special verdict stating the value of the land without the improvements and the value of the land with the improvements . . . .â€Â  Hall v. Boatwright, 58 S.C. 544, 547, 36 S.E. 1001, 1002 (1900).Â  At trial, Bloome presented evidence of the value of his house; however, he failed to present evidence of the value of the land without the improvements or the value of the land with the improvements.Â  Additionally, the betterments statute requires for Bloome to have believed that he was the exclusive owner of the land.Â  Id. at 547-548, 36 S.E. at 1002-1003.Â  The trial judge found that Bloome knew that he did not have a deed to the land and that he could have checked with the Register of Deeds to determine if a deed had been recorded.Â  Therefore, the trial judge was correct in holding that Bloomeâ€™s claim failed under the betterments statute.Â  
Bloome argues the trial court erred when it ruled that he had to pay $750 a month to stay ejection from the property during the appeal.Â  
Rule 203(d)(2)(B), SCACR, requires an appellant to file along with their notice of appeal, a â€œcopy of the order(s) and judgment(s) which are to be challenged on appeal.â€Â  Bloome filed a motion to stay ejection in the trial court after he filed his notice of appeal with this court.Â  Bloome did not file an amended notice of appeal with this court subsequent to the trial courtâ€™s ruling on the motion to stay; therefore, this issue is not properly before us.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
 AFFIRMED.
BEATTY, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur. 

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: State v. Griffith
text:
SCREENING REPORT


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
John D. Griffith, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Pickens County
J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-099
Submitted January 1, 2006 â€“ Filed February 17, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant.
John Benjamin Aplin, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  On July 12, 2002, John D. Griffith pled guilty to one count of criminal domestic violence of a high and aggravated nature (CDVHAN) and two counts of criminal domestic violence (CDV) third offense.Â  He was sentenced to seven years, suspended upon the service of three years with three years of probation for the CDVHAN, and concurrent terms of eighteen months on each of the CDV third offense charges.Â  Following a probation revocation hearing, the court revoked Griffithâ€™s probation and reinstated the balance of his suspended sentence.Â  This appeal follows.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On April 2, 2004, a probation arrest warrant was issued charging Griffith with violating the terms of his probation.Â  Specifically, the warrant affidavit alleged there was probable cause to believe Griffith committed the offense of CDV on April 2, 2004.Â  It further alleged Griffith had failed to pay supervision fees and court costs as instructed, and that he failed to follow the advice and instructions of his supervising agent.Â  
A probation revocation hearing was held on April 22, 2004, at which time Griffith appeared without counsel.Â  The probation revocation court noted the State was recommending revocation of his probation and that Griffith had four years remaining on his original sentence.Â  Because Griffith was exposed to being returned to prison, the court asked Griffith why he did not have an attorney.Â  Griffith stated that he did not have the funds to secure counsel, but had inquired at the public defenderâ€™s office and was told he did not qualify for a public defender based on the wages he had been earning.Â  Griffith stated he was willing to waive his right to counsel.Â  The court then stated:

Do you understand that a lawyer would represent you better than you would represent yourself, sir, because a lawyer, he or she, would know whatever defenses you may have in fact or in law to these charges.Â  And also because a lawyer would probably have a working relationship with probation or with the Court that may be able to work a better arrangement for you than you could work yourself.Â  And then finally, because a lawyer would know of any defenses you have, any legal defenses, a lawyer would be able to assert those for you and you might not even be aware of them.Â  Are you aware of all those things, sir?

Griffith indicated he was aware of that, but still wished to go forward without an attorney.Â  The court found Griffith was aware of his right to and the benefits of counsel and determined he had made a knowing waiver of counsel.Â  
Along with a CDV charge, Griffith was charged with three counts of assault with a deadly weapon, all stemming from an April 2, 2004 incident after Griffith followed his wife, their two children and a neighbor in the neighborâ€™s car and allegedly swerved his car toward the vehicle in which they were riding.Â  Griffith claimed he did not swerve his car into the other car, but was merely attempting to wave to his children in the car when his car veered over a little toward the other car.Â  He maintained it was simply an accident, and he did not try to run the other car off the road.Â  He further denied being in arrears on the fees and costs.Â  Griffith presented his wife on his behalf, who testified Griffith was not trying to run her off the road that day, but was only waving at the children.Â  She claimed she had not hesitated to press charges against him in the past and would have done so again had he attempted to hurt her.Â  
The probation agent countered that the reporting officer indicated the wife refused to sign a statement â€œbecause she was scared to, and stated she had enough problems with the suspect and did not want her name on anything.â€Â  The State maintained the wifeâ€™s testimony was given out of fear, and that the amount of violence involved in the initial charge supported this position and showed the wife was â€œcovering for Mr. Griffith.â€Â  The agent further noted the complainant in this charge was actually a third individual who was in another car and witnessed the incident, believing it to be a deliberate act which warranted her calling the police.Â  
The court found Griffith was in violation of the terms of his probation and revoked his probation, requiring him to serve his remaining four years.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
On appeal, Griffith asserts the court erred in finding he waived his right to counsel because the court failed to warn him of the dangers of self-representation.Â  He thus contends the court did not comply with the mandates of Huckaby v. State, 305 S.C. 331, 408 S.E.2d 242 (1991) and Faretta v. California, 422 U.S. 806 (1975).Â Â  
We first note the State argues this issue is not preserved for our review because Griffith failed to raise the issue below and the court did not rule upon it.Â  We disagree.Â  Our supreme court has held â€œ[a] notable exception to [the] general rule requiring a contemporaneous objection is found when the record does not reveal a knowing and intelligent waiver of the right to counsel.Â  The pro se defendant cannot be expected to raise this issue without the aid of counsel.â€Â  State v. Rocheville, 310 S.C. 20, 25 n.4, 425 S.E.2d 32, 35 n.4 (1993) (citation omitted).Â  Accordingly, we find the issue is properly before us on appeal.
We find, however, no merit to Griffithâ€™s assertion that the court erred in finding a valid waiver of his right to counsel.Â  â€œThe Sixth and Fourteenth Amendments of our Constitution guarantee that a person brought to trial in any state or federal court must be afforded the right to the assistance of counsel before he can be validly convicted and punished by imprisonment.â€Â  Faretta, 422 U.S. at 807.Â  The right to counsel attaches in probation revocation hearings and the requirements for waiving the right to counsel in a probation revocation hearing are the same requirements as apply when a defendant desires to waive his right to counsel in a trial.Â  Salley v. State, 306 S.C. 213, 215, 410 S.E.2d 921, 922 (1991).Â  
â€œFaretta requires that a defendant â€˜be made aware of the dangers and disadvantages of self-representation so that the record will establish he knows what he is doing and his choice is made with eyes open.â€™â€Â  Wroten v. State, 301 S.C. 293, 294, 391 S.E.2d 575, 576 (1990) (quoting Faretta, 422 U.S. at 835).Â  As part of the Sixth Amendment right to counsel, and the requirement that an accused be apprised of that right, the record must demonstrate that the probation revocation judge conducted a hearing to determine whether a request to proceed pro se was accompanied by a knowing and intelligent waiver.Â  Huckaby, 305 S.C. at 335, 408 S.E.2d at 244.Â  The record must reflect that the defendantâ€™s decision to represent himself was made with an understanding of the risks of self-representation, and that the defendant was made aware of the dangers and disadvantages of self-representation.Â  Id. â€œWhile a specific inquiry by the trial judge expressly addressing the disadvantages of a pro se defense is preferred, the ultimate test is not the trial judgeâ€™s advice but rather the defendantâ€™s understanding.â€ Wroten v. State, 301 S.C. at 294, 391 S.E.2d at 576.Â  â€œIf the record demonstrates the defendantâ€™s decision to represent himself was made with an understanding of the risks of self-representation, the requirements of a voluntary waiver will be satisfied.â€Â  Id.Â  (citations omitted).Â  In the absence of a specific inquiry by the probation revocation judge to determine whether the defendant has made his decision to proceed pro se â€œwith eyes open,â€ the appellate court will look to the record to discern whether there are facts to show the defendant had sufficient background or was apprised of his rights by some other source so as to constitute a knowing and intelligent waiver of the right to counsel.Â  Salley, 306 S.C. at 215, 410 S.E.2d at 922.
Here, the court informed Griffith that a lawyer â€œwould represent [him] betterâ€ than he could represent himself, that a lawyer would know what defenses he may have in fact or in law to the charges, a lawyer would have a relationship with the court and probation that could result in a better arrangement than Griffith may be able to attain on his own, a lawyer would be better able to assert any legal defenses Griffith might have, and that Griffith might not even be aware of available defenses.Â  Although the court did not use the words â€œdangersâ€ or â€œdisadvantagesâ€ in informing Griffith of his rights, it is clear the court explained to Griffith that he would lose the specific benefits of counsel if he proceeded pro se.Â  Implicit in this explanation was that Griffith would be disadvantaged by not having an attorney represent him in the matter.
This is not like Huckaby, wherein the probation revocation judge asked two questions, merely apprising Huckaby of his right to counsel and asking if he wished to waive the right.Â  Huckaby, 305 S.C. at 336, 408 S.E.2d at 245.Â  Further, unlike the situation in Huckaby, the record in the case at hand does not reflect that Griffith was under the impression the revocation hearing was a mere informal procedure conducted as a formality to have probation continued.Â  Id.Â  Here, the trial judge specifically asked Griffith why he did not have counsel representing him on the matter in light of the fact that the State was recommending revocation of his probation and that Griffith had four years remaining on his original sentence and thus was exposed to prison time.
The record before us reflects that Griffithâ€™s decision to represent himself was made with an understanding of the risks of self-representation, and that he was made aware of the dangers and disadvantages of self-representation.Â  Accordingly, the requirements of a voluntary waiver have been satisfied and we find Griffithâ€™s waiver of counsel to be valid.
For the foregoing reasons, Griffithâ€™s revocation of probation is
AFFIRMED. 1
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

1 We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Anderson v. Greene
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Estate of Deloris G. Anderson, Respondent,
v.
Linda Greene and Frank Greene, III, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Georgetown County
J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-100
Heard January 11, 2006 â€“ Filed February 17, 2006

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED AND REMANDED IN PART


  
    
      
George E. Graham, of Conway, for Appellants.
JohnnyÂ  Morant, of Georgetown, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â Linda Greene and Frank Greene, III appeal the order of the circuit court affirming the probate courtâ€™s dismissal of their claims against the estate of Deloris Anderson for rents collected by Anderson and for fraud.Â  We affirm in part and reverse and remand in part.Â  
FACTS
Anderson was the Greenesâ€™ aunt.Â  When Andersonâ€™s father, Frank Greene Sr., passed away on October 8, 1980, he left as his only heirs at law Anderson and the Greenes, whose father, Frank Greene, Jr., had predeceased Frank Sr.Â  Although Frank Sr.â€™s estate was never formally administered, the Greenes presented three deeds dated July 23, 1981 purporting to divide Frank Sr.â€™s estate.Â  One deed was ostensibly signed by Anderson and Linda to convey their interest in two lots to Frank III, one deed was ostensibly signed by Anderson and Frank III to convey their interest in a lot to Linda, and the final deed was ostensibly signed by Linda and Frank III conveying their interest in a lot to Anderson.Â  The mailing address on the deeds to Linda and Frank III was listed as in care of Anderson at her address.Â  The Greenes lived out of state at this time.Â  At the hearing, they claimed to have no knowledge of the deeds and denied ever signing any of them.Â  
It was not until after Andersonâ€™s death that another relative discovered the deeds and informed the Greenes that they existed.Â  Although Anderson rented all of the properties, she never shared any of the rents with the Greenes.Â  The Greenes filed a claim against Andersonâ€™s estate seeking $117,522.70 for their share of the rents.Â  The personal representative of Andersonâ€™s estate denied the claim.Â  
The probate court found that because the Greenes testified that their signatures on the deeds into them were forged, the deeds were not genuine and were â€œmerely bogus documents.â€Â  Thus it held the Greenes could not prove title to the properties through the deeds.Â  In addition, the court ruled that because Frank Sr.â€™s estate had never been probated and there had not been any quiet title action, the Greenes could not establish their title to the property as Frank Sr.â€™s heirs.Â  On the Greenesâ€™ claim for fraud, the court ruled they had failed to establish all of the essential elements for the cause of action.Â  Thus, the probate court denied the Greenesâ€™ claims against Andersonâ€™s estate.Â  The circuit court affirmed the probate courtâ€™s order.Â  This appeal followed. Â Â 
DISCUSSION
1.     Standard of review 
The Greenes first argue the circuit court applied the incorrect standard of review in deciding the appeal of the probate courtâ€™s order.Â  We disagree. 
On appeal from the final order of the probate court, the circuit court should apply the same standard of review that the Supreme Court or Court of Appeals would apply on appeal.Â  In re Howard, 315 S.C. 356, 361, 434 S.E.2d 254, 257 (1993).Â  This appeal involves a claim for money due from an estate and a claim for fraud.Â  As the circuit court correctly held, both are actions at law.Â  See Howard v. Mutz, 315 S.C. 356, 362, 434 S.E.2d 254, 258 (1993) (stating a claim for money due from an estate sounds in law); Perry v. Heirs at Law and Distributees of Charles Gadsden, 313 S.C. 296, 301, 437 S.E.2d 174, 177 (Ct.App.1993) affâ€™d as modified by 316 S.C. 224, 449 S.E.2d 250 (1994) (stating fraud is an action at law unless an equitable remedy is sought).Â  Thus, we hold the circuit court did not err in applying the standard of review for an action at law.Â  
This standard of review provides: â€œon appeal of a case tried without a jury, the findings of fact of the judge will not be disturbed upon appeal unless found to be without evidence which reasonably supports the judgeâ€™s findings.â€Â 
Townes Associates, Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â  However, the appellate court may correct errors of law without deference to the lower court.Â  State ex rel Condon v. City of Columbia, 339 S.C. 8, 13, 528 S.E.2d 408, 410 (2000).
2.     Ownership of property 
The Greenes next argue the probate court erred in denying their creditorâ€™s claim because they had not established an ownership interest in the properties. 
We agree with the Greenes that the probate court committed an error of law by holding that the deeds into the Greenes were invalid due to the forged signatures.Â  â€œWhere the signature of one grantor on a deed is genuine but the signature of the other grantor is a forgery, the deed is only partially valid and is effective to convey only the interest of the grantor whose interest is genuine.â€ 23 Am.Jur.2d Deeds Â§ 164 (2002).Â  Neither party challenges the probate courtâ€™s conclusion that the Greenesâ€™ signatures on the deed were forged.Â  However, there was no evidence presented at the hearing that Andersonâ€™s signatures on the deeds were also forged.Â  Thus, while the transfers of the Greenesâ€™ interests through the deeds were invalid, the transfers of Andersonâ€™s interests to the Greenes were valid and effectively conveyed her interests.Â  
In addition, we find the probate court erred in holding the Greenes failed to establish title or ownership to real property absent probate of Frank Sr.â€™s estate, a quiet title suit, or a confirmation of title action. 
Title to real property vests in the heir or heirs immediately on the death of the intestate, subject to probate administration.Â  Carter v. Wroten, 187 S.C. 432, 435, 198 S.E. 13, 15 (1938); S.C. Jur. Descent & Distribution, Â§ 24 (1998).Â  â€œIn fact the proof of death of an intestate decedent raises the presumption that his real property descended to his heirs.â€Â  28 S.C. Jur. Descent & Distribution Â§ 24 (citing Pinkney v. Knowles, 112 S.C. 7, 10, 99 S.E. 354, 355 (1919)).Â  From the record it appears the Greenes and Anderson were Frank Sr.â€™s heirs at law, that Frank Sr. owned the disputed properties, and that he died intestate.Â  We find the probate court committed an error of law in holding the Greenes could not establish their rights to the properties absent probate administration of Frank Sr.â€™s estate or action to quiet title or confirm title.Â  However, as it is unclear whether the Greenes and Anderson were Frank Sr.â€™s only heirs, the court on remand should determine the Greenesâ€™ intestate interests in the properties and Andersonâ€™s intestate interests that passed to the Greenes through the deeds. 
3.     Fraud 
Finally, the Greenes argue the probate court erred in finding they failed to establish a cause of action for fraud.Â  We disagree.Â  

In order to establish actual fraud, a party must prove:Â  
  
(1) a representation; (2) its falsity; (3) its materiality; (4) either knowledge of its falsity or reckless disregard of its truth or falsity; (5) intent that the representation be acted upon; (6) the hearerâ€™s ignorance of its falsity; (7) the hearerâ€™s reliance on its truth; (8) the hearerâ€™s right to rely thereon; and (9) the hearerâ€™s consequent and proximate injury.
  

Sorin Equip. Co. v. The Firm, Inc., 323 S.C. 359, 365, 474 S.E.2d 819, 823 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  To establish constructive fraud, the party must establish all elements of actual fraud except the element of intent.Â 
Ardis v. Cox, 314 S.C. 512, 516, 431 S.E.2d 267, 269 (Ct. App.1993).Â  The failure to prove any element of fraud is fatal to the action.Â 
Sorin Equip Co., 323 S.C. at 366, 474 S.E.2d at 823. Furthermore, â€œ[f]raud cannot be presumed; it must be proved by clear, cogent, and convincing evidence.â€Â  Foxfire Village, Inc. v. Black & Veatch, Inc., 304 S.C. 366, 374, 404 S.E.2d 912, 917 (Ct. App. 1991).
The probate court held the Greenes failed to establish the element of misrepresentation.Â  The Greenes maintained that they knew nothing about the deeds or the rents collected by Anderson until after Andersonâ€™s death.Â  We agree with the probate court that the record is entirely devoid of any evidence of any type of representation, either verbal or by conduct made to them by Anderson.Â  
The Greenes correctly assert that â€œacts, conduct, or supression of the truth may constitute fraud.â€Â  See Carter v. Boyd Constr., 255 S.C. 274, 178 S.E.2d 536 (1971).Â  However, â€œ[n]on-disclosure becomes fraudulent concealment only when it is the duty of the party having knowledge of the facts to make them known to the other party to the transaction.â€Â  Lawson v. Citizens & S. Natl.Â  Bank of S.C., 259 S.C. 477, 481-82, 193 S.E.2d 124, 126 (1972).Â  Although the Greenes assert â€œDeloris Anderson had an implicit duty to advise the Appellants of their ownership[,]â€ they fail to set forth any basis upon which such a duty to disclose arose.Â  See Regions Bank v. Schmauch, 354 S.C. 648, 673-74, 582 S.E.2d 432, 445-46 (Ct. App. 2003) (stating the duty to disclose may arise from (1) a preexisting fiduciary relationship; (2) where in the particular transaction in question one party expressly reposes a trust and confidence in the other or where from the circumstances of the case, the nature of their dealings, or their position towards each other, such a trust and confidence in the particular case is necessarily implied; and (3) â€œwhere the very contract or transaction itself, in its essential nature, is intrinsically fiduciary and necessarily calls for perfect good faith and full disclosure without regard to any particular intention of the partiesâ€).Â  
Not only did the Greenes fail to present any evidence of a representation, they also failed to present evidence of their detrimental reliance or their right to rely.Â  Accordingly, we agree with the probate court that the Greenesâ€™ claim of fraud fails as a matter of law.Â  
CONCLUSION
We affirm the circuit courtâ€™s affirmance of the probate courtâ€™s denial of the Greenesâ€™ claims for fraud.Â  We reverse the circuit courtâ€™s affirmance of the probate courtâ€™s order holding the Greenes may not maintain a claim for money due from Andersonâ€™s estate and remand for further proceedings.Â  
AFFIRMED IN PART AND REVERSED IN PART AND REMANDED.
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

title: Huggins v. Catledge
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Dianne Elizabeth Huggins, Appellant,
v.
Christopher W. Catledge, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lancaster County
Brooks P. Goldsmith, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-101
Submitted February 1, 2006 â€“ Filed February 17, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Mitchell A. Norrell, of Lancaster, for Appellant.
Philip E. Wright, of Lancaster, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Dianne Elizabeth Huggins appeals from the family courtâ€™s denial of her action for a change of custody of the partiesâ€™ minor son.Â  We affirm. [1]  
FACTS
Huggins and Christopher W. Catledge were divorced in 2000.Â  In accordance with the partiesâ€™ joint custody agreement, Catledge was granted primary custody of their son Christian.Â  At the time of the hearing in this action, Christian was seven.Â  In September of 2003, Huggins brought the current action seeking a change of custody.Â  In her complaint, Huggins requested a guardian ad litem be appointed.Â  After a temporary hearing on July 8, 2004, the family court sent a letter to Catledgeâ€™s attorney with instructions for preparation of an order.Â  In this letter, the court denied Hugginsâ€™ request for appointment of the guardian.Â  The record on appeal, however, does not contain any order from this hearing.Â  
After a final hearing, the family court issued an order holding the change of circumstances relied upon by Huggins was insufficient to justify a change of custody.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, this court may find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 414 S.E.2d 157 (1992).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the family courtâ€™s findings.Â  Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 561 S.E.2d 610 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Nor must we ignore the fact that the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Cherry v. Thomasson, 276 S.C. 524, 280 S.E.2d 541 (1981).Â  Our broad scope of review does not relieve appellant of her burden to convince this Court that the family court committed error.Â  Skinner v. King, 272 S.C. 520, 522-23, 252 S.E.2d 891, 892 (1979).
LAW/ANALYSIS
1.     Guardian ad Litem
Huggins argues the family court erred in refusing to appoint a guardian ad litem.Â  We first question whether this issue is properly before this court.Â  After the temporary hearing, the family court sent a letter to the parties stating that it was denying the request for appointment of a guardian.Â  Although the court instructed Catledgeâ€™s attorney to prepare an order, it does not appear from the record that any such order was ever entered.Â  
An order is not final until it is written and entered by the clerk of court. Â First Union Natâ€™l Bank of S.C. v. Hitman, Inc., 306 S.C. 327, 411 S.E.2d 681 (Ct. App. 1991), affâ€™d, 308 S.C. 421, 418 S.E.2d 545 (1992).Â  Until an order is written and entered by the clerk of court, the judge retains discretion to change his mind and amend his ruling accordingly.Â  Id.Â  An oral ruling is not a final ruling on the merits nor is it binding on the parties until it has been reduced to writing, signed by the judge, and delivered for recordation.Â  Bayne v. Bass, 302 S.C. 208, 394 S.E.2d 726 (Ct.App.1990) The Decree must be in writing and until such time the judge may modify, amend or rescind such an oral ruling.Â  Id.Â  
The family court in its letter even cautioned:Â  â€œAs always, I reserve the right to change or modify this decision prior to signing the order.â€Â  Accordingly, we find that as Huggins failed to secure a final ruling on request for appointment of a guardian, she may not raise this issue on appeal.Â  
Furthermore, we find no reversible error in the family courtâ€™s denial of the request for appointment of a guardian.Â  

Section 20-7-1545 provides:
  
In a private action before the family court in which custody or visitation of a minor child is an issue, the court may appoint a guardian ad litem only when it determines that:
(1) without a guardian ad litem, the court will likely not be fully informed about the facts of the case and there is a substantial dispute which necessitates a guardian ad litem; or
(2) both parties consent to the appointment of a guardian ad litem who is approved by the court . . . .
  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1545 (Supp. 2005) (emphasis added).
In private actions, a guardian â€œfunctions as a representative of the court, appointed to assist the court in making its determination of custody by advocating for the best interest of the children and providing the court with an objective view.â€Â  Patel v. Patel, 347 S.C. 281, 287, 555 S.E.2d 386, 389 (2001).Â  However, the family court judge, not the guardian, is the ultimate decision-maker with respect to visitation and the best interest of the child.Â  Arnal v. Arnal, 363 S.C. 268, 609 S.E.2d 821 (Ct. App. 2005). 
In its letter, the court stated it was temporarily denying the request for a guardian noting that it could not make a finding that it would not be fully informed of the facts without such an appointment.Â  The parties presented numerous witnesses who testified as to Christianâ€™s education, dental care, and home life, and the new stability in the motherâ€™s life.Â  The family court, which was the ultimate decision maker with regards to the custody of the child, was able to make its decision based on the evidence presented.Â  Accordingly, we find no error in its denial of Hugginsâ€™ request for appointment of a guardian.Â  
2.Â  Change of custody
Huggins argues the family court erred in failing to find a change of circumstances sufficient to warrant a change of custody and in holding it was in Christianâ€™s best interests to stay with his father.Â  We disagree.Â  
Because the best interest of the child is the overriding concern in all child custody matters, when a non-custodial parent seeks a change in custody, the non-custodial parent must establish the following:Â  (1) there has been a substantial change in circumstances affecting the welfare of the child and (2) a change in custody is in the overall best interests of the child.Â  Latimer v. Farmer, 360 S.C. 375, 602 S.E.2d 32 (2004).Â  As the one seeking the change of custody, Huggins bears the burden of establishing both of these criteria.Â  Id.Â  In reaching a determination as to custody, the family court should consider how the custody decision will impact all areas of the childâ€™s life, including physical, psychological, spiritual, educational, familial, emotional, and recreational aspects.Â  Additionally, the court must assess each partyâ€™s character, fitness, and attitude as they impact the child.Â  Shirley v. Shirley, 342 S.C. 324, 330, 536 S.E.2d 427, 430 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  
Huggins asserts several changed circumstances that she claims justify a change of circumstances.Â  Since the original custody agreement, Huggins has remarried and established a more stable home environment.Â  She and her new husband have a child, who was nineteen months old at the time of the hearing.Â  Remarriage alone is not sufficient to warrant a change in custody.Â  Fisher v. Miller, 288 S.C. 576, 344 S.E.2d 149 (1986).Â  Catledge has also moved since the divorce.Â  The supreme court held, â€œ[A] change in Fatherâ€™s residence is not itself a substantial change in circumstances affecting the welfare of Child, which justifies a change in custody.â€Â  Latimer, 360 S.C. at 382, 602 S.E.2d at 35.
Huggins contends that she has now taken a job that allows her to spend more time with the child than the father can.Â  Huggins works until 3:30 each day and would be able to be with Christian until his bedtime.Â  Catledge is currently working third shift, from 10:00 p.m. until 6:00 a.m, Sunday through Thursday.Â  On the nights he works, Christian and Catledgeâ€™s daughter from a prior relationship spend the night at Catledgeâ€™s motherâ€™s home.Â  Catledgeâ€™s mother testified the children love staying with her overnight.Â  Although Catledge may be away from the children while they sleep, he is available to care for them during normal waking hours.Â  
Huggins also contends that Catledge neglected Christianâ€™s dental care.Â  At his visit on June 13, 2002, Christian was diagnosed as having four cavities in his back teeth.Â  The dentistâ€™s records clerk testified that children usually do not lose these teeth until they are ten to twelve years old.Â  Christian missed the next scheduled appointment a month later and did not return to the dentist until over a year later.Â  At that time, in addition to one new cavity, the four original cavities remained with one in need of a possible pulpectomy[2].Â  Catledge testified that the dentist told him that he had an option of delaying treatment if the cavities were not causing the child any pain.Â  In addition, Catledge stated the delay was due to his trying to obtain insurance cards from Huggins so he could take Christian to the dentist.Â  Christian has since had the cavities filled one at a time and is having regular dental visits.Â  The family court concluded that the childâ€™s dental needs were not neglected by the father.Â  
Finally, Huggins contends the fact that Christian failed first grade is grounds for a change of custody.Â  Christianâ€™s teacher testified that although the child was well behaved in class, he was a slow learner who did better in math than in reading.Â  His performance was inconsistent with his doing better one six-weeks and then not as well the next six-weeks.Â  She stated that there were times when he needed extra help at home and Catledge always responded to her requests for extra help, including coming in for conferences.Â  Catledge authorized the child to enroll in the programs available to assist Christian and Christian successfully completed these programs.Â  However, at the end of the year, Christian was right on the borderline and after conferencing, the teacher and Catledge decided to hold the child back.Â  The teacher testified there was nothing that could have been done over the summer that would have enabled the child to be promoted to second grade.Â  
Huggins admitted that she had no contact with Christianâ€™s school until after she learned that he would not be promoted.Â  At this point she contacted a tutor for the child, although Catledge hired someone else to tutor him.Â  In addition, after Catledge informed her no summer school was available, Huggins discovered an available summer school program, which Catledge enrolled the child in.Â  However, Catledge allowed the child to miss one week of the four-week class to go to church camp.Â  Huggins acknowledged that at the time of the hearing, the child was doing fine in school with no extra tutorial help.Â  We find no evidence that Catledge was neglectful of the childâ€™s educational needs.Â  
The child attends church with Catledge at the same church Hugginsâ€™ parents attend.Â  Catledge testified the child is in the R.A. program and would be playing on the basketball team.Â  Catledge will be coaching.Â  
The family court noted that both parties acknowledge that the other party is a fit parent.Â  It held, â€œ[The child] is doing well in the care of his father in an environment where he is comfortable and surrounded by family and friends.Â  Disrupting that custodial arrangement would not be in his best interests.â€Â  An appellate court â€œshould be reluctant to substitute its own evaluation of the evidence on child custody for that of the trial court.â€Â  Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996).Â  Considering the record as a whole, we find no error in the family courtâ€™s denial of Hugginsâ€™ request for a change of custody.Â  
CONCLUSION
The order of the family court denying Hugginsâ€™ request for a change of custody based on a change of circumstances is 
 AFFIRMED.Â  
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] There is no evidence in the record that the child actually had a pulpectomy.Â

title: State v. Jackson
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Raymond Jackson, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â Roger L. Couch, Special Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-102
Submitted February 1, 2006 â€“ Filed February 17, 2006

APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Tara S. Taggart, Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliot, Office of the Attorney General, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Raymond Jackson appeals his conviction for distribution of crack cocaine.Â  He argues the trial court erred in denying a directed verdict of acquittal because the State did not present sufficient evidence of his guilt.Â  We review the refusal of a directed verdict in the light most favorable to the State.Â  State v. Creech, 314 S.C. 76, 441 S.E.2d 635 (Ct. App. 199).Â  In a criminal case, the trial court is concerned with the existence or nonexistence of evidence, not with its weight.Â  State v. Mitchell, 341 S.C. 406, 535 S.E.2d 126 (2000).Â  The trial court must submit the case to the jury â€œif there is any substantial evidence which reasonably tends to prove the guilt of the accused, or from which his guilt may be fairly and logically deduced.â€Â  Id.Â  
In this case, the State presented ample evidence reasonably tending to prove Jacksonâ€™s guilt.Â  Two police officers testified to the controlled drug purchase that led to the arrest of Jackson for distribution of crack cocaine.Â  The officers hired another individual to perform the purchase; that individual wore a wire during the transaction, which recorded Jackson, and identified Jackson in court as the purchaser of the crack cocaine.Â  Therefore, the trial court did not err in denying Jacksonâ€™s motion for directed verdict.Â  Accordingly, after a thorough review of the record and Jacksonâ€™s brief pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), and State v. Williams, 305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we dismiss[1] defendantâ€™s appeal and grant counselâ€™s motion to be relieved. 
APPEAL DISMISSED.
HEARN, C.J., and ANDERSON and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Charles E. Avery Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From McCormick County
William P. Keesley, III, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-103
Submitted February 1, 2006 â€“ Filed February 17, 2006

APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.

title: State v. Knight
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Johnny L. Knight, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Anderson County
Â Alexander S. Macaulay, Circuit Court Judge
Â J. Cordell Maddox, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-109
Heard December 6, 2005 â€“ Filed February 21, 2006

REVERSED


  
    
      
David F. Stoddard, of Anderson, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General David A. Spencer, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Christina Theos Adams, of Anderson; for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Johnny Knight was convicted of possession of methamphetamine (or â€œcrankâ€) and sentenced to two years imprisonment, suspended upon the service of two years probation.Â  We reverse.Â  
FACTS
On July 3, 2003, Deputy Stanley Jones, Jr., from the Anderson County Sheriffâ€™s Department noticed a vehicle weaving on the road, and he stopped the vehicle.Â  After the female driver failed the field sobriety test, Deputy Jones arrested her for driving under the influence.Â  A search incident to arrest produced crank.Â  Deputy Jones also ordered the passenger, Knight, to get out of the vehicle.Â  Jones noticed a large bulge in Knightâ€™s left pants pocket, and he feared it was a weapon.Â  After frisking Knight, Jones determined the object felt metallic, and he retrieved brass knuckles from Knightâ€™s pocket.Â  Knight was arrested for possession of a concealed weapon.Â  Pursuant to a search incident to arrest, Jones discovered two grams of crank hidden inside a cigarette package in Knightâ€™s right pocket.Â  An arrest warrant was later issued, charging Knight with possession of crank.Â  The magistrate did not issue a warrant for possession of a concealed weapon because the statute provides an exception for brass knuckles where there is no evidence they were carried in furtherance of a crime.[1]Â  
On February 10, 2004, a hearing was held on Knightâ€™s motion to suppress the crank.Â  Deputy Jones testified regarding the events leading up to Knightâ€™s arrest, and he stated he did not know at the time of Knightâ€™s arrest that carrying brass knuckles without intent to commit a crime was excepted from the concealed weapon statute.Â  In response to questioning by the solicitor, Deputy Jones affirmed there was no evidence that Knight was using the brass knuckles in furtherance of a crime.Â  Knight then moved to suppress the crank evidence, arguing mere possession of brass knuckles, without an intent to commit a crime, was not a crime under the concealed weapon statute.Â  Therefore, he argued, there was no probable cause for the arrest.Â  Finding â€œunder the totality of the circumstances,â€ there was evidence that would cause a prudent person to believe that Knight had committed the offense of carrying a concealed weapon in furtherance of the crime of unlawful possession of a controlled substance, the trial court held the arrest was valid and denied the motion to suppress.Â  
In lieu of pleading guilty, Knight elected to have a bench trial because he wanted to preserve the suppression issue for appeal.Â  The parties agreed the State could summarize the testimony of Deputy Jones for the court instead of having Jones testify.Â  The State summarized Deputy Jonesâ€™s testimony for the court.Â  Although Knight stipulated the substance found was crank, he renewed his objection to the search that led to the discovery of the crank evidence.Â  Knight did not present any evidence after the court denied his motion for a directed verdict.Â  The trial court found Knight guilty as charged and sentenced him to two years imprisonment, suspended upon the service of two years probation.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only and is bound by the factual findings of the trial court unless clearly erroneous.Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5-6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).Â  The trial courtâ€™s factual findings on whether evidence should be suppressed due to a Fourth Amendment violation are reviewed only for clear error.Â  State v. Brockman, 339 S.C. 57, 66, 528 S.E.2d 661, 666 (2000).Â  â€œOn appeal from a suppression hearing, this court is bound by the circuit courtâ€™s factual findings if any evidence supports the findings.â€ State v. Abdullah, 357 S.C. 344, 349, 592 S.E.2d 344, 347 (Ct. App. 2004), cert. denied (Nov. 19, 2004).Â  Our review in Fourth Amendment search and seizure cases is â€œlimited to determining whether any evidence supports the trial courtâ€™s finding.â€Â  State v. Green, 341 S.C. 214, 219 n.3, 532 S.E.2d 896, 898 n.3 (Ct. App. 2000). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Knight stipulates the brass knuckles were validly seized pursuant to a Terry[2] search.Â  He argues, however, that there was no probable cause to arrest him for possession of a concealed weapon, and therefore, the search incident to the arrest was unlawful.Â  The State argues that probable cause existed to arrest Knight for possessing the brass knuckles in furtherance of a crime and that, even if the arrest were illegal, the crank was admissible pursuant to inevitable discovery.Â  Because Knight stipulates that Deputy Jones had probable cause to conduct a Terry frisk for weapons, the only question we must address is whether his arrest, and thus, the subsequent search incident to arrest, was valid.Â  
Probable cause for a warrantless arrest exists when, considering the totality of the circumstances surrounding the information at the officerâ€™s disposal, there was sufficient information to cause a reasonable person to believe that criminal activity has been or is being committed.Â  State v. Goodwin, 351 S.C. 105, 110, 567 S.E.2d 912, 914 (Ct. App. 2002); see State v. Moultrie, 316 S.C. 547, 552, 451 S.E.2d 34, 37 (Ct. App. 1994) (â€œ[P]robable cause for a warrantless arrest generally exists â€˜where the facts and circumstances within the arresting officerâ€™s knowledge are sufficient for a reasonable person to believe that a crime has been or is being committed by the person to be arrested.â€™â€(quoting United States v. Miller, 925 F.2d 695, 698 (4th Cir. 1991))).Â  â€œThe burden of establishing probable cause and the existence of circumstances constituting an exception to the general prohibition against warrantless searches is upon the prosecution.â€Â  State v. Freiburger, 366 S.C. 125, 132, 620 S.E.2d 737, 740 (2005).
The concealed weapon statute provides that it is illegal for a person to carry a â€œdeadly weapon usually used for the infliction of personal injuryâ€ concealed on his person.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-23-460 (2003).Â  However, the section further provides that it does not apply to â€œrifles, shotguns, dirks, slingshots, metal knuckles, or razors unless they are used with the intent to commit a crime or in furtherance of a crime.â€Â  Id.Â  There are no South Carolina cases discussing this exception to the concealed weapon statute or what constitutes evidence that the weapon was used with â€œthe intent to commit a crime or in furtherance of a crime.â€Â  
The parties do not dispute that the mere possession of brass knuckles, without more, does not violate the concealed weapon statute.Â  Thus, we must focus our analysis on whether probable cause existed for a warrantless arrest of Knight pursuant to the portion of the statute criminalizing possession of concealed brass knuckles when used in furtherance of a crime.Â  
Reviewing the evidence and the totality of the circumstances surrounding the information at Deputy Jonesâ€™s disposal, we find there was not sufficient information to cause a reasonable person to believe that Knight was concealing brass knuckles in furtherance of a crime.Â  The only evidence presented at trial was the testimony of Deputy Jones, and he affirmatively testified there was no evidence the brass knuckles were being used in furtherance of a crime. Although the State argues the trial court properly considered the totality of the circumstances and found the nexus between weapons and drugs gave rise to probable cause to believe Knight possessed the brass knuckles in furtherance of drug transportation, there is no evidence to support that finding.[3]Â  Based on the only information presented at trial, the State failed to meet its burden of proving probable cause existed.Â  Thus, the arrest was illegal, and the crank discovered in the search incident to the illegal arrest should have been suppressed. 
However, the State further argues:Â  (1) even if the arrest were illegal, the crank was admissible due to inevitable discovery; and (2) the search was reasonable under the circumstances because there was a heightened sense of danger when Deputy Jones discovered the occupants of the vehicle had both weapons and crank.Â  We disagree.
Citing State v. Smith, 329 S.C. 550, 495 S.E.2d 798 (Ct. App. 1998), the State asserts the discovery of the brass knuckles warranted a further weapons frisk â€œwhich would inevitably lead to discovery of the crank.â€Â  Under the inevitable discovery doctrine, evidence that may have been obtained in violation of a defendantâ€™s constitutional protections may, nevertheless, be admitted at trial if it would have been discovered inevitably by some other lawful means.Â  See Nix v. Williams, 467 U.S. 431, 448 (1984) (â€œExclusion of physical evidence that would inevitably have been discovered adds nothing to either the integrity or fairness of a criminal trial.â€).Â  In Smith, this court noted that under the â€œplain feel doctrine,â€ the officer validly seized a baggy containing drugs he felt during a Terry pat-down for weapons because the officer could determine the object was contraband as soon as he felt the baggy, without additional manipulation, and the defendant admitted that the bag contained his â€œreefer.â€Â  Smith, 329 S.C. at 560-61, 495 S.E.2d at 803-04.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
 Smith is inapplicable in the present case.Â  Although discovery of the brass knuckles may have led to a reasonable search to insure Knight had no further weapons, it would not have led to the â€œinevitable discoveryâ€ of the crank.Â  According to Deputy Jonesâ€™s testimony, the crank was discovered inside a cigarette box in Knightâ€™s pocket.Â  Deputy Jones could not have discovered via the â€œplain feel doctrineâ€ that the cigarette box concealed crank.Â  The search of the cigarette box exceeded the bounds of the Terry search.Â  See State v. Abrams, 322 S.C. 286, 289, 471 S.E.2d 716, 718 (Ct. App. 1996) (noting that the limited purpose of Terry was satisfied when the officer discovered there were no weapons on Abrams, and the further search of a Tylenol bottle concealing crack cocaine was impermissible and the drugs should have been suppressed).Â  Thus, we find no merit to the Stateâ€™s argument that the crank concealed in Knightâ€™s cigarette box would have inevitably been discovered during the weapons pat-down.
Despite the Stateâ€™s argument that there is a nexus between drugs and weapons that would lead to probable cause, no evidence was presented in this case that would support probable cause to arrest Knight for possessing a concealed weapon in furtherance of a crime.Â  Because the testimony elicited by the State amounted to a denial of probable cause to arrest Knight, we find the Stateâ€™s argument unavailing.Â  
CONCLUSION
There was no evidence in the present case that Knight possessed the brass knuckles in furtherance of a crime.Â  Thus, Knight was unlawfully arrested and the search incident to arrest was invalid.Â  The trial court erred in failing to suppress the crank found as a result of the invalid search.Â  Accordingly, Knightâ€™s conviction and sentence are
 REVERSED.
HEARN, C.J., HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  It is illegal for a person to carry a concealed deadly weapon.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-23-460 (2003).Â  However, the section further provides that it does not apply to â€œ. . . metal knuckles . . . unless they are used with the intent to commit a crime or in furtherance of a crime.â€Â  Id.  
[2]Â  Terry v. Ohio, 392 U.S. 1, 27 (1968) (noting that an officer must have a reasonable suspicion that an individual is armed and dangerous before conducting a pat-down or frisk of the person).
[3]Â  In support of this argument, the State relies on United States v. Pasquarille, 20 F.3d 682, 686-88 (6th Cir. 1994) (finding probable cause existed to search a van, based on the law enforcement officerâ€™s perspective, where the van and driver met an informantâ€™s description of someone selling cocaine); State v. Butler, 353 S.C. 383, 390-93, 577 S.E.2d 498, 501-02 (Ct. App. 2003) (discussing whether an officer had a reasonable suspicion to conduct a pat- down or frisk of a suspect reasonably believed to be armed); and State v. Blassingame, 338 S.C. 240, 248-50, 525 S.E.2d 535, 539-40 (Ct. App. 1999) (upholding a stop and frisk where the police officer had a reasonable suspicion that Blassingame fit the description of an armed suspect).Â  These cases are factually distinguishable from the present case because they address whether the initial stop or frisk was supported by probable cause based on the officerâ€™s reasonable belief that he was in danger, that the suspect had weapons, or that a crime was being committed.Â  These cases do not address whether a search incident to arrest was supported by probable cause where the officer mistakenly believed the suspectâ€™s actions were criminal or where there was no indication that the suspectâ€™s actions constituted a crime.Â

title: SCDSS v. Smalls
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
South Carolina Department of Social Services, Respondent,
v.
Robin Smalls, and Dontravis Anderson, DOB:Â  08/20/92 and Deandre Anderson, DOB:Â  10/26/93, Minors under the age of 18 years,
Defendants, 
of whom Robin Smalls is Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Darlington County
Timothy L. Brown, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-110
Submitted February 1, 2006 â€“ Filed February 21, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
W. James Hoffmeyer, of Florence, for Appellant.Â  
Newton I. Howle, Jr., of Darlington, for Respondent.
Richard Edward Conner, Jr., of Hartsville, for Guardian Ad Litem.Â  
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Robin Smalls appeals a family court order terminating her parental rights as to her sons Dontravis (DOB:Â  8/20/92) and Deandre (DOB:Â  10/26/93).Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
The South Carolina Department of Social Services filed a complaint seeking to terminate Smallsâ€™ parental rights based on the following contentions:Â  1) the children were removed from and have lived outside of Smallsâ€™ home for a period of at least six months without Smalls remedying the conditions that caused the removal, 2) the children have been in foster care for fifteen of the last twenty-two months, 3) Smalls has willfully failed to support the children or make a material contribution to the childrenâ€™s care, and 4) termination is in the best interests of the children.Â  
The family court held a hearing on March 1, 2005.Â  DSS caseworker Mae Stradford testified the children have been in foster care since 1994.[2]Â  The parental rights of the father have previously been terminated.Â  Smalls was under a court order to pay child support of $21.34 per week.Â  At the time of the hearing, Smalls was $1,053.72 in arrears in support payments.Â  Smalls made her last payment in April 2004.Â  Smalls visited the children on July 28, 2004 and on January 22, 2005.Â  Stradford testified Smalls had not done anything to remedy the conditions causing removal, including failure to follow her treatment plan as to employment, housing, and counseling.Â  Smalls was last employed in the spring of 2004, has recently moved numerous times, and last saw her counselor in July 2004.Â  
Dontravis suffers from cerebral palsy and â€œattention deficit, hyperactive activity disorder,â€ and currently resides in a therapeutic foster home where he has lived since 1994, when he was seventeen months old.Â  The foster parents intend to adopt Dontravis.Â  Deandre suffers from attention deficit disorder and resides in a foster home where he has been since 1994, when he was three months old.Â  He likewise is in the process of being adopted.Â  
Stradford testified the children were in loving homes, had their own rooms, and were much closer to their foster parents than to their mother.Â  Both sets of foster parents provided nurturing homes and had stable employment.Â  The childrenâ€™s basic needs of food, medical care, and education were being met.Â  
On cross-examination, Stradford admitted she knew that in 2003 Smalls began caring for another son, Deshawn (approximately sixteen years old), and daughter, Matia (approximately ten years old), taking sole responsibility for Deshawnâ€™s medication.Â  Stradford also admitted she did not visit Smalls often.Â  She explained, however, that she had been to Smallsâ€™ home six or seven times over a twelve-month period and Smalls was not home or had moved without notification to DSS.Â  Stradford met with Smalls three times during that period.Â  
As to Smallsâ€™ failure to attend counseling, Stradford recognized that Smallsâ€™ counselor was in Florence and Smalls lived in Hartsville, creating a transportation problem.Â  Stradford explained that DSS provided transportation for counseling and on one occasion, Stradford sent a driver to Smallsâ€™ home to transport her to a scheduled counseling session and Smalls was not at her residence.Â  
Nancy Gregg and her two daughters, Chanell and Tamiko, testified on Smallsâ€™ behalf.Â  Chanell testified she has known Smalls for thirteen or fourteen years, Smalls baby-sits Chanellâ€™s daughter, and Smalls keeps a clean house.Â  Chanell testified Smalls spends a lot of time with Matia and Deshawn, helping with homework, ensuring Deshawn takes his medication, and picking the children up every day from the school bus.Â  Chanell pays Smalls $50 per week for babysitting services.Â  Tamiko testified in a like manner regarding Smallsâ€™ lifestyle.Â  Smalls baby-sits Tamikoâ€™s two children overnight while Tamiko works third shift.Â  Tamiko claimed she did not pay Smalls for babysitting services.Â  Nancy also testified Smalls was a good mother.Â  Nancy explained that Smalls has a two-bedroom apartment and a pullout couch.Â  Nancy admitted, â€œon any given day there would be four or five childrenâ€ in the apartment.Â  
Smalls testified she missed appointments with the counselor when she moved.Â  She explained she earned a parenting certificate and tried to do everything required by the treatment plan.Â  As to child support, she testified she paid regularly until she lost her job in April 2004.Â  She lost her job due to her move to Hartsville and resulting lack of transportation.Â  Smalls still has a valid certified nursing assistant certificate and explained her job search since then:Â  â€œWhen I moved back to Hartsville, I was looking for a job in that same career, doing like nursing homes, but I called one but it was . . . too far to even . . . walk. . . .â€Â  She also applied to a few fast food restaurants.Â  Transportation allegedly remains the main impediment to Smallsâ€™ employment.Â  As to visitation, Smalls testified she would sometimes call DSS to set up a visit, but she did not have a telephone to receive return calls.Â  She recently purchased a cellular phone but has never called Dontravis or Deandre.Â  Smalls testified she no longer receives AFDC assistance, but does receive food stamps, a utility check, and free living accommodations.Â  
The family court terminated Smallsâ€™ parental rights to Dontravis and Deandre.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn a termination of parental rights
(TPR) case, the best interests of the children are the paramount consideration.â€Â  Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 579, 578 S.E.2d 733, 735 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Before a parentâ€™s rights may be terminated, the alleged grounds for termination must be proven by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Department of Soc. Servs. v. Mrs. H, 346 S.C. 329, 333, 550 S.E.2d 898, 901 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  On appeal, this court may review the record and make its own determination of whether the grounds for termination are supported by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Id.Â  However, our broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the findings of the family court or ignore the fact that the family court was in a better position to assess the credibility of the witnesses.Â  Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 452, 477 S.E.2d 476, 480 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
The family court terminated Smallsâ€™ parental rights upon finding:Â  (1) the children lived outside the home for a period of at least six months and Smalls willfully failed to provide support, 2) the children lived in foster care for fifteen of the last twenty-two months, and (3) termination was in the best interests of the children.Â  Smalls appeals, raising three issues. 
Smalls first argues the family court erred in finding she willfully failed to pay child support.Â  Smalls contends her failure to pay child support was not willful but due to her loss of employment.Â  The family court may order termination of parental rights upon a finding of the following:

The child has lived outside the home of either parent for a period of six months, and during that time the parent has wilfully failed to support the child.Â  Failure to support means that the parent has failed to make a material contribution to the childâ€™s care.Â  A material contribution consists of either financial contributions according to the parentâ€™s means or contributions of food, clothing, shelter, or other necessities for the care of the child according to the parentâ€™s means.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(4) (Supp. 2005).Â  Whether a parentâ€™s failure to support a child is willful is a question of intent to be determined from all the facts and circumstances in each case.Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Broome, 307 S.C. 48, 52, 413 S.E.2d 835, 838 (1992).Â  The trial judge is given wide discretion in making this determination.Â  Id.Â  However, the element of willfulness must be established by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Id.Â  â€œParental conduct â€˜which evinces a settled purpose to forego parental duties may fairly be characterized as â€˜willfulâ€™ because it manifests a conscious indifference to the rights of the child to receive support and consortium from the parent.â€™â€Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Smith, 343 S.C. 129, 137, 538 S.E.2d 285, 289 (Ct. App. 2000) (quoting Broome, 307 S.C. at 53, 413 S.E.2d at 839).
The family court found Smalls voluntarily left her employment to move to Hartsville, and that she received some money from babysitting.Â  There is also evidence Smalls received financial support from family members and money from other sources, such as a â€œutility check.â€Â  However, Smalls made no child support payments after April 2004.Â  Furthermore, Smalls has made only sporadic attempts to secure employment to improve her ability to pay child support.Â  We find support to justify the courtâ€™s finding that Smallsâ€™ failure to pay child support constitutes willfulness sufficient to justify termination.Â  
Smalls next argues the family court erred in terminating parental rights based on the children living outside the home for fifteen of the last twenty-two months because Smalls has not had the opportunity to live with the children since 1994 and it has been DSSâ€™s plan to terminate her parental rights since that time.Â  Our statutory scheme provides a ground for termination of parental rights where the child has been in foster care under the responsibility of the State for fifteen of the most recent twenty-two months.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(8) (Supp. 2005).Â  As the children have been in foster care since 1994, there is clear and convincing evidence to support the family courtâ€™s finding to that effect.Â  
Finally, Smalls argues the family court erred in finding termination was in the best interest of the children.Â  We disagree.Â  Having found at least one ground on which the family court properly terminated Smallsâ€™ parental rights, we need only determine that termination of Smallsâ€™ rights is in the best interest of the children.Â  The interests of the child shall prevail if the childâ€™s interests and the parental rights conflict.Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Parker, 336 S.C. 248, 259, 519 S.E.2d 351, 356 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Dontravis and Deandre have resided with their foster parents since infancy, for over twelve years.Â  Both foster families have expressed interest in adoption.Â  Although the children know their mother, their contact with her has been sporadic and infrequent.Â  The guardian agreed termination was in the best interest of the children.Â  We find clear and convincing evidence that termination is in the best interest of the children.
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated above, the family courtâ€™s termination of Smallsâ€™ parental rights as to Dontravis and Deandre is

    AFFIRMED.
    
    GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]  For background facts of the removal of the children, refer to South Carolina Department of Social Services v. Smalls, 2000-UP-275 (Ct. App. 2000).

title: Perkins v. Zeigler
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Vanessa Perkins, Respondent,
v.
Curtis Zeigler and Curtis Zeigler d/b/a Windjammer 3000 and Joe Green, Defendants,/Of whom Curtis Zeigler and Curtis Zeigler d/b/a Windjammer 3000 are,
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Berkeley County
Robert E. Watson, Master-in-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-111
Submitted February 1, 2006 â€“ Filed February 21, 2006Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Christopher Joseph Louden, of Moncks Corner, for Appellant.
Vanessa Perkins, of Decatur, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Curtis Zeigler appeals from the master-in-equityâ€™s order awarding Vanessa Perkins $150,000 in damages on her breach of contract claim.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
FACTS
On January 24, 2002, Zeigler and Perkins entered into a commercial lease contract for Zeigler to lease property from Perkins in Moncks Corner known as Windjammer 3000.Â  As a condition of the lease, Zeigler was to maintain comprehensive property damage insurance on the property in the amount of at least $200,000.Â  The building on the property was totally destroyed by fire on June 9, 2002.Â  Unfortunately, Zeigler failed to secure insurance on the property.
Perkins brought this action for breach of contract due to Zeiglerâ€™s failure to maintain insurance as required by the lease, seeking $150,000 in damages.Â  Although Zeigler admitted he did not have insurance on the property, he denied Perkinsâ€™ other allegations.Â  Furthermore, in his amended answer, he asserted Perkins did not own the property at the time she entered into the lease with him and therefore, the lease agreement was void ab initio. 
The master upheld the lease and awarded Perkins $150,000 in damages.Â  Zeigler filed a motion for a new trial and to amend the judgment.Â  The master vacated the previous order to issue a new order again upholding the lease and awarding Perkins $150,000.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An action for breach of contract seeking damages is an action at law.Â  Sterling Dev. Co. v. Collins, 309 S.C. 237, 240, 421 S.E.2d 402, 404 (1992).Â  In an action at law tried without a jury, the trial courtâ€™s factual findings will not be disturbed on appeal unless those findings are wholly unsupported by the evidence or controlled by an error of law.Â  Gordon v. Colonial Ins. Co. of California, 342 S.C. 152, 155, 536 S.E.2d 376, 378 (Ct. App. 2000).

DISCUSSION
Zeigler asserts the trial court applied an incorrect measure of damages.Â  He contends Perkinsâ€™ recovery is limited by her ownership interest in the property.Â  We disagree.
The property on which the Windjammer 3000 was located had been owned by Stephan Bash, who died intestate.Â  In 1986, his heirs executed a deed delineating the ownership interest of each heir.Â  Under this deed Perkins received 1.785% ownership in the property.Â  Perkins testified that she and her sister subsequently inherited their motherâ€™s 1.785% interest.[2]Â  
The Supreme Court of Mississippi recognized that within insurance law, there are two lines of cases regarding whether a co-tenant may insure the entire property and receive all insurance proceeds.Â  Sullivan v. Estate of Eason, 558 So.2d 830, 833 (Miss. 1990).Â  It noted:Â  

â€œThe general rule, sustained by the great weight of authority, is, in the absence of anything in the instrument creating the estate, or of agreement to that effect, between the parties, no duty rests upon the one or the other to insure for the benefit of the remainderman or his cotenant, and insurance taken by one with an insurable interest in the property, who pays the premiums thereon out of his own funds, is a personal indemnity to the insured. . . .

Id. at 833 (quoting Bell v. Barefield, 122 So. 318, 319 (Ala. 1929) (alteration in original).Â  The other line of cases holds that one securing insurance for the benefit of the other insurable interests in property holds the proceeds in trust for those interests.Â  Id.
Although the second line of cases requires cotenants to share in insurance proceeds, these cases do not afford Zeigler a defense to payment of the full amount of damages.Â  At the most, Perkins would be considered to be holding the proceeds in trust for her cotenants.[3]Â  
In South Carolina Insurance Company v. Price, 315 S.C. 212, 432 S.E.2d 508 (Ct. App. 1993), the named insured obtained insurance on property owned by BroSis, a partnership consisting of the named insured and his siblings.Â  After the building burned down, the insurance company brought an action claiming that it was liable only for the named insuredâ€™s share of the value of the building.Â  This court relied on the Valued Policy Statute, which holds, â€œThe amount of insurance must be fixed by the insurer and insured at or before the time of issuing the policy.Â  In case of total loss by fire the insured is entitled to recover the full amount of insurance.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-75-20 (2002).Â  Thus, this court held that the insurer was obligated to pay the full value of the building rather than the named insuredâ€™s fractional share.Â  Id.Â  at 213, 432 S.E.2d at 508-09.
Under the lease, Zeigler was required to insure the premises, which he failed to do.Â  Thus, as a remedy for breach of this provision of the lease, Perkins is entitled to the amount she would have received from the insurance.Â  See South Carolina Fed. Sav. Bank v. Thornton-Crosby Dev. Co., 303 S.C. 74, 77, 399 S.E.2d 8, 10 (Ct. App. 1990) (â€œIn a breach of contract action, damages serve to place the nonbreaching party in the position he would have enjoyed had the contract been performed.â€).Â  We find no error in the masterâ€™s determination that Perkinsâ€™ recovery from Zeigler should not be limited in proportion to her fractional ownership interest in the property.Â  Accordingly, the order of the master awarding Perkins $150,000[4] in damages is 
 AFFIRMED.Â Â Â Â Â  
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] In his order, the master noted that Anatha Bash, one of the heirs of Stephen Bash, testified that the family had given the land and building to Perkinsâ€™ mother to be used without any compensation being given to any other heirs.Â  Perkins, thus, had total use of the building in question with approval of the heirs of Stephen Bash.Â  Zeigler presented no evidence challenging this testimony.
[3] As this is not a dispute between the cotenants over the proceeds of the policy, we take no position as to which line of cases this court would follow in such a dispute and whether Perkins would have to share the proceeds. 
[4]Â  In her Respondentâ€™s brief, Perkins appears to request this court increase the amount of the damages the master awarded her.Â  As Perkins failed to appeal this award, we decline to address this request.Â

PER CURIUM:Â  Kenneth Edwards appeals a family court order registering a North Carolina judgment against him for child support and other costs, claiming North Carolina did not have personal jurisdiction.Â  Because Edwards was aware of the North Carolina actions and subject to North Carolinaâ€™s jurisdiction, as evidenced by the signed certified mail receipt and the affidavit from the wifeâ€™s attorney, we find the order valid and remaining in effect.Â  We affirm the trial courtâ€™s finding that Edwards should continue to pay $300 per month on the arrears due in his child support case pursuant to Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR, and the following authorities:[1]Â  S.
