title: Brunson v. Brunson
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
David T. Brunson, Appellant,
v.
Chantalle M. C. Brunson, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Paul W. Garfinkel, Family Court Judge
Â  Deadra L. Jefferson, Family Court Judge
Â William J. Wylie, Jr., Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-115
Submitted January 1, 2006 â€“ Filed February 22, 2006

AFFIRMED in part, REVERSED in part


  
    
      
Cynthia Barrier Castengera, of Newland and David Dusty Rhoades, of Charleston, for Appellant.
Chantalle Irland, of Lakewood, for Respondent.
Jon A. Mersereau, of Charleston, for Guardian Ad Litem.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: David Brunson appeals several aspects of a family court order that arise from a change of custody dispute with Chantalle Brunson.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part.
FACTS
David Brunson (Father) and Chantalle Brunson[1] (Mother) married in 1994.Â  They have one child, Kristen (Child), born on January 17, 1995.Â  In 1999, the parties divorced based on one yearâ€™s continuous separation.Â  The divorce order approved the partiesâ€™ custody agreement, which awarded joint custody of Child with Motherâ€™s residence being the primary residence.Â  It also required the Brunsons to attend joint counseling sessions.Â  Further, the agreement required Mother to notify Father of her intention to move within sixty days of the move. Â Less than two months after the divorce, Mother and Child relocated without disclosing their whereabouts. 
Based on Motherâ€™s disappearance, Father filed a complaint on May 6, 1999, seeking modification of custody, visitation, and child support.Â  Father alleged he was deprived of visitation and that Mother violated the terms of the court order by not providing notice of her intention to move.Â  Father indicated that he did not know Motherâ€™s exact whereabouts and was unable to personally serve the pleadings.Â  Because Father asserted he had no information about Motherâ€™s whereabouts other than in the Charleston, South Carolina, area, he was granted permission to serve Mother via publication in the local Post and Courier newspaper.Â  
During the initial merits hearing on November 4, 1999, which was not attended by Mother, Judge Jefferson found Mother in violation of the prior order and awarded physical custody to Father.Â  She also included an unusual provision in the order that allowed Mother to challenge the order within five days of personal service.Â  Mother challenged the order in a timely fashion by filing a motion to vacate.Â  The court held a lengthy hearing that extended over several days and resulted in Mother retaining physical custody.Â  
The family court judge heard testimony from Dr. Diane Hamrick, a psychologist.Â  The prior court order required the Brunsons to attend joint counseling sessions with the caveat that â€œunder no circumstances are any of the discussions in these therapy sessions to be admitted into evidence in the Family Court of South Carolina . . . .â€Â  During one of the counseling sessions, Father made a comment that Dr. Hamrick interpreted as a threat on Motherâ€™s life.Â  As a result, Dr. Hamrick withdrew from counseling the Brunsons and reported the threat to the guardian ad litem.Â  Fatherâ€™s exact words and his intent remain in dispute.Â  Father contends his intention was to arrange a date when he said he wished that he had let a friend â€œtake her out when he wanted to.â€Â  Dr. Hamrick, however, recalls Father saying he knew someone who would â€œget rid of her for him.â€Â  
Based on representations in the motion, affidavits, and testimony that Father could not determine Motherâ€™s whereabouts when he requested to serve process by publication, the Judge found that Father and his attorney â€œdeliberately failed to disclose . . . information to the court.â€Â  The court cited an affidavit signed by Father, in which he stated a Charleston area P.O. Box address was â€œthe only address [he had] for her [at the time].â€Â  During the motion to vacate hearing, he further described the â€œextensive measuresâ€ taken to locate Mother and Child.Â  The family court judge determined that at the time the affidavit was signed and the hearings were conducted, Father was aware of a specific address in Colorado that Mother recently used.Â  Father contends this address was an old address and was not valid when he signed the affidavit and gave his testimony.Â  
Mother contends she left the Charleston area because of Fatherâ€™s threats and intimidation.Â  Judge Jefferson continued custody with Mother and awarded her $5,000.00 in attorney fees.Â  Further, the judge found Father violated the divorce decree by failing to comply with a mutual restraining order.
During the motion to vacate hearing, Fatherâ€™s attorney moved for the judge to recuse herself on the grounds that she was biased against him and that she made up her mind on the merits of the case before the conclusion of the testimony.Â  The judge denied the motion.Â  
After concluding all proceedings related to the motion to vacate, the judge recused herself on October 6, 2000.Â  The judge then sent a copy of her order on the motion to vacate to the grievance committee as her complaint against Fatherâ€™s counsel.Â  
Judge Wylie presided over the subsequent trial on the merits and ultimately awarded Mother sole custody of Child, denied the partiesâ€™ requests for attorneysâ€™ fees, and declined to hold Father in contempt. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, the appellate court has authority to find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  This does not require the appellate court, however, to disregard the findings of the family court, which saw and heard the witnesses.Â  McElveen v. McElveen, 332 S.C. 583, 591, 506 S.E.2d 1, 5 (Ct. App. 1998).
â€œIn order for a court to grant a change of custody based on changed circumstances, the party seeking the change must meet the burden of showing changed circumstances occurring subsequent to the entry of the order in question.â€Â  Shirley v. Shirley, 342 S.C. 324, 330, 536 S.E.2d 427, 430 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  â€˜â€œ(T)he change of circumstance relied on for a change of custody must be such as would substantially affect the interest and the welfare of the child, not merely the parties, their wishes or convenienceâ€â€™ Id. (quoting Sharpe v. Sharpe, 256 S.C. 517, 521, 183 S.E.2d 325, 327 (1971)).Â  This change of circumstances must amount to a material change of conditions.Â  Bolding v. Bolding, 278 S.C. 129, 130, 293 S.E.2d 699, 700 (1982) (emphasis added).
Custody decisions are matters left largely to the discretion of the trial court.Â  Stroman v. Williams, 291 S.C. 376, 378, 353 S.E.2d 704, 705 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs either when the court is controlled by some error of law or where the order, based upon findings of fact, lacks evidentiary support.Â  McKnight v. McKnight, 283 S.C. 540, 543, 324 S.E.2d 91, 93 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.      Jurisdiction 
Father contends the family court judge did not have jurisdiction to allow Mother to challenge the initial order by petitioning the family court for review within five days of personal service.Â  We disagree.
â€œA portion of a judgment that is not appealed presents no issue for determination by the reviewing court and constitutes, rightly or wrongly, the law of the case.â€Â  Austin v. Specialty Transp. Servs., 358 S.C. 298, 320, 594 S.E.2d 867, 878 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  It is a fundamental rule of law that an appellate court will affirm a trial courtâ€™s ruling if the offended party does not challenge that ruling.Â  Biales v. Young, 315 S.C. 166, 168, 432 S.E.2d 482, 484 (1993).Â  Failure to challenge the ruling â€œis an abandonment of the issue and precludes consideration on appeal.â€Â  Id. at 168, 432 S.E.2d at 484.Â  
The judgeâ€™s order dated December 21, 1999, allowed Mother to challenge her ruling.Â  Specifically, the judge stated she â€œheard only one part of the story regarding issues raised by the pleadingsâ€ and, as a result, provided Mother with an opportunity to challenge the order and â€œreview its decision.â€Â  Father did not appeal this order.Â  Since Father did not challenge any part of this order, it is the law of the case and may not be altered on appeal.
II.Â  The Order of Publication
Father argues the judge erred by finding the order of publication defective.Â  We disagree.
The judge found the original order of publication defective because of misrepresentations Father made to the court.Â  An order of publication is properly issued when it is supported by an affidavit alleging that the affiant has exercised due diligence and was unable to find the person to be served.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-9-710 (2005).Â  â€œThe [statute] does not specify the character of the facts and circumstances which must be stated in the affidavit or the quantity of evidence necessary to satisfy the officer before ordering publication.Â  It simply requires that it must appear to [the issuing officerâ€™s] satisfaction . . . [and] when he is satisfied, in the absence of fraud or collusion, it is final.â€Â  Yarbrough v. Collins, 293 S.C. 290, 292-93, 360 S.E.2d 300, 301 (1987).Â  
In this case, the judge found that Father and his attorney possessed information regarding Motherâ€™s whereabouts, namely a letter from a private investigator, which supplied recently used addresses in Colorado.Â  Concluding that the decision to allow notice by publication was based on deception, the family court determined the order was defective.Â  Because there is evidence in the record to support the judgeâ€™s conclusion, it will not be disturbed on appeal.Â  
III.Â  Recusal
Father contends the judge erred by not recusing herself.Â  We disagree.
â€œA judge should disqualify [herself] in a proceeding in which [her] impartiality might reasonably be questioned,â€ including, but not limited to, instances where she has a personal bias or prejudice against a party.Â  Murphy v. Murphy, 319 S.C. 324, 331, 461 S.E.2d 39, 42 (1995).Â  â€œIt is not enough for a party to allege bias; a party seeking disqualification of a judge must show some evidence of bias or prejudice.â€Â  Christensen v. Mikell, 324 S.C. 70, 74, 476 S.E.2d 692, 694 (1996).Â  However, such â€œbias must stem from an extrajudicial source and result in [decisions] based on information other than what the judge learned from [her] participation in the case.â€Â  Roper v. Dynamique Concepts, Inc., 316 S.C. 131, 139, 447 S.E.2d 218, 223 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  â€œ[R]eversal is mandated only where there is evidence of judicial prejudice.â€Â  Felder v. Charleston County Sch. Dist., 327 S.C. 21, 26, 489 S.E.2d 191, 194 (1997).Â  Evidence of judicial prejudice may be established by showing that the record does not support the courtâ€™s findings.Â  Ellis v. Procter & Gamble Distrib. Co., 315 S.C. 283, 285, 433 S.E.2d 856, 857 (1993).
Father failed to provide evidence of extra-judicial bias or prejudice.Â  Furthermore, a review of the record shows the courtâ€™s interaction with Fatherâ€™s counsel did not rise to the level of demonstrating bias.Â  The record also supports the judgeâ€™s findings.Â  Accordingly, we affirm the judgeâ€™s decision to deny the request for recusal.Â  
IV.     Dr. Hamrickâ€™s Testimony 
Father argues the family court judge erred by admitting Dr. Hamrickâ€™s testimony.Â  We disagree.
â€œThe public policy protecting confidential communications must be balanced against the public interest in the proper administration of justice.â€Â  Floyd v. Floyd, 365 S.C. 56, 89, 615 S.E2d 465, 483 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  To warrant a reversal based on the admission of evidence, the appellant must show both error and resulting prejudice.Â  Commerce Ctr. Of Greenville, Inc. v. W. Powers McElveen Assocs. Inc., 347 S.C. 545, 556 S.E.2d 718 (Ct. App. 2001). Â 
The prior court order providing for counseling sessions clearly stated that â€œunder no circumstances are any of the discussions in [the] therapy sessions to be admitted into evidence in the Family Court of South Carolina . . . .â€Â  The parties agreed to the counseling as part of the resolution of the custody issue.Â  It is unreasonable, and we believe against public policy, to allow these sessions to provide an open forum for one parent to make threats or to otherwise intimidate the other parent.
We find the confidentiality provision in question here was intended to facilitate candid discourse between Father and Mother with the ultimate goal of protecting Childâ€™s best interests.Â  Neither the judge, nor the parties could have contemplated these counseling sessions would protect illegal activity or statements such as making a threat on anotherâ€™s life.Â  Public policy mandates that we take such an approach.Â  Furthermore, Father has not shown prejudice resulted from admitting Dr. Hamrickâ€™s statement.Â  Even if Fatherâ€™s statement was not proven to be a threat, the record shows other instances of Fatherâ€™s abusive, threatening and harassing behavior. 
V.         Attorneysâ€™ Fees 
Father argues the judge erred in awarding Mother attorneysâ€™ fees resulting from the motion to vacate.Â  We agree.
Â There is no indication in the order the family court took into account the factors of either E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 415 S.E.2d 812 (1992), or Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 403 S.E.2d 313 (1991).Â  This court finds both partiesâ€™ contributed to the events leading up to the motion to vacate the December 19, 1999 order.Â  Fatherâ€™s conduct and deception and the manner in which Mother left South Carolina contributed to the necessity for court intervention.Â  Therefore, both parties are responsible for paying their own fees.
VI.Â  Divorce Decree
Father argues the judge erred in finding Father violated the divorce decree. Â We disagree.
The family court found Father violated the divorce decree, which contained a mutual restraining order prohibiting the parties from harassing each other.Â  This finding was specifically based on Father threatening Motherâ€™s life and confronting her at her place of residence.Â  The family courtÂ  did not order any specific sanction as a result of this finding.Â  
â€œThe trial judge was in a superior position to judge the witnessâ€™ demeanor and veracity, and therefore, [her] findings should be given broad discretion.â€Â  Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996).Â  Upon review of the record, there is evidence to justify the courtâ€™s finding that Father violated the divorce decree by threatening Motherâ€™s life and harassing Mother at her place of residence.Â  
VII.Â  Vacating the Default Order
Father argues the family court erred by vacating her earlier order giving custody to Father.Â  We disagree.
The family court vacated the earlier order based upon reasons discussed in Sections I and II.Â  Based on our earlier findings, we affirm the family court.
VIII.    Gross Misrepresentations 
Father argues the family court erred by finding Father and his counsel made gross misrepresentations to the court.Â  We disagree.
The court based this particular finding on, among other things, evidence that Father and his counsel had possession of a letter from Dr. Hamrick regarding the threat before the initiation of this case and failed to disclose the letter or the information contained in it.Â  
The judge, â€œwho saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.â€Â  McElveen 332 S.C. at 591, 506 S.E.2d at 5.Â  Here, Father has failed to meet his burden to convince this court that the family court judge erred in her factual findings.Â  See generally, DuBose v. DuBose, 259 S.C. 418, 192 S.E.2d 329 (1972).Â  The order contains findings of fact regarding various misrepresentations and incomplete disclosures, which prompted the court to make its ruling.Â  Because there is evidence in the record to support her findings, the judgeâ€™s decision will not be disturbed.Â  
IX.      Custody 
Following the trial on the merits, Judge Wylie concluded Childâ€™s best interests would be served by Mother receiving sole custody and Father having visitation privileges.Â  Father argues that because Mother did not present any pleadings seeking sole custody, the court erred in granting such relief.Â  We disagree.
Either party seeking a change in custody must show facts substantially affecting the childâ€™s best interests and well being.Â  See Shirley v. Shirley, 342 S.C. 324, 330, 536 S.E.2d 427, 430 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  The family court considered how its custody decision would impact all areas of Childâ€™s life, including physical, psychological, spiritual, educational, familial, emotional, and recreational aspects.Â  See Hollar v. Hollar, 342 S.C. 463, 472, 536 S.E.2d 883, 888 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  
â€œWhen issues not raised by the pleadings are tried by express or implied consent of the parties, they shall be treated in all respects as if they had been raised in the pleadings . . . [and] failure [to so] amend does not affect the result of the trial of these issues.â€Â  Rule 15(b), SCRCP.Â  â€œAn appellant has a duty to provide this Court with a record sufficient for review of the issues on appeal.â€Â  State v. Tyndall, 336 S.C. 8, 17, 518 S.E.2d 278, 283 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  The record Father provided does not include any of Motherâ€™s testimony.Â  Therefore, we are left to look at the judgeâ€™s order to determine whether Mother asked for sole custody.Â  Because the order clearly shows Mother did testify (â€œ[m]otherâ€™s testimony made it clear to the Court that she would like . . . her common law husband [to be Childâ€™s] father.â€), we are left to infer that she did seek custody.Â  Therefore, we hold the issue of custody was tried by the consent of both parties and does not need to be formally pled to be considered by this court.
Mother represents herself in this appeal and did not supply this court with a brief or contribute to the record on appeal.Â  Although we do not expressly know what Mother pled at trial, we do know that custody was the crux of the case and the focus of the December 3, 2003 order.Â  The trial judge considered all of the appropriate factors used to determine whether circumstances changed sufficiently to alter custody.Â  The family court ultimately decided that Father did not prove a sufficient change of circumstances and Mother did prove a substantial change of circumstances.Â  The family court found that the social, educational, spiritual, medical, familial, and recreational aspects of Childâ€™s life continue to develop successfully in Motherâ€™s care.Â  Additionally, Mother has remarried and is able to devote herself full time to caring for Child.Â  Child is enrolled in private school and active in Girl Scouts, tee ball, music, and dance.Â  Mother proved that the move to Colorado has been beneficial for the child.Â  
Father concedes the child is doing well academically and socially, but argues the Mother moved to Colorado to alienate him from the child.Â  The family court found that Mother left after difficulties exchanging Child for visitation with Father.Â  Fatherâ€™s conduct included bullying and spiteful conduct in an effort to intimidate Mother.
Â While this court does not condone Motherâ€™s failure to comply with the notice provisions of the initial order, it does appear that the Child is thriving due to Motherâ€™s efforts.Â  This fact along with Fatherâ€™s conduct are significant changes warranting the family courtâ€™s determination it was in Childâ€™s best interest to award Mother sole custody of Child with visitation to Father.Â  
Accordingly, the family courtâ€™s decision is
 AFFIRMED in part, REVERSED in part.[2]
STILWELL, KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur. 

[1] Mother currently goes by the name Chantalle Irland.Â  She is representing herself pro se and did not file a brief for this appeal.
[2] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Hart v. Hart
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Gregory S. Hart, Appellant,
v.
Cynthia Hart, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Robert S. Armstrong, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-116
Submitted February 1, 2006 â€“ Filed February 24, 2006

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Gregory Samuel Forman, of Charleston, for Appellant.
Cynthia Hart, of New Smyrna, Florida, pro se.
      
    
  

 PER CURIAM:Â  In this post-divorce matter, Gregory S. Hart, the husband, appeals a family court order issued pursuant to a rule to show cause brought by Cynthia Hart, the wife.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part and remand.[1]
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
On October 5, 2004, the parties appeared before the family court to request approval of an agreement they had reached concerning the division of their property and other matters incident to their divorce.[2]Â  The agreement required, among other things, that the husband deliver to the wife various items of personal property and compensate her for her equitable interest in his business by paying monthly installments secured by a note and non-interest-bearing second mortgage on his primary residence.Â  The wife was to assume responsibility for the costs associated with the preparation and filing of the mortgage and all costs associated with extinguishing the mortgage when the husband satisfied the debt.Â  The family court approved the agreement and filed an order to that effect on October 7, 2004.Â  
The following month, the family court issued a rule to show cause against the husband based on a complaint filed by the wife alleging in pertinent part that the husband failed to return certain items, the husband returned other items in damaged condition, and the husband failed to execute the note and mortgage prepared by her attorney.Â  
A hearing on the rule to show cause took place March 10, 2005.Â  Both parties testified.Â  In addition, the husband called attorney Dean Porter as an expert witness regarding problems with the mortgage as drafted by the wifeâ€™s attorney.Â  
Several weeks later, the family court issued an order on the rule to show cause.Â  In the order, the family court (1) found the husband had violated the agreement by failing to deliver various personal effects to the wife, but held a finding of contempt in abeyance pending his return of a mattress set and a Bombay entertainment center; (2) ordered the husband to pay the wife $200 â€œfor the value of damaged propertyâ€; (3) ordered the husband to execute the note and mortgage; and (4) ordered the husband to pay $500 toward attorney fees and costs incurred by the wife in pursuing the contempt action.Â  The husband appeals this order.
DISCUSSION
1.Â  At the outset, we note the wife has not filed a brief in this appeal.Â  Although we recognize this failure is not necessarily a stipulation of error in the appealed order,[3] we nevertheless â€œmay take such action as [we] deem proper,â€[4] including reversing the judgment below.[5]Â  We find it appropriate to avail ourselves somewhat of this prerogative given the substantial issues of fact raised in this appeal and the authority of this court to take its own view of the evidence in an equity matter.[6]  
2.Â  The husband takes issue with the family courtâ€™s finding that, contrary to the partiesâ€™ agreement, he failed to return the wifeâ€™s dive equipment.Â  We agree with the husband that the preponderance of the evidence does not support this finding.Â  
â€œExhibit A,â€ which is referenced in the order approving the partiesâ€™ agreement, listed â€œdive equipmentâ€ as one of the personal effects that the husband was to deliver to the wife.Â  The agreement, however, did not enumerate the specific items of diving gear that the wife was to receive.Â  The family court determined the husband returned only the wifeâ€™s diving fins and still needed to return her wet suit, dive mask and snorkel.Â  Although it appears from the record that the wife offered some testimony suggesting she had owned a ladies wet suit, dive mask, and snorkel, another exhibit referenced in the order lists the dive equipment as an item bought by the husband as a gift to the wife during the marriage and values it at $200.Â  When the husband presented his case, he testified that he purchased the wife only a set of fins for about $180.Â  He acknowledged he and the wife had gone diving on their honeymoon in Greece, but explained they used rented equipment and had not dived since that time.Â  The record does not reflect that the wife presented any reply evidence refuting the husbandâ€™s assertions.Â  
3.Â  We disagree with the husband that the family court â€œerred in finding that he failed to return the â€˜leather top end table.â€™â€Â  The family court made no such finding; therefore, no error occurred.Â  
At the hearing, the wife acknowledged the husband had provided her a leather top end table, but stated it was not the leather top end table she was expecting to receive.Â  The husband, however, testified that the leather top end table he returned to the wife was the only such table of which he was aware and that neither party owned a table fitting the description of the item that the wife claimed belonged to her.
According to the appealed order, the family court recounted the wifeâ€™s testimony and noted the item in dispute appeared on one of the exhibits referenced in the order approving the agreement.Â  There is no finding in the appealed order, however, that the husband â€œfailedâ€ to return the correct table.Â  
Furthermore, the family court neither imposed a finding of contempt against the husband for his alleged failure to give the wife the desired table nor made avoidance of such a finding conditional on the return of the item.
4.Â  We agree with the husband that the family court erred in ordering him to pay $200 to the wife for â€œdamaged property.â€Â  In her complaint on the rule to show cause, the wife alleged the husband damaged eleven items that he was supposed to return to her:Â  a red velvet chair, a green animal print chair, the glass door of an entertainment center, a coffee table, a dryer, three end tables, a green room rug, her bicycle tires, and the frame and glass from a print.Â  Contrary to the wifeâ€™s allegations, however, the family court specifically found the husband had not damaged the coffee table, rug, or picture frame and made no finding that he had damaged any of the remaining items.Â  Because there are no findings that the husband was responsible for any of the alleged damage, it follows that he should not have to pay anything to the wife.
5.Â  We disagree with the husband that the family court erred in finding that the Bombay entertainment center was part of the â€œBombay setâ€ he had agreed to return to the wife.Â  According to literature from the Bombay Company that the wife submitted into evidence, the four pieces that the wife acknowledged the husband returned to her were from the â€œHaberdasherâ€ collection and the entertainment center was called a â€œHaberdashers Entertainment Cabinet.â€Â  The husband testified only that he thought the entertainment center was separate from the other pieces of furniture, but gave no specific facts as to why he believed this.Â  According to our view of the preponderance of evidence, then, it was reasonable for the family court to find the entertainment center was part of the set of furniture that the husband was to return to the wife.
6.Â  Regarding the note and mortgage, the husband argues â€œto the extent the courtâ€™s finding indicates the ex-husband is somehow responsible for the problems with the note and mortgage, there is simply no factual basis to sustain that finding.â€Â  We do not interpret the appealed order as finding the husband to be at fault regarding the problems with the preparation of the note and mortgage; therefore, we do not address this issue.
7.Â  The husband claims the family court erred in failing to grant his claim for payment of attorney Porterâ€™s fees.Â  Because, however, the appealed order does not rule on this request and the husband did not raise this issue in a Rule 59(e) motion, he failed to preserve this issue for appellate review.[7]
8. Â Finally, the husband argues the family court erred in awarding attorney fees to the wife and in denying attorney fees to him.Â  In view of the beneficial results obtained by the husband in this appeal, we remand this issue to the family court for further consideration.[8]
 AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  The partiesâ€™ divorce decree had already been filed.
[3]Â  State v. Tessnear, 257 S.C. 290, 295, 185 S.E.2d 611, 613 (1971).
[4]Â  Rule 208(a)(4), SCACR.
[5]Â  Wierszewski v. Tokarick, 308 S.C. 441, 444 n.2, 418 S.E.2d 557, 559 n.2 (Ct. App. 1992).
[6]Â  See Campbell v. Carr, 361 S.C. 258, 266, 603 S.E.2d 625, 629 (Ct. App. 2004) (Goolsby, concurring) (concurring in the reversal of the appealed decision and noting as reasons the equity standard of review and the presence of substantial questions of both fact and law); Hendricks v. Hendricks, 285 S.C. 591, 593, 330 S.E.2d 553, 553-54 (Ct. App. 1985) (noting that the court of appeals has jurisdiction in appeals from the family court to find facts according to its own view of the evidence).
[7]Â  See Noisette v. Ismail, 304 S.C. 56, 403 S.E.2d 122 (1991) (holding that, when the trial court does not explicitly rule on a question and the appellant fails to make a Rule 59(e), SCRCP motion to alter or amend the judgment on that ground, the issue is not properly before the court of appeals and should not be addressed).
[8]Â  See Sexton v. Sexton, 310 S.C. 501, 503, 427 S.E.2d 665, 666 (1993) (reversing an attorney fees award in a divorce case because the petitioner prevailed on numerous issues on appeal).

title: Williams v. Churdar
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Tim Williams, Appellant,
v.
Douglas A. Churdar and Robert Cook, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-118
Submitted February 1, 2006 â€“ Filed February 24, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Timothy L. Williams, of Columbia, for Appellant.Â  
Curtis L. Ott, of Columbia and David L. Moore, of Greenville, for Respondents. 
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Tim Williams appeals several evidentiary rulings by the trial court and complains about the conduct of his own attorney in the trial of this case in which he sued his former employer for malicious prosecution, defamation and other claims.Â  We affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR, and the following authorities:Â  State v. Carlson, 363 S.C. 586, 606, 611 S.E.2d 283, 293 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing State v. Patterson, 324 S.C. 5, 18, 482 S.E.2d 760, 766 (1997), for the proposition that where an appellant objects to improper comments and the objection is sustained the issue is not preserved unless the appellant further moves to strike or requests a curative instruction); Elam v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 361 S.C. 9, 23, 602 S.E.2d 772, 779-80 (2004) (â€œIssues and arguments are preserved for appellate review only when they are raised to and ruled on by the lower court.â€); Hillman v. Pinion, 347 S.C. 253, 257, 554 S.E.2d 427, 430 (Ct. App. 2001) (explaining that the neglect of the attorney is the neglect of the client, and no mistake attributable to an attorney can be used as a basis for relief on appeal unless the mistake would have been excusable if attributed to the client); Cogdill v. Watson, 289 S.C. 531, 537, 347 S.E.2d 126, 130 (Ct. App. 1986) (â€œThe failure to make an objection at the time evidence is offered constitutes a waiver of the right to object.â€).[1] Â 
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HUFF and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Oaklan v. Oaklan
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Michelle Oaklan, Respondent,
v.
John Oaklan, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Jane D. Fender, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-119
Submitted February 1, 2006 â€“ Filed February 24, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Jack D. Simrill, of Hilton Head Island, for Appellant.
Frank H. Clabaugh, of Hilton Head Island, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  John Oaklan (Husband) appeals a family court order denying his motion to vacate an arbitration award.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Michelle Oaklan (Wife) and Husband were married in 1998.Â  No children were born of the marriage.Â  The parties separated in 2002, and Wife filed an action against Husband seeking, inter alia, equitable distribution.Â  By order dated February 27, 2003, the family court required Husband to vacate the marital residence, ordered Wife to pay costs associated with the residence, and restrained the parties from depleting marital assets or incurring marital debt.Â  During the pendency of the action, Wife refinanced the house with an equity line of credit and extended the mortgage term from fifteen to thirty years.Â  She alleged she used a portion of the proceeds to reduce the partiesâ€™ credit card debt.Â  
The parties agreed to submit the issue of equitable distribution to final and binding arbitration.Â  The arbitrator found that both parties contributed to the marital estate, each contributed to the breakup of the marriage, and neither was entitled to alimony.Â  The arbitrator concluded the marital assets included the marital residence, which had an equity of approximately $32,000 after subtracting the balance of the line of credit from the appraised value.Â  The arbitrator determined that expenses incurred by Wife during the separation were marital in nature and ordered Husband to pay one-half of them.Â  The arbitrator awarded a 50/50 equitable distribution.Â  Because Wife desired to purchase Husbandâ€™s share of the marital residence, the arbitrator ordered Wife to pay Husband $6,535.08 and ordered Husband to execute the necessary documents to consummate the transaction.Â  
The family court adopted the arbitration decision and granted the parties a divorce.Â  Husband thereafter moved to vacate the arbitration award arguing, inter alia, the equity line of credit Wife incurred during the separation violated the family courtâ€™s order forbidding the parties from incurring marital debt during the pendency of the action.Â  Wife moved to dismiss Husbandâ€™s â€œappeal.â€Â  
The family court held a hearing on Husbandâ€™s motion and found the parties agreed to arbitration and all issues raised by Husband were before the arbitrator.Â  The court found the arbitration was final and binding, denied Husbandâ€™s motion to vacate, and granted Wifeâ€™s motion to dismiss.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Husband argues the family court lacked subject matter jurisdiction over the equity line of credit because it was nonmarital.Â  We disagree.Â  
The determination of whether a debt is marital in nature is a factual issue and marital debt, like marital assets, must be specifically identified and apportioned in equitable distribution.Â  Wooten v. Wooten, 364 S.C. 532, 546-47, 615 S.E.2d 98, 105-06 (2005).Â  When a debt is incurred after the initiation of marital litigation, it may be considered marital in nature and apportioned accordingly if it was incurred for marital purposes.Â  Id.Â  Thus, whether jurisdiction exists depends on the factual determination of the credit line as marital or nonmarital.Â  Bowen v. Bowen, 345 S.C. 243, 247, 547 S.E.2d 877, 879 (Ct. App. 2001) (stating family court has jurisdiction to determine if property is nonmarital; once it determines it nonmarital, there is no continuing jurisdiction over said property).
Wife alleged she used the proceeds of the equity line of credit to reduce marital credit card debt when she refinanced the marital residence during the pendency of the action.Â  She asserts the net effect of refinancing was that marital debt and assets remained the same.Â  Both parties submitted all pertinent materials to the arbitrator including information about the refinance.Â  The arbitrator circulated a proposed order.Â  Husband challenged that portion of the arbitratorâ€™s order.Â  The arbitrator acknowledged Husbandâ€™s arguments and concluded the credit line was a marital debt.Â  We find no error.
In the alternative, Husband argues the family court erred in refusing to set aside the arbitration award due to the arbitratorâ€™s treatment of the equity line of credit.[2]Â  We disagree. 
Arbitration agreements in South Carolina are governed by the Uniform Arbitration Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-48-10 through -240 (2005).Â  The Arbitration Act provides that a â€œwritten agreement to submit any existing controversy to arbitration . . . is valid, enforceable and irrevocable, save upon such grounds as exist at law or in equity for the revocation of any contract.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-48-10(a) (2005).Â 
This court has found the Arbitration Act applies to agreements to arbitrate equitable apportionment claims.Â  Swentor v. Swentor, 336 S.C. 472, 477-78, 520 S.E.2d 330, 333 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  
In this case, as in Swentor, the parties agreed to submit equitable distribution issues to arbitration.Â  The family courtâ€™s ordinary power to approve settlement agreements after a review for fairness does not exist where the parties agree to binding arbitration.Â  Id. at 482, 520 S.E.2d at 336.Â  â€œTo allow a family court judge to set aside an arbitration award because the judge found the award to be unfair would severely undermine the finality of arbitration agreements.â€Â  Id. at 483, 520 S.E.2d at 336.
The family court may vacate an arbitration award only upon one of the statutory grounds set forth
in South Carolina Code section 15-48-130,[3] or for â€œmanifest disregard or perverse misconstruction of the law.â€Â  Lauro v. Visnapuu, 351 S.C. 507, 516, 570 S.E.2d 551, 556 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  We find no such grounds present in this case.
AFFIRMED. 
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1] Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Â Â Â Â Â Â  We consolidate Husbandâ€™s remaining issues on appeal.
[3] Â Â Â Â Â Â  a)Â  Upon application of a party, the court shall vacate an award where:

  (1)Â  The award was procured by corruption, fraud or other undue means;
  (2)Â  There was evident partiality by an arbitrator . . . ;
  (3)Â  The arbitrators exceeded their powers;
  (4)Â  The arbitrators refused to postpone the hearing . . . as to prejudice substantially the rights of a party; or
  (5)Â  There was no arbitration agreement . . . .

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-48-130 (2005).

title: Young v. Greene
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Jeff Young and Shonya Young, Appellants,
v.
Tracy Alan Greene and Ted Anthony Greene, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â Paula H. Thomas, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-122
Submitted February 1, 2006 â€“ Filed February 24, 2006Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Gene M. Connell, Jr., of Surfside Beach, for Appellants.
Jon L. Austen and Francis M. Ervin, both of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Appellants Jeff and Shonya Young sued respondent Tracy Greene and his brother Ted, alleging Tracy collided with their vehicle on July 15, 2000, when Tracy, while driving his brotherâ€™s truck, turned left in front of them.Â  The Youngs seek to recover damages for severe personal injuries they allegedly received from the automobile accident.Â  The jury returned a verdict for the Greenes.Â  We affirm.[1]
1.Â Â Â Â Â Â  We find no error in the trial judgeâ€™s instructing the jury it could find for the Greenes.Â  The Youngs contend the Greenesâ€™ counsel admitted liability, leaving only the question of the amount of damages for the jury to determine.Â  In this case, however, the record shows the Greenes only admitted simple negligence.[2]Â  
â€œLiability encompasses all elements of a negligence claim, including damages proximately caused by the alleged negligence.â€ Â Hinds v. Elms, 358 S.C. 581, 585, 595 S.E.2d 855, 857 (Ct. App. 2004). Â â€œA determination of negligence, standing alone, is a far cry from a determination of liability.â€Â  Id.Â  The plaintiff must also prove proximate cause in a negligence action.Â  Hurd v. Williamsburg County, 363 S.C. 421, 611 S.E.2d 488 (2005).Â  The issue of proximate cause is generally a question for the jury and, if more than one reasonable inference can be drawn from the evidence, the trial judge must submit the issue to the jury.Â  Graham v. Whitaker, 282 S.C. 393, 321 S.E.2d 40 (1984).Â  
Because the Greenes admitted only simple negligence, the Youngs were still required to prove that negligence proximately caused their injuries and they were required to prove the amount of damages they suffered as a result.Â  
2.Â Â Â Â Â Â  We find no error in the trial judgeâ€™s denial of the Youngsâ€™ motion for a new trial where the jury could reasonably conclude the Greenesâ€™ negligence was not a proximate cause of the alleged damages.Â  
The trial judge may grant a new trial absolute when, sitting as the thirteenth juror, she concludes the juryâ€™s verdict is not supported by the evidence.Â  Duncan v. Hampton County Sch. Dist. No. 2,  335 S.C. 535, 517 S.E.2d 449 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Although the Greenes neither testified nor presented any witnesses, the trial judge found many contested issues in the trial that could justify a verdict for the Greenes.Â  Evidence is not rendered undisputed simply because there is no direct evidence contradicting it.Â  There still remains a question of its inherent probability, the credibility of the witnesses, and the inferences to be drawn from the evidence.Â  Vereen v. Liberty Life Ins. Co., 306 S.C. 423, 412 S.E.2d 425 (Ct. App. 1991).Â  
Dr. William Endicott, the Youngsâ€™ dentist, testified he briefly examined the Youngs on the 17th or 18th of July 2000.Â  Although he usually treats emergency cases right away, Endicott first treated the Youngs on September 13, 2000, approximately two months after the accident.Â  Dr. Jeff Benjamin, the Youngsâ€™ neurologist, testified he started treating Shonya Young on October 27, 2000, and Jeffrey Young on November 22, 2000, approximately three to four months after the accident.Â  Dr. Benjamin testified Jeffrey complained to him of pain in his lower back and neck.Â  
On July 23, 2000, Jeffrey suffered injuries in a fight and received medical attention in a hospital emergency room.Â  The hospital report reveals someone struck Jeffrey in the head with a stick, causing him to lose consciousness.Â  The report also reveals he denied any neck or back pain at the time, even though the automobile accident occurred a week prior.Â  Â Â 
Although both doctors opined the July 15, 2000 automobile accident caused the Youngsâ€™ injuries, the doctors also admitted they based their determinations about the relationship between the injuries and the accident largely upon information supplied by the Youngs.Â  The July 23, 2000 incident appears in the medical records; however, the record on appeal does not indicate the Youngs discussed the incident with either doctor and neither of the Youngs testified at trial.Â  
Officer Michael Marsh, who responded to the scene of the accident, testified he generally remembered when people were seriously injured.Â  Moreover, his report indicates the Youngs did not go to the hospital immediately after the accident.Â  
The testimony at trial created an issue of fact regarding the truthfulness of the Youngsâ€™ alleged injuries.Â  The facts above could reasonably lead the jury to conclude the Youngs suffered no injuries as a result of the July 15, 2000 accident.Â  See Ross v. Paddy, 340 S.C. 428, 532 S.E.2d 612 (Ct. App. 2000) (noting even where the evidence is uncontradicted, the jury may believe all, some, or none of the testimony, and where the credibility of a witness has been questioned, the matter is properly left to the jury to decide); Burns v. Universal Health Servs., Inc., 361 S.C. 221, 603 S.E.2d 605 (Ct. App. 2004) (stating a juryâ€™s verdict will be upheld if there is any evidence to sustain the factual findings implicit in the verdict).
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.Â  

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] We note the Greenesâ€™ counsel twice misspoke in admitting liability; however the record is clear that he only admitted simple negligence.Â  Â Â

title: Yochem v. Yochem
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDINGÂ Â  EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Marlene C. Yochem, Respondent,
v.
Robert C. Yochem, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Jane D. Fender, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-123
Submitted February 1, 2006 â€“ Filed February 24, 2006Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
William Randall Phipps, of Hilton Head Island, for Appellant.
Edwin W. Rowland, of Hilton Head Island, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  The family court granted Marlene Yochem (Wife) a divorce from Robert Yochem (Husband) on the ground of adultery, divided the partiesâ€™ assets, and awarded Wife attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  Husband appeals, arguing the family court erred in (1) apportioning the marital estate and ordering that Wife receive $48,529.29 from the sale of the marital home to repay her original investment of nonmarital funds, (2) awarding Wife permanent periodic alimony of $1,000.00 per month, and (3) ordering Husband to pay $12,500.00 towards Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  We affirm.[1]  
I.Â  Apportionment of Assets (Marital Home)
Husband first contends the family court erred in failing to consider all of the factors enumerated in section 20-7-472 of the South Carolina Code in apportioning the partiesâ€™ estate.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472 (Supp. 2005).Â  Specifically, Husband argues the court placed undue emphasis on Wifeâ€™s contribution of $48,529.29 of nonmarital property toward the acquisition of the partiesâ€™ first home (the Crooked Pond home) and, after its sale, incorrectly assumed the money was placed into the partiesâ€™ second home (the Chinaberry home).Â  Husband asserts the court â€œignored the $47,000 nonmarital contribution from Husbandâ€™s retirement, as well as all the personal labor [H]usband expended on both the Crooked Pond and Chinaberry houses.â€Â  Husband finally contends any nonmarital funds Wife contributed were transmuted.Â  As a result, Husband maintains he should be awarded one half of the net proceeds from the sale of the Chinaberry home.
On appeal from an order of the family court, an appellate court has the authority to find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Hopkins v. Hopkins, 343 S.C. 301, 304, 540 S.E.2d 454, 456 (2000).Â  Where, however, the evidence is disputed, an appellate court may adhere to the findings of the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses and was in a superior position to judge the witnessesâ€™ demeanor and veracity.Â  Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996).
Pursuant to section 20-7-472 of the South Carolina Code, in making an equitable division of marital assets and debts, the family court must give weight in such proportion as it finds appropriate to the list of enumerated factors, including the duration of the marriage and the ages of the parties, marital misconduct or fault, the value of the marital property and each spouseâ€™s contribution, the income and earning potential of each spouse, the health of each spouse, and such other factors that the court deems relevant.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472 (Supp. 2005).Â  
The family court does not have jurisdiction to apportion nonmarital property.Â  Id. Â§ 20-7-473.Â  Nonmarital property includes property acquired by either party before the marriage.Â  Id.Â  Nonmarital property may be transmuted into marital property if (1) it becomes so commingled with marital property that it is untraceable, (2) it is jointly titled, or (3) it is utilized in support of the marriage so as to evidence an intent by the parties to make it marital property.Â  Greene v. Greene, 351 S.C. 329, 569 S.E.2d 393 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Transmutation is a matter of intent to be gleaned from the facts in the case, and the party claiming transmutation of nonmarital property must produce enough objective evidence that, during the marriage, the parties regarded the disputed property as marital.Â  Hatfield v. Hatfield, 327 S.C. 360, 489 S.E.2d 212 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  
In this case, the family court determined an equal division of all marital assets was appropriate, except for the Chinaberry home, which had been the partiesâ€™ marital residence.Â  The court stated the Chinaberry home was to be sold and Wife repaid her investment of nonmarital funds of $48,529.29, with the parties to equally split the remaining net proceeds.Â  The court reviewed the statutory factors, noting this was a marriage of long duration that ended with the partiesâ€™ divorce on the ground of Husbandâ€™s adultery, and that Wife, who was 56, had suffered the removal of ninety percent of her stomach and thus had limited income potential due to her disability.Â  Husband, meanwhile, had misrepresented his inability to work, which was revealed after Wife hired a private investigator.Â  
The evidence shows the parties were married on July 30, 1993, in Hershey, Pennsylvania.Â  A week later, on August 5, 1993, they signed a Real Estate Agreement that stated the parties intended to relocate to Hilton Head Island, South Carolina, and purchase real estate using equity that Wife received in the sale of property from her prior marriage.Â  The settlement statement from the purchase of the partiesâ€™ Crooked Pond home shows a cash down payment of $48,529.29 was made on the $202,500.00 residence and it is undisputed those funds were supplied by Wife.Â  Wife testified that when the parties purchased the Chinaberry home, she made a cash payment of $39,630.72, as indicated on the settlement statement, and that additional nonmarital funds went towards remodeling the home.Â  The family court stated it was satisfied that Wifeâ€™s nonmarital property was used to create equity in the current marital residence in the amount of $48,529.29 and that this amount could be traced to the current home.Â  
Although Husband argued Wife had either already received her nonmarital investment back or, alternatively, that her nonmarital investment was subsequently transmuted, the family court believed Wifeâ€™s evidence and concluded the intent of the parties was that Wifeâ€™s contribution of nonmarital funds from her prior marriage was to remain nonmarital.Â  Husband was, in any event, to receive an equal share of the net proceeds from the sale of the Chinaberry home after Wife received her funds, so the family court did not, contrary to Husbandâ€™s assertion, ignore his alleged contributions of funds and personal labor.Â  The court adequately reviewed the statutory factors before making its award and, although the evidence was conflicting, we hold the overall apportionment was fair and Husband has shown no clear error amounting to an abuse of discretion.Â  See Woodall, 322 S.C. at 10, 471 S.E.2d at 157 (stating where the evidence is disputed, an appellate court may adhere to the findings of the trial judge, who was in a better position to evaluate credibility); Bragg v. Bragg, 347 S.C. 16, 23, 553 S.E.2d 251, 255 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œThe [family courtâ€™s] apportionment of marital property will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.â€); Terwilliger v. Terwilliger, 298 S.C. 144, 147, 378 S.E.2d 609, 611 (Ct. App. 1989) (â€œResolving questions of credibility is a function of the family court judge who heard the testimony.â€); Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 300, 372 S.E.2d 107, 113 (Ct. App. 1988) (stating an appellate court looks to the fairness of the overall apportionment and if the end result is fair, it is irrelevant if an appellate court might have weighed specific factors differently). Â Â Â Â 
II.Â  Alimony
Husband next asserts the family court erred in awarding Wife permanent periodic alimony of $1,000.00 per month.Â  
The amount of alimony to be awarded is within the broad discretion of the family court and should not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Rimer v. Rimer, 361 S.C. 521, 524, 605 S.E.2d 572, 574 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs either when a court is controlled by an error of law or where the factual findings lack evidentiary support.Â  Id.
Section 20-3-130(C) of the South Carolina Code lists the factors a family court should consider when deciding whether and how much alimony to award, including the duration of the marriage, the educational background of each spouse, the employment history and earning potential of each spouse, the standard of living established during the marriage, and the current and reasonably anticipated expenses and needs of both spouses.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C) (Supp. 2005).Â Â  
The family court was primarily concerned with Wifeâ€™s future ability to pay for her health insurance coverage because the coverage she had through Husband would be unavailable after the divorce.Â  The court set the award at $1,000.00 per month so she would have enough after taxes to purchase her own health insurance.Â Â  Â 
We find given her pre-existing health condition and lack of income, Wife would need alimony to cover this cost.Â  The trial court noted Wife was in poor health and unable to work due to her disability.Â  Moreover, the court expressly found Husbandâ€™s testimony that he was unable to work was not credible based on surveillance conducted by Wifeâ€™s private investigator, which showed him engaged in activities at several job sites and transporting and instructing employees.Â  The court further noted Husbandâ€™s lifestyle established that he was receiving income from working, as he could not support the lifestyle he was enjoying without additional income beyond the retirement funds he was receiving.Â Â Â  
Our review of the record supports the courtâ€™s findings.Â  For example, despite his protestations as to his lack of income, at the time of trial Husband had an option on a million-dollar residence.Â  In addition, Wife demonstrated Husbandâ€™s continuing employment in the home improvement field although he had denied working.Â  Accordingly, we find no abuse of discretion in the family courtâ€™s award of $1,000.00 monthly alimony to Wife.
III.Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees and Costs
Husband lastly contends the family court erred in ordering him to pay $12,500.00 of Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  Specifically, Husband argues there is no evidence to support the courtâ€™s conclusions that Wife was unable to pay and that it would detrimentally affect Wifeâ€™s standard of living to require her to pay them in full.Â  Husband contends Wife is in a better position to pay the fees since she is to receive $48,529.29 more from the marital estate.Â  Husband further states if he should prevail on appeal, the award necessarily should be reversed.Â  Finally, Husband contends since evidence of the attorneyâ€™s fees was submitted by affidavit, the family court deprived him of the opportunity to conduct cross-examination regarding the fees.
The family court is authorized to make an award of attorneyâ€™s fees and other costs pursuant to statute.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-120 (1985) & id. Â§ 20-3-130 (Supp. 2005).Â  â€œIt is well settled that an award of attorneyâ€™s fees is within the sound discretion of the trial judge and will not be disturbed absent an abuse of that discretion.â€Â  Smith v. Smith, 308 S.C. 492, 496, 419 S.E.2d 232, 234-35 (Ct. App. 1992).
Initially, we note Husband does not expressly challenge the amount of Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees and costs; rather, he only argues that he should not be required to pay a portion thereof.Â  We find, however, no abuse of discretion in this case.Â  
In deciding whether to make an award of attorneyâ€™s fees, the court should consider the contingency of compensation, beneficial results obtained, the abilities of the parties to pay, their respective financial conditions, and the effect of the attorneyâ€™s fees on each partyâ€™s standard of living.Â  Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161-62 n.1, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 n.1 (1991) (citing Mitchell v. Mitchell, 283 S.C. 87, 320 S.E.2d 706 (1984)).
Wifeâ€™s fees were in excess of $20,000.00.Â  The family court found Wife did not have the ability to pay her own attorneyâ€™s fees due to her disability, which involved the loss of ninety percent of her stomach, her loss of income, and the need for financial support.Â  Moreover, Husband had the ability to assist with Wifeâ€™s expenses in light of his retirement income and the ability to earn income from his self-employment.Â  The court also noted Wife had received beneficial results and had prevailed on her claim for a divorce on fault grounds, alimony, and the equitable division.Â  We conclude the record amply supports these findings.Â  
To the extent Husband further contends the family court erred by having the parties submit affidavits of attorneyâ€™s fees, thus depriving him of the opportunity to conduct cross-examination, we find Husband does not indicate where in the record he made a contemporaneous objection on this basis that was ruled on by the court.Â  See, e.g., Watson ex. rel. Watson v. Chapman, 343 S.C. 471, 540 S.E.2d 484 (Ct. App. 2000) (stating a contemporaneous objection must be both made to and ruled on by the trial court to preserve an alleged error for appellate review) (citing Tupper v. Dorchester County, 326 S.C. 318, 487 S.E.2d 187 (1997)).Â  The parties attempted to submit affidavits during the trial and the family court asked that they be held until the end of the trial.Â  Thereafter, each of the parties submitted their affidavits without making any objections as to this procedure.Â  Accordingly, we find no reversible error in this instance.Â  Cf. Clark v. Ross, 284 S.C. 543, 571, 328 S.E.2d 91, 108 (Ct. App. 1985) (holding the trial court erred in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees and expenses based on an unserved affidavit without affording the opposing party the opportunity to question the affidavit and the information it contained).Â Â Â  
 AFFIRMED.  
GOOLSBY, HUFF, and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Because oral argument would not aid the Court in its decision, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Madera Utilities v. SCDHEC
text:
Prehearing Report / Proposed Opinion


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Madera Utilities, Inc., Appellant,
v.
South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control,
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â John M. Milling, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-124
Submitted January 1, 2006 â€“ Filed February 24, 2006Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
William Benjamin Rogers, Jr., Rogers & Munnerlyn, PA, of Bennettsville, for Appellant.
Julie F. McIntyre, S.C. Dept. of Health & Environmental Control, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Madera Utilities appeals a circuit court order affirming an administrative law judgeâ€™s decision denying its motion to add parties to the action under Rule 19(a), SCRCP.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In October 1985, Madera Utilities purchased the right to operate the Heatherwood Wastewater Treatment Facility (WWTF) in Central, South Carolina.Â  Madera operated the facility under a National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permit issued by the Department of Health and Environmental Control (DHEC) in September 1998.Â  Among other things, the permit required Madera to complete certain construction projects and eliminate discharge from the facility by September 1, 2000 in accordance with a schedule of compliance.Â  Madera did not challenge the permitâ€™s terms at the time of issuance.Â  
Madera failed to comply with the NPDES permit by neglecting to eliminate the facilityâ€™s discharge by September 1, 2000.Â  In response, on September 28, 2001, DHEC issued an administrative order that outlined the violations, set a new schedule of compliance, and imposed a $5,000 fine.Â  Following receipt of this order, Madera requested a contested case hearing before an administrative law judge.Â  In its Prehearing Statement, Madera asserted that in order to reach a full and fair resolution of the dispute, Pickens County, the City of Clemson, and the owners of the property on which the WWTF is located should be added as parties.
In a pre-hearing order, the ALJ treated this request as a motion to join necessary parties under Rule 19(a), SCRCP.Â  The order stated that while the requested parties may have interests that relate to the action, Madera was the permit holder and operator of the treatment facility.Â  Accordingly, the ALJ denied the motion.Â  
At the outset of the hearing before the ALJ, Madera stipulated that it did not comply with the NPDES permit or the accompanying schedule of compliance.Â  During the hearing Madera asserted that it was impossible for it to comply with the order because: â€œ1.) Madera does not have the financial resources to complete the construction required to eliminate its discharge; and 2.) Madera does not own the real property on which the facility is situated and thus cannot undertake the required construction without the permission of the propertyâ€™s owner . . . .â€Â  
Mr. Rogers, the secretary and sole remaining officer of Madera, explained during the hearing that Maderaâ€™s non-compliance with the permit and subsequent order was not willful.Â  Specifically, he asserted that Madera made attempts to obtain financing in order to make the necessary improvements to the WWTF, but was unable to obtain funds because it does not own the property on which the facility is located.Â  Mr. Rogers also informed the court that Madera was in discussions with the Pickens County Regional Authority and the City of Clemson regarding a possible purchase or assumption of the facility.Â  
Following the hearing, the ALJ issued an order in favor of DHEC dismissing Maderaâ€™s arguments as insufficient to warrant relief from the permitâ€™s enforcement.Â  Madera appealed this decision to the Board of Health and Environmental Control who affirmed and adopted the ALJâ€™s order.Â  This decision was subsequently appealed to the circuit court, which denied the appeal without an opinion.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Maderaâ€™s sole contention in its appeal to this court is that the previous tribunals erred in failing to join Pickens County, the City of Clemson and the property owners as necessary parties under Rule 19(a), SCRCP.Â  We disagree.
Rule 19(a), SCRCP provides that a party shall be joined in an action if:

(1) [I]n his absence complete relief cannot be accorded among those already parties, or (2) he claims an interest relating to the subject of the action and is so situated that the disposition of the action in his absence may (i) as a practical matter impair or impede his ability to protect that interest or (ii) leave any of the persons already parties subject to a substantial risk of incurring double, multiple, or otherwise inconsistent obligations by reason of his claimed interest.

After reviewing the record, and the ALJâ€™s ruling on this issue in particular, we conclude that neither the ALJ nor the other tribunals erred in refusing to add the requested parties.Â  As the ALJ noted, while the City of Clemson, Pickens County, and the landowners may have interests that relate to the current action, Madera is the permit holder and the operator of the facility that is subject to regulation.Â  As such, Madera has not shown how failure to join the parties would impair or impede their ability to protect their interests or subject them to the possibility of incurring double, multiple, or otherwise inconsistent obligations.
AFFIRMED. [1]
STILWELL, KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
